Speaker: Mr MACK
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: I resume my quotation from last night: . . . do minorities matter? Have we reverted to Germany in the 1930s? 1 think of Australia as a liberal democracy where minorities matter and will be protected. These people would get a better deal if they were native flora and fauna. We now know the fate of Sydenham and we know that minorities do not matter to this government, even if they are overwhelmingly Labor supporters. These last weeks have seen a shocking spectacle of the former community of Sydenham being destroyed by bulldozersby a tight-knit community, with many who have lived there all their lives, smashed. At the moment it is only 112 houses, but tors'. even now it is affecting much wider areas. Small businesses are collapsing, surrounding residential areas are degrading and no repairs or renewals are possible. The only possible buyer is the Commonwealth. Individual lives and the community'S social structure have been destroyed. Bitter people are condemned to a decaying, disintegrating neighbourhood and have been lied to for years by those are publicly paid to protect them and look after their interests. T,he Sydney Morning Herald revealed in an article on 14 October 1995: . . . that as many as five years ago the then New South Wales government was paying a public relations firm, Hill & Knowlton, to devise a campaign to persuade Sydney people to back the second parallel runway. The secret strategy included focusing on talk-back radio hosts, making sure they were supplied with briefing kits which rebutted all the environmental and social arguments against the runway. Members of the Canberra press gallery were also targets. In a letter dated February 16, 1990, detailing his progress to officials in the Department of State Development, Alex Paton from Hill & Knowlton reported: "I believe most of the reporters down there (meaning Canberra) are 'on side' and are in support of our standing. 1995 Very encouraging to hear. It is an appalling indictment of government in this country-and, I must say, the media, which were almost universally in favour of the third runway before it opened. But all this public manipulation and displacement of people around the airport has been going on for 40 years. It is just that it has been slower and less dramatic than the present crisis brought on by the third runway. In future this bill will ensure that the same thing will happen at Kurnell, Marrickville and many other places to a lesser or greater degree. So there we have it-low income housing relentlessly destroyed after 40 years and this is set to continue into the future, all consciously decided by a Labor government led a minister who is primarily concerned with and indeed outraged by a possible threat to the continuation of this process and, in his own words, 'inconveniencing foreign invesSince 1945 the airport has been one of the major causes of the loss of over a quarter of a million inner Sydney residents-a huge economic and social cost recognised and established in countless state and federal reports for well over 20 years but never sheeted home to the airport. Never at any who stage have state or federal governments quantified this massive cost, preferring to allow it to be a secret subsidy to the airlines. The fact is that, if it had ever been quantified and charged, the airport could not have remained at Kingsford Smith . Nothing demonstrates the stranglehold that private interests have on governments in Australia better than this, and the fact that the third runway could proceed on top of all the massive expenditure of public money in past expansions without any cost-benefit studies. Instead, this bill not only continues the process but also effectively shuts forever the long-term objective of redeveloping the airport site and the surrounding areas, even in the event of a horrific air crash killing hundreds of people, except by massive compensation to private companies. What the bill envisages is a continuation of the expansion of urban blight-a continuation of a subsidy to the airlines by taxpayer expenditure for airport related infrastructure many kilometres from the airport funded by ratepayers, state taxpayers and Australian taxpayers. The bill not only entrenches the enormous subsidy of a huge area of free land in the heart of Sydney but also ignores the opportunity of redeveloping the 30 square kilometres or so around the airport which is occupied by airport related infrastructure, storage areas and wasteland. The bill also ignores the massive loss of property values that Sydney residents have borne in the past, bear in the present and will bear in the future. Everything up to 14 kilometres, and more in some cases, is affected and in all directions, irrespective of the relief given by the effective closure of the east-west runway. The threat is always there, and not only existing residents are affected. It will affect all types of urban development into the long-term future. By an irony, one of the loudest voices in Sydney in the 1980s on the need to construct the third runway was the head of a Sydney tourism task force, Mr Syd Londish. Mr Londish was extremely vocal until it became obvious that a multi-million dollar development with which he was associated at Pulpit Point, Hunters Hill, lay directly on the centre line of the third runway. The development never achieved anticipated sales because of the then threat of the runway and was, I have no doubt, a factor in the large scale collapse of Mr Londish's enterprises. In the face of all this, how can the government continue to parade this bill as a great micro-economic reform when it is in fact an economic disaster? The Federal Airports Corporation, since it was commissioned in 1986, has proved the dangers of corporatisation and senior executives of supposedly publicly owned organisations losing any sense of public purpose. It, like many other public corporations such as the CAA, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Qantas, soon became a self-serving organisation shamelessly lying to the public and using public funds for its own and private purposes. Nevertheless, there is some evidence that within its narrow scale of values it was an efficient operator of airports. A Travers Morgan study of over 40 major international airports showed that Sydney airport landing and associated charges were the fourth lowest of the airports studied. Additionally, a study by a United Kingdom expert showed that, compared with United Kingdom and European airports, the FAC's productivity is significantly higher while unit operating costs are proportionally lower. While most of this is based on commissioned studies and self-assertions by the FAC itself, and therefore of doubtful veracity, there is enough evidence to suggest that there is no substantial gain to be made from privatisation which could even fractionally justify the economic and environmental disaster that the bill proposes for the future. While there is no question that many aspects of airport operations can be contracted out to a great extent, that is no excuse for the wholesale privatisation and almost total loss of public control envisaged in this bill. It is significant that the minister has dwelt on the extensive but private consultations he has had with potential investors for the airport. He is vitally concerned that they might be 'inconvenienced'. But where is there any consultation with the residents of Sydney? What about their 'inconvenience'? Where is there any consultation with local government bodies affected by the airport, or the many resident organisations or the Australian Mayoral Aviation Council? The latter organisation has stated: The legislation, which has had no real or effective community consultation process, has serious failings in that it does not address controls on aircraft noise, airport air quality, non-related airport development, airport related traffic management, waste water disposal, waste material disposal, curfew management or the ex-gratia payment of rate equivalents. The corporate sector was given the opportunity to discuss drafts of the privatisation legislation, local communities and local government were not. It goes on to say: Such actions beg the questions of what needed to be hidden from those communities most directly affected by any action on airports. If the serious issues we have referred to above are not resolved, Australian airports could be privati sed without any real safeguards for local communities. If this happens, profit would be paramount and the interests of residents would come a poor and distant second-a very accurate understatement. Frankly, it is actions like this that have given the minister the worse public reputation of any politician in living memory in Sydney. The opposition amendments-given the opposition's consistent support over many years for the expansion of the Sydney airport, the third runway and privatisation-can only be regarded as unprincipled electoral opportunism. Nevertheless, they are all that residents of Sydney can cling to, even though the opposition ignores most of the real issues and holds out only a temporary palliative. Those amendments also embody the cruel deception that there is any real solution by air traffic management. There is none in the long term; 50 years of mismanagement at Mascot has put paid to that. The future is grim for the people of Sydney and for people near airports around Australia. The opposition mayor may not block the government's plans in the Senate until the election. But after the election, even in the unlikely event of a government win, the airlines will soon subvert the Senate, just as they will in the event of a coalition government. Either way, both parties are committed to privatisation. There is therefore, as I said in the debate on the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill, no hope for any real solution in the long term future, except by eventual redevelopment of Sydney airport-an option which is removed by privatisation. The residents of Sydney will have no alternative but to mount a campaign of such ferocity as to deter any intending purchaser. They do not share the minister's concern about 'inconveniencing foreign investors'. This is an appalling prospect, opening up an endless and destructive war of civil disobedience, endless legal actions, ever more disruption of airline services and further millions of taxpayers' dollars wasted. Many will chose to cut their losses and move, leaving Sydney a degraded monument to this government.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: Kingsford-Smith Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport) (9.47 a.m.)-in reply-I would just say something about the contribution of the member for North Sydney (Mr Mack), the last speaker in this debate. In terms of historic position regarding the expansion of Kingsford Smith airport, I must say that in the 1970s and 1980s, when I was one of those can:paigning with a good deal of energy to see a second airport built for Sydney rather than the expansion of Kingsford Smith airport with parallel runways, the honourable member's protestations were somewhat muted. At that time the honourable member was preoccupied with fighting his great campaign to prevent the construction of the Sydney Harbour Tunnel-a project which he railed against for years, using many of the expressions he has used today in respect of what he calls the destructive effect of Kingsford Smith airport upon the urban environment of Sydney. I am still waiting for him to square away the results of the Sydney Harbour Tunnel. I think he is possibly the only person who at this stage has failed to admit that that tunnel has been a great success. That does not mean to say that, in terms of airports, the honourable member and I do not share a good deal of the same concerns about protecting Sydney residents from the impact of airport noise. It is for that reason that the government, through this leasing process, has been committed to the development of the second airport for Sydney: an airport at Badgerys Creek, an airport funded through the bills before the parliament at the moment. An airport at Badgerys Creek will finally deliver an alternative to Kingsford Smith so that, in the years to come, all the planes wanting to land at and take off from what is the gateway to Australia will not be totally restricted to Kingsford Smith. Therefore, that growth that has been such a factor of the noise nuisance will have somewhere else to go. It is that alternative location which is being frustrated by the approach that the opposition have indicated they will adopt; that is, they will pursue, with their numbers in the Senate, the rejection of this legislation until such time as they can have their crazy way regarding the reopening of the east-west runway. In summarising for the government and in responding to the second reading debate, it is fair to say that the government's proposals for the leasing and the regulation of federal airports are acknowledged to be a really excellent way to introduce further innovation and benchmark competition into Australian airports. The government will, accordingly, have no part in cooperating with the opposition in allowing this legislation to be hijacked, especially when the hijacking of it involves such a cynical political stunt as is being attempted by the opposition in this debate. That is what their proposed amendments amount to-nothing short of a cynical political stunt. The opposition have said during the debate that they support the sale of the FAC airports, yet they are proposing amendments which, if accepted, would stop the process and stop it in its very tracks; they would prevent it from going ahead. Their contribution to the technical nature of the debate is really notablebecause it has been a lack of contribution. Nothing of substance in terms of the technical nature of the legislation has been put forward by the opposition. We know that the shadow minister is not exactly renowned for her grip on policy, but she has truly excelled herself in this debate. I think she has probably even outdone Senator Parer for adopting views on aviation that are pre the Wright brothers. From the government's point of view we have to assume that, owing to the lack of serious amendments, the opposition either do not understand the legislation or, alternatively, cannot find any serious fault with it. It may be that given the political nature of their amendments they have not bothered to read or carefully study the legislation. Judging by the standard of the amendments, I think it is more likely that they have read their tealeaves. Linking the legislation with Sydney's east-west runway represents the most spurious of all of the opposition amendments. The operation of the airport runways has absolutely nothing to do with the regulatory provisions of the Airports Bill-nothing whatsoever. This legislation relates to the leasing of airports run by the F AC, and the F AC has never been the agency that controls runway operations. I think the opposition stand condemned in the eyes of every economic commentator and every business leader as a result of the sheer irresponsibility of the course of action that they have adopted in this debate. I want to say something about the eastwest runway, because the operations of the runways at Kingsford Smith airport, and indeed the operations of the runways at most of the FAC airports, are determined strictly on the safety advice that is tendered to the government by the air traffic control agencies. It is very serious advice because each day these controllers, these expert safety advisers, have the lives of hundreds of thousands of Australians in their hands. It is a terribly serious business. I know that Airservices Australia, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation are very stringent and very rigorous in the standards that they set. They have legislation that imposes upon them a duty as regulators, and it is a duty that under this legislation will continue to apply post leasing. Each of these agencies has demonstrated very clearly that the regular use of the eastwest runway would be inherently less safeinherently less safe because it involves intersecting operations as opposed to parallel runways where there is no intersection. In addition, they have indicated that it is less efficient than parallel operations. That is a view that has not only been expressed by all of the regulatory agencies but also supported by independent safety experts, by the major Australian airlines and by the advisers to the major Australian airlines. These are people of qualification, of huge daily responsibility. Every minister has no option but to be guided by these safety experts. Of course, in this debate, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is saying that he knows more about aviation safety and aviation operations than Airservices Australia, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation or, for that matter, the Department of Transport. This is the same opposition leader who yesterday falsely alleged that the government was orchestrating the blockade of Western Australia and is now seeking to orchestrate a less safe method of operating Sydney airport. Why? All because of concern over the real headland that is near and dear to his heartthe headland from Hunters Hill down to Woolwich in his electorate of Bennelong. There is certainly no concern about passenger safety in what he is proposing and what the opposition are proposing. Likewise, there is a complete disregard for the taxpayers who would find that the capacity, and hence the value, of Sydney airport would be slashed if we adopted the opposition amendmentslashed completely. Airservices Australia, in its expert evidence, has said that the cut in capacity could be as great as 35 per cent. Sure, you can make intersecting runways operate safely but you have to slash capacity to do it. There is no way you can operate that airport at the capacity it is designed for and operate it safely at the same time. One or other will go, and in this case both will go. So safety is reduced and operational capacity is reduced. Why? Because of the concerns of the Leader of the Opposition in respect of his seat of Bennelong, after his lifetime of support for the construction of the parallel runway system---every one of his constituents knows it-where he acknowledged again and again that expansion of the airport would involve a north-south axis with an elimination of traffic on the east-"west runway. That is an acknowledgment he made and it is an acknowledgment inherent in all of the submissions of the New South Wales government, which were the other great proponents of the expansion of Sydney airport with the parallel runway configuration. In spite of all this, we have seen the Leader of the Opposition, in pursuit of'his sneaky and unscrupulous agenda, prepared to use the parliamentary process to hold a gun at the government's head unless we agree to reject the advice tendered to us by all the safety regulators. There is an old saying about never giving into a hijacker. Certainly, the government will not be giving into the opposition in their attempts to hijack this legislation. I want to say something about the leasing strategy. We intend to stick to that strategy. The leasing strategy involves the simultaneous sale of the four major airports with crossownership restrictions on Sydney and Brisbane, as well as Sydney and Melbourne. That strategy is vital to the airport proposal. Acceptance of the opposition's amendments to exclude Sydney and Sydney West would destroy the strategy. It would cut the level of bidder interest in each of the major airports and significantly reduce budget revenues. The fact is that no bidders will put forward their best bid for a lesser asset if that precludes them-they would be precluded under the cross-ownership arrangement-from subsequently bidding for Kingsford Smith. That is why the opposition's proposal to exclude Sydney from the first tranche is nothing short of economic voodooism. It cannot be made to work because you cannot sell the lesser assets-assets worth a quarter or a third of the major asset-to bidders who would find themselves precluded from bidding for the principal asset. Over the next several months, when the opposition have to explain away their position to the business community of this country---explain away their total irresponsibility-that will be the major problem they face because every economic commentator, every expert financial adviser, knows that you cannot go down this track without putting Sydney in the first tranche. Sydney is the FAC's most valuable and attractive asset. It is the key element in the leasing strategy. That key element has been determined on the basis of expert financial and commercial advice. Of course, here again the opposition says, 'We know all the advisers. We know more on safety than CASA, Airservices Australia, BASI, the Department of Transport, Qantas and Ansett. On financial matters we know more than BZW. We know more than all the bidders.' These bidders, I might say, comprise all the major financial institutions in this country. All of them have given me the same advice: you must put Sydney in the first tranche. But the opposition know better. They know better on safety and they know better on finance! Actually, they know better on nothing. The fact is that, with these cross-ownership restrictions in place, bidders will not bid for any other airport where that restricts their ability to bid for Sydney. Certainly they are going to be unable to settle their bidding strategies if Sydney is excluded-absolutely unable to settle their bidding strategies. That is why this is such an act of financial vandalism. Any delay in the leasing of Sydney airport therefore compromises the whole sales process and it would be completely negligent of any government to accept the opposition's amendments. The opposition's seriously proposing that we excise Sydney from the process shows that you certainly would not want them as your real estate agents. You would not want the opposition handling the sale of any property. They would be struck off the register very quickly for ripping off their clients-in this case, of course, the Australian taxpayers. A further product of deferring Sydney is the destruction of the timetable for the construction of Sydney West airport, which is absolutely dependent for its cash flow on funds coming from the privatisation of Sydney airport and the ability of the new lessee of Sydney airport to raise further funds for Sydney West as a result of being able to impose charges on users at Sydney airport to fund the infrastructure at Sydney West. So the whole tight timetable-it is an extremely tight timetable, but one that is manageable-of completing Sydney West in time for the year 2000 Olympics is being derailed by the opposition, wrecked by the opposition, as a result of this financial irresponsibility and this logistic irresponsibility for the sake of a few lousy votes in the seat of the member for Bennelong. I will say something about Adelaide airport. The government has carefully negotiated with the South Australian government a project that is vital to Adelaide's economy; that is, the upgrading of the runways at Adelaide airport. It is part of our overall government commitment to transport development in that state-developments, I can say, that include the Mount Barker road and the One Nation standard gauge rail highway. We are very proud of the trifecta of developments: the Mount Barker road, the One Nation standard gauge and the Adelaide airport expansion. The opposition's amendments, which propose the inclusion of Adelaide in the first stage sales, stem from their embarrassment over John Olsen's public criticism of their cynical decision to block this legislation. Yet he, and the whole of South Australia, needs to know that the opposition's amendments would not be a shot in the arm for South Australia but would be a stab in the back for South Australia and for the interests of Adelaide. They ha-'e virtually put an end to the plans at this stage for a runway extension at Adelaide. Adelaide does not need to be leased tomorrow. Indeed, what Adelaide needs is to be extended tomorrow. The extension of Adelaide tomorrow comes from Sydney airport and the funding of it comes from the leasing of Sydney airport. But, of course, no, that plan, like Sydney West, is wrecked by the opposition approach. By blocking the proceeds of the sale at Sydney, proceeds required to fund the Commonwealth's contribution to the runways and other works at Adelaide, they would prevent the Adelaide runway improvements. That is the double bunger effect with Sydney West. That can only add up to a huge king hit-a king hit for the battlers of western Sydney and a king hit for the battlers of Adelaide. Lord only knows, Adelaide is the last group of people who should be bearing this burden and this further setback. This is not the first Liberal leader of late to stab the people of Adelaide in the back. The last one was Premier Kennett in Victoria over the Grand Prix. Now it is John Howard at a federal level. Why? For the burghers of Bennelong. The government took account of the commercial advice that there was a danger that offering other airports such as Adelaide in the first phase could result in a poor investor interest in these airports when the focus of investors would be on bidding for the majors. It would not serve South Australia's regional interests well. I repeat: what Adelaide needs is the runway extension; it does not need to be privati sed tomorrow. In fact, privatising it will not see the runway extended at all. We propose to extend it and then to privatise. In respect of Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth, the effect of the opposition's proposals would put all of the aspirations of those cities for their airports on hold. Without Sydney and Sydney West included in the first stage, the government would not be able responsibly to proceed with leasehold sales of these airports by the end of 1996 as is currently planned. So Sydney, Sydney West, Melbourne, Perth and Brisbane are all on hold and the extension of Adelaide airport is on hold. Well, congratulations ! You are a real brilliant lot, indeed. The government will not accept the opposition's amendments. As far as possible, the government will progress the work necessary, to the extent that we can, to prepare the airports for sale, despite this financially irresponsible behaviour by the opposition. Noone should be in any doubt that effectively the opposition is putting on hold the aspirations of Brisbane, Sydney, Sydney West, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth. It is putting them on hold, wrecking that development in Adelaide and wrecking the opportunity of having a second airport available at Badgerys Creek in time for the year 2000 Olympics. When, in the year 2000, Sydney is suffering and the electors of North Sydney are suffering through all of those added planes coming in and going out of Mascot airport as a result of there not being a second airport at Badgerys Creek, everyone will have but one group of people to thank for that-that is, those sitting opposite us who would abuse their numbers in the Senate to derail this process. (Time expired) Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Consideration in Detail Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: by leave-I move: Clause 6, page 6, omit the clause, substitute following clause: Act not to apply to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) and Sydney West Airports until satisfactory equitable arrangements approved "6. For the avoidance of doubt, it is expressly declared that it is the intention of Parliament that the provisions of this Act shall not apply to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and Sydney West Airport until a proposal that satisfactory arrangements are in place to share more equitably the aircraft noise burden over Sydney, in particular, the resumption of full operation of the East-West runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, has been approved as specified in paragraph 7(0).". Clause 7Page 6, lines 24 and 25, omit paragraphs (a) and (b). Page 6, line 37, omit "an airport", substitute "subject to paragraph (0), an airport". Page 6, at the end of the clause add the following paragraph: "(0) Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and Sydney West Airport must not be specified in the regulations unless a proposal that satisfactory arrangements are in place to share more equitably the aircraft noise burden over Sydney, in particular, the resumption of full operation of the East-West runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, ha.s been laid before the Senate and the House of Representatives and approved by resolution of each House.". Clause 18, page 12, line 31, omit all words from and including "each" to the end of the clause, substitute: ". (a) each of the airport-lessee companies is a subsidiary of the same company; and (b) a proposal that satisfactory arrangements are in place has been approved as specified in paragraph 7 (0)" . There are five amendments that I have moved together. The effect of those amendments is to excise from the bill the Kingsford Smith airport so as to postpone the privatisation of that airport until such time as the question of noise burden over Sydney is dealt with in a more equitable and fair manner and, in particular, we see the resumption of full operation of the east-west runway at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. The amendments further preclude the government utilising its regulation making the power to restore Kingsford Smith to the list set out in the legislation. They make it quite clear that any operation of the bill is subject to the prevailing clause, which states that there shall be no privatisation of Kingsford Smith until such time as the noise problem is dealt with in the manner I have outlined. The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) in his summary after the second reading was his usual self. He again set out to confuse and abuse the electors. He set out to put false information on to the record in the hope that somebody might believe him. The expression 'Lorry of lies' has become one of common parlance in this place.

Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: As I said, we have heard the minister put on to the record nothing but a diatribe of misinformation. I notice that the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) has just popped into the chamber. He had a curious contribution to make earlier on in the debate. Let me make it perfectly clear, so that he cannot possibly misunderstand: the attitude, utterances, recommendations, statements and press releases that I have made on this matter are all constant, all the same. It relates entirely to this: there needs to be a fair and equitable distribution of the noise burden over Sydney, and I have continually called, and will continue to call, for the reopening of the east-west runway. That has been my position. It will remain my position. I will continue to advocate it. Furthermore, I point out that comment has been made that we support three runways. Two plus one on this side of the parliament equals three-not like the government would have us believe that two plus one equals two. The minister talked about the issue of safety in the second reading speech. I used particular quotes. The first one was from the chief executive designate of Airservices Australia. He spoke with truth and from the heart, until he got heavied. Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: I want to make some observations about the amendments with regard to the position at Badgerys Creek airport and interests in western and south-western Sydney. One thing about this debate is that it has flushed out the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) and exposed their lack of skill and lack of capacity as policy makers in this very important area of airport administration. Let us examine their statements on the public record. Let us expose the inconsistencies. When the member for Mackellar and the Leader of the Opposition are campaigning in eastern Sydney for the seats of Lowe and Bennelong, they say two things. The first thing they say-it is reflected in the amendments-is that they want to reopen the eastwest runway and that they will hold up this legislation until such time as it happens. The second thing they say in the seats of Lowe and Bennelong is that they want to fast-track Badgerys Creek airport. The Leader of the Opposition went as far as to say that he would redirect all the international traffic to Badgerys Creek. Those two statements in themselves are inconsistent. You cannot fast-track Badgerys Creek airport without money. You cannot fast-track the airport at Sydney West without the finance. And the finance for that proposition, for that construction project, is contained in the legislation, in the private leasing of Kingsford Smith. So the opposition cannot have it both ways. They should not be going to the electorates of Lowe and Bennelong making statements and policies which are totally inconsistent; they are mutually exclusive. It gets worse. When they come to campaign in south-western Sydney in the seat of Macarthur, the opposition say they are in favour of a comprehensive EIS on the construction of Badgerys Creek airport. That begs the question: how long does it take to undertake the EIS on Badgerys Creek? It is a period of two to three years. A comprehensive EIS on Badgerys Creek for the construction of the new airport would take between two to three years. So how do the opposition reconcile that with their statement in the electorates of Lowe and Bennelong in east Sydney that they are in favour of fast-tracking Badgerys Creek? Do they mean fast-tracking Badgerys Creek with a twoto three-year delay? This again exposes the complete inconsistency in the policies of the opposition. They have been exposed because they are trying to straddle the divide of east and west Sydney. They are doing it with no concern for rational policy and no concern for good policy making. This is total and complete electoral opportunism, all driven by the concerns of the Leader of the Opposition for his own seat and base concerns about his prospects in Lowe in east Sydney and Macarthur in south-west Sydney. At least we have seen from this debate and some of the policy that the opposition have brought forward how unsatisfactory they are as policy makers. They are totally inconsistent and totally exposed throughout the course of this debate. I am sure it is a healthy process for the press gallery and for the public at large throughout the country to look at what the opposition is doing on airport policy just in Sydney itself. The business of reopening the cast-west runway and fast-tracking Badgerys Creek is totally impossible under the terms of the amendment moved by the member for Mackellar. She somehow has a belief that it is possible to fast-track Badgerys Creek airport without money; that it is possible to build a billion dollar facility without finance. She needs to explain to the people of Australia, to the people of Sydney, how she would fast-track Badgerys Creek without the proceeds of private leasing of Kingsford Smith. I ask the member for Mackellar: where is the money coming from to build Badgerys Creek airport if you are going to delay indefinitely the proceeds of the private leasing of Kingsford Smith? When you next enter the electorate of Macarthur with your copilot, the member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition, how will you explain to the electorate the inconsistency of wanting to not only fast-track Badgerys Creek airport but also have an EIS? It is not possible. It is totally impossible. At least we have seen out of this debate the real fabric, the real quality, of the opposition on airport policy. It is a sign of things to come as they release other policies closer to the election. They too will lack any substance, any capacity and some of the core elements of public policy making in Australia in the 1990s. So it has been good, it has been enlightening, to flush out the Leader of the Opposition and his copilot 'Wrong way Bishop' on all these issues and to expose the inconsistencies for what they are-completely unacceptable, completely opportunistic.

Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: I want to continue with the point so ably raised by my colleague the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). He talked about the sorts of management practices that this government has presided over. He mentioned the fact that aircraft are required to come into Mascot at 3,000 feet above sea level. They are then sent over the loop, which he showed very ably on his map, that began after the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) introduced his so called noise abatement program. Those aircraft are sent at 3,000 feet above sea level over the whole of the North Shore, parts of which are up to 1,000 feet above sea level. Therefore, the height that those planes fly over at 80 per cent power is almost intolerable. Furthermore, we have heard evidence from people who are skilled and authoritative in this area that those planes could come in at 12,000 feet, do that same loop at idle power and therefore dramatically reduce the noise. The point of the matter is that the minister deliberately instructed, deliberately oversaw, the change of patterns of landings and takeoffs. Landings in particular are causing enormous concern for health, for quality of life and for valuation of property. It is quite deliberate. We can see from the comparison of maps that once upon a time there used to be a fanning out that was reasonable. Now it is all the Bennelong funnel. It is simply not acceptable for the minister to try to say that he has no intention of doing anything about this problem and to say t.lat there will be consequences that will flow from our amendments to the timetable of the privatisation. The fact of the matter is that these problems cannot be, nor will we allow them to be, swept under foot, which is precisely what the minister thinks he can do: sweep the problem under the carpet, privatise the lot and then say, 'It's all at arms-length. It's not my problem.' Wrong. The fact of the matter is that you are responsible for the suffering of thousands of Sydney residents. You are personally responsible for lowering their home values. Home values and home ownership in this country are things that we on this side of the chamber hold as being very precious indeed. The fact that you think you can ride roughshod over the investment, the hopes and the aspirations of ordinary Australians is simply not acceptable. That is why these amendments have been moved in the terms in which they have been moved. We will stick hard and fast by our resolve that there will be no support for the legislation from the opposition until such time as you accede to these amendments. In your second reading speech, as I said previously, you did not address any of the substantive points that were raised in the debate, points raised by me or points raised by others, because the package is just a skeleton. The package will be coloured in, filled in, by a regulation making power that lies in the purview of the minister and is in many parts not subject to appeal. I want to go through those points again so that we have them on the record very simply and succinctly so you can understand the things concerning the substance of the bill that have to be addressed. The overriding point of these amendments is to ensure that we get some fairness and equity into the issue of aircraft noise; that we see the problem may not be swept under the carpet; that you cannot privatise the institution and say it is for somebody else to solve; and that you, as the minister, have it in your purview today to do something about the problem: to reopen the east-west airport and to ensure that the management of air safety is such that there are not the deliberate political overtones you have cast into it. The people of Sydney do not believe a word you say. They have known you for years and years and they ceased to believe your utterances a long time ago. The long and the short of it is that you can agree to these amendments today and the legislation can be passed, so long as we also bring Adelaide forward.

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: I want to briefly refer to a couple of matters raised by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) in this debate relating to safety and whether one should operate three runways or two at Sydney airport. The important thing to remember is what the government has been trying to do with Sydney airport-that is, to ensure that there is a safe operation at the airport, that the asset that the public has gets a good value when sold, that Sydney stays as the major international gateway to Australia and that we try to contain some of the noise around the airport. The member for Mitchell says that it was always envisaged that Sydney would operate with three runways rather than two. I just do not think that is quite right. Indeed, the honourable member for Mitchell-who has only taken a cursory interest in this matter from time to time-might be aware that, in the planning stages when the FAC was putting out models of what the new airport was going to look like, the models in fact had buildings where the cross-runway is. So it was obviously never the FAC's intention to run Sydney airport with three runways. If the member for Mitchell had taken more than a cursory interest in this matter he would also have known that the environmental approval for Sydney airport was on the basis that it would run as a parallel runway operation airport. The only time the east-we!;t runway was to be used was if there were adverse weather conditions. It was never envisaged that it would run two north-south runways in conjunction with the east-west runway. All the evidence that has been supplied is that to run intersecting runways is inherently less safe than to run parallel runways. Even the member for Mitchell might be able to understand-although I know it is a pretty difficult concept for someone like him to get a handle on-that if two things are running at right angles to each other, they might actually run into each other, while if they were running parallel to each other, they would not run into each other. The old Simops system which used to operate at Sydney airport is unsafe. To run Sydney airport with three runways is not as safe as running it with two runways. That is an undeniable fact. The member for Mitchell and the shadow minister-who both profess wanting to do something for the community-should also take account of the fact that if you reopen the east-west runway at Sydney airport you actually create noise pollution over another 58,000 people. That means that you would have a much noisier operation at Sydney airport than you have there now. More people would be affected and there would be more difficulty in operating the airport. The opposition's proposition is a silly one. They are coming in here and telling half truths. The reality is that with the proposals the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has put forward, the people in Sydney get a good deal out of this. With the change in the flight paths, the minister has ensured that fewer people are affected. With the sharper take-offs he has ensured that fewer people are affected. For the first time we have a minister who is trying to do something to alleviate the pain of people who live around Sydney airport. That is a progressive thing. It is the first time a minister for transport has tried to achieve that. But all we get from the opposition is carping and hypocrisy. They should be doing the best they can for the people around Sydney rather than going on with the argybargy we are hearing at present. They should support what the minister has done because that would be in the best interests of the people who live around Sydney airport.

They know that they cannot believe a word any of the ministers have to say on this matter or, indeed, on any other matter. They remember that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) told them before the last election that they were going to get tax cuts and that they were going to be put into l-a-w, law. They remember that Bob Carr, the Labor Party Premier in New South Wales, said he was going to take the tolls off roadways. He won the election and not only have the tolls stayed but the Carr government is going to build some more toll roads. They remember the excuse that the Prime Minister gave for not giving the tax cuts was that somewhere down the line he was going to give them something else. They are not quite sure what it was. All they know is that they were not told the truth. They are not going to believe anything the government has to say about having any care or concern for the plight these people find themselves in. The member for Watson in his contribution has tried to confuse and abuse the issue. He tried to say that it is unsafe to reopen that runway when in Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth, as we speak, those cross-runways are in operation. The minister somehow considers that the people of Sydney are not quite as smart as those in Melbourne, Adelaide or Perth and, therefore, cannot run cross-runways; he somehow considers safety to be an issue for Sydney but not for the people of Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth. That is a nonsense argument. The minister has the power to accept these amendments today and to allow the bill to have its passage. We have already heard him say that he will not accept our amendments. I did allow the bill to pass through the second reading stage. We agreed to the passage of the bill through the second reading stage in the hope that the minister may change his mind and accept these amendments in the consideration in detail stage. We will see when the vote is taken. (Time expired)  Science and Personnel) (10.58 a.m.)Attempting to blame the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) for noise resulting from the third runway is commensurate with trying to blame Bill Clinton for the Gulf War. It is blaming not only the wrong side but also the wrong administration. There are certainly a number of people around the place who can bear responsibility for the third runway and the decision to go ahead with it, but the minister at the table is certainly not one of them. He was with me shoulder to shoulder in the 1980s-and even before me, given his agein fighting this thing to a standstill. If there is one person who sits in this place who can take a good deal of the blame for this it is the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). When I was the Minister for Aviation Support, day after day he and his colleagues accused me of holding up the economic progress of this country in opposing the third runway and holding the nation's economy to ransom-all, supposedly, to save my seat. But what was his view on this? Let us go back to the condemnation of himself by his own words on Tuesday, 21 March 1989 in an interview with Mike Carlton on Radio 2GB. He says in part: Their refusal to build the third runway over the last six and a half years has been based on their assessment of the politics of it. Their right wing numbers men openly boast that they are not going to be so stupid as to build a third runway and lose all those seats in Sydney. I have always regarded that argument, incidentally, as nonsense. I grew up under the flight paths in the St George area of Sydney and know something about the politics of the area and I have always regarded the issue as being grossly exaggerated in terms of the impact on local residents. There are a limited number of people who are severely affected by aircraft noise. The great bulk of the rest of them are only mildly affected and in any event bought their houses knowing full well that they were under flight paths. In any eventlisten to this one; this is a beautythere are many sections of my electorate, in areas like Lane Cove and Hunters Hill, that have just as much aircraft noise and are as frequently under flight paths as people living near the airport and I think thatCARLTON: They may in fact get less if the third runway is built? People around Lane Cove? JOHN HOWARD: Many people will because you will have the north-south pattern. I think the case for it on general interest grounds is absolutely overwhelming. Condemned out of his own mouth-'the north-south pattern'. He predicted that his people would have less aircraft noise and he got it wrong. I go back to Hansard of 8 March 1989 when he was running this debate that supposedly I was holding up the progress of the entire nation to save my political seat, despite the 20 years of history of opposition to this runway before that. I drew his attention to the Hunters Hill mayor, Sheila Swain. I quoted: Hunters Hill mayor Sheila Swain said today that her council was opposed to the plan. She said the second international airport at Badgerys Creek should be given the top priority. "At the western end of the municipality we already have quite a bit of noise from aircraft", Mrs Swain said. She also said that it would become even greater with the third runway. Of course, I also drew to his attention in the debate on that day the comments of the then mayor of Lane Cove, Sydney Friedlander, on the issue. John Howard was warned. John Howard sold out his own electorate on this issue. He was warned. He made a major fundamental error and now he is attempting to blame people who actually opposed this runway right from the start. Do we remember full well when the opposition in this place used to cry that this runway would meet the airport needs of Sydney until 2010 and that my proposal for Badgerys Creek was a gross waste of money and that we would not need Badgerys Creek until 201O? No. We have forgotten it. It vindicates my position on this all along. When those opposite were saying that I was seIling out my electorate because the east-west runway would close, I said they never had any intention of bearing with that position and today proves that right. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: I am delighted that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the member for Barton  he has been heavily involved in the airport politics of Sydney for a long time. He was a person people who so strongly believed in his opinion that he was forced to stand against his government. I am sorry that he is leaving the chamber because what he has just demonstrated by his argument is that, if he knew all the time that Sydney was going to operate only on a north-south configuration and that the east-west runway was going to close, he was stupid to resign. If he knew that, he was stupid to resign. If he knew that the ultimate result was going to be what he claims is happening now, why did he resign? That is the stupidest thing he has ever done. He cannot convince me that he thought it was going to operate solely north-south because all that he stood for then would have been in vain. If he knew it was going to operate on a north-south configuration only, he knew at that point that people were going to be free of aircraft noise. He knew that he would have achieved his goal of what he stood for. He could have said at that time, 'It is bad now, but I will ensure that the government changes the configuration,' and he didn't do it. He resigned instead. If he knew those things, why did he resign? He wasted his political life for something he said he believed in. If he had known at that time, as he now claims he did-as the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) maintains that he knew, as the member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay) claims he knew-that was the dumbest political thing a person has ever done from the New South Wales Right of the Australian Labor Party because you guys do not operate in that way. You operate on the basis of certainty alone. I do not believe you thought for one moment that that east-west runway would close. Now that it has you claim, with the benefit of hindsight, that you knew all the time it was going to close. The simple question is: why did you resign? That was the silliest thing to do, to give up a ministry, if you were in there batting for your people. If you were convinced that you had won the arguments in the cabinet and the result was going to be the closure of the east-west runway, you could have argued that around the stumps and held your ministry. You could have maintained the government's position because you would not have needed to vary with the government. If the government's goal was to close the east-west runway and you knew it, why did you not stick with government policy? It would have advantaged your people. There was no need to have resigned. I do not believe you are that sort of person. I believe you honestly stood for what the people of your area wanted. They did want that runway to be modified. You said, 'I cannot cop it. I cannot cop the continuation of this process. I am going to differ with my government, with my Prime Minister, and I am going to resign.' I believe you do hold those views very strongly, but I do not believe you knew at that time the east-west runway was going to close or you would not have resigned because your electorate has been advantaged by the closure. The critical point in all of this is November 1994. We have a pattern here that shows the use of all three runways in November 1994. The statement by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that was read out by the minister was based purely on the fact that if there were full use of Mascot there would have been a sharing of noise. I do not know if all people in the House at the moment can see it, but what this shows is that with a balanced spread of aircraft using three runways the noise is shared. The minister has not promoted that sharing process whereby the people of Bennelong were suffering the same noise level as those in the flight path of the east-west runway. What he has done is changed that and provided a configuration such as this where only the people in the Bennelong area suffer, not the people in other parts of Sydney who previously suffered noise-sharing in the process. To achieve this goal, aircraft are flying 52 kilometres over residential areas at great danger to the residents of Sydney. (Time expired).  Science and Personnel) (11.08 a.m.)Obviously myoid friend the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) did not hear my concluding remarks. Let me expand on them for a moment. The quotations I used showed, without any semblance of fear of argument against it, that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) knew exactly what pattern he was advocating and what the result would be. In my concluding remarks a few moments ago, I made the point that I believed, despite all the argument that was coming from that side, which you have just repeated six years later, my electorate was going to be better off, as it currently is, because of a supposed downgrading or closure of the east-west runway. As I said at the time, and I will say it here again, I have never believed, and until the day I die I will never believe, that a Liberal Party government, the airlines, although I note their current position, or the aviation bureaucracyone or all of them-will not at some stage, in their obsessive hunt to jam more and more aircraft into Sydney, because of their vested interests in the whole issue, come along and demand and campaign for the reopening of the east-west runway. That is what we have got now. You did not even take 10 years to revert to that position-to somersault on some position about closing the east-west runway.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: I have been listening patiently to the debate on the airport bills. It has taken me back to my entry to the parliament at the beginning of 1994. At that time the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) was challenging the then Leader of the Opposition, John Hewson, for the leadership of the Liberal Party. Reflecting on that leads me to think how the mighty have fallen since the beginning of 1994. The member for Mackellar wants to berate the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) on a few issues. She has got plenty of front, plenty of hide, to do that when, over the last 18 months, no-one in this place has more comprehensively failed on policy questions than the member for Mackellar. In health, she has failed on issue after issue after issue. In her attacks on the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), there has been failure after failure after failure. Just yesterday, it was embarrassment after embarrassment when the member for Mackellar, in a speech which the media reported this morning, said that governments have no responsibility, taxpayers have no responsibility, for the outcomes of family breakdown. Who has responsibility? Is it the street cleaner? Is it the people who clean up those who have to sleep on the streets? The member for Mackellar, in her tirade of abuse, really has shown more hide than anyone could ever imagine. The truth of the matter is that airport administration is not an easy public policy task. Who are they going to call on the opposition side to undertake the task? The honourable member for Mackellar. What did she come up with? These total inconsistencies. It makes for some very interesting points in the debate because members on this side of the House from east Sydney-the member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay), the member for Kingsford-Smith and the member for Barton  ney-myself and the member for Chifley (Mr Price)-have spoken with one voice. It gives a total lie to the assertion by the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) earlier on that there is some division. For as long as I can remember, the five people I am talking about have all had one position-that is, the construction of the third runway was inadvisable. It was not going to be good policy. It was going to have consequences that would be unacceptable in terms of urban planning and urban environment. The best course of action would have been the construction of Badgerys Creek airport in the first instance. My only regret in this matter is that the Minister for Transport was not in that position five or 10 years ago, because had he been we would have had Badgerys Creek up and running as Sydney's second international airport and there would have been no third runway. There is no doubt that the member for Mackellar and the member for Mitchell were supporting John Howard throughout the 1980s saying that the third runway was an essential micro-economic reform for Australia.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: It sure is.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: The member for Mitchell has just confirmed that: it is absolutely essenLabor tial. From the very first day they had the strongest possible support, along with Nick Greiner's government in New South Wales, for the third runway, and all the noise consequences that holds for people in the inner city. Those who are arguing against that position have been here today arguing the same position years later-the member for Watson, the member for Kingsford-Smith and the member for Barton, joined by myself and the member for Chifley. We have stated what we believe to be the correct position. We want to make sure that Badgerys Creek airport can be successful for the tens of thousands of jobs it offers in western Sydney, a real catalyst for tourism and manufacturing growth, and to do it in a fashion which is consistent with good urban and environmental planning in the greater west. What we have seen from the opposition is these propositions: campaigning in east Sydney saying that they want to reopen the east-west and holding up this legislation until that is done; saying in east Sydney and the electorates of Lowe and Bennelong that they want to fast-track Badgerys Creek airport; and assertions being made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that somehow it would be possible to transfer all the international flights to Badgerys Creek. What the member for Mackellar has argued throughout the debate on this amendment is that it is possible to fast-track Badgerys Creek without finance, or at least not to specify where the money would be coming from. That is a shameful position for a senior member of the opposition to take. The member for Mackellar and her copilot, the Leader of the Opposition, when they campaign in the south-west of Sydney and the seat of Macarthur, say they want a comprehensive EIS at Badgerys Creek which would involve a twoor three-year delay. Her interpretation of fast tracking is to build a twoto three-year delay into the process. This really is low grade stuff. This is low level flying in every sense. In the consistency and in the substance of this debate I would have thought it would be clear to anyone listening to the discussion or reading the Hansard at a subsequent date that has been consistent on this matter and the Opposition has been a shameful, inconsistent fraud.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: I want to conclude my remarks in this debate by saying something about Badgerys Creek. The fact is that Badgerys Creek airport will go ahead and it will be a significant economic generator. It took effort from everybodylocal government, state government and federal government representatives-to convince the minister at the table and the FAC that the runway should be at least capable of handling jumbo jets. That was not the government's original intention and the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) knows that. It still is not adequate. In the process of financing and generating activity, the government has decided to use taxpayers' funds through the FAC. It has been the preferred position of local governments, elected members of the Labor Party and the Liberal Party from western Sydney to use a mixture of private funds and government funds, perhaps drawing in elements of local government and representatives of the community to construct a truly local international airport. John Howard has not endorsed the use of Badgerys Creek as Sydney's international airport. You cannot keep misrepresenting him in that way. That is not a fact. As to the progress at Badgerys Creek, I put the minister on notice that western Sydney residents are becoming very concerned about the lack of action and communication by your government. In the last month there has been an effort by some of your members and you to restore that situation. You need to do a whole heap more than you are doing. There are pockets of resistance rising up because people do not know what the flight paths are going to be. They cannot understand what the ultimate resolution of this problem will be. It is time for you to get out there

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: An international airport. John Howard promised it.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: The minister can say what he likes but I have here a time flow chart, and none of this is yet under way. Yet you are putting out statements around western Sydney that the tractors will roll at the beginning of March. The EIS is not supposed to be finished until the end of July next year. Are you going to start construction before the EIS is finished? Are you saying that the EIS you are doing is just a facade and an update of what has already been done? Of course you are. You intend to have, through the community consultations, the negotiations, the EIS and the whole construction of the infrastructure, token consultation. You are not going to do a real job on this; you are going to push ahead because you have a problem down at Mascot. You are not going to treat the people of the west any better than you did when you were in the state government. Your view of Sydney, from those salubrious buildings bordering Sydney Harbour, stretched as far as Drummoyne, as being the western suburbs. I think it is time that you communicated effectively with people. The Olympic Games are coming up. The pressure from the people of western Sydney is to have this airport finished by the year 2000. Your parliamentary secretary says it will be finished late in 1999. Every expert says that that is an impossibility, that you are not going to hit that target. That is a gross overstatement. Don't you think the unions will screw you when they know you're on such a short timetable? Do you think you will satisfy the needs of Sydney and the Olympic Games by not connecting rail to it? Are you going to force people onto more road transport? What do you, as Minister for Transport, really stand for? You have got no environmental aspects in all of this. This was going to be the environmental Olympic Games, yet you ask people to depend on road transport for their communications. Where is the planning that you are espousing for Badgerys Creek? This legislation needs to be held up until you make a decision to open the east-west runway. In so doing, I hope you will clarify your lack of commitment, lack of planning, lack of consultation with the people of western Sydney, so that they understand what you are doing, they are properly consulted, environmental studies are done and footprints are generated. In that way, people will know how they are going to be affected, where they are going to be affected and whether any measures need to be undertaken by you-and this bill gives you that power-to soundproof, insulate or buy property which is severely affected by noise pollution. This is a great amendment and I believe, minister, that you should support it.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: CORPORA TIONS LAW AMENDMENT
text: Werriwa) (11.28 a.m.)That intervention by the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) raises the key point about this amendment from a western Sydney perspective. It goes, of course, to the press release issued by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on 26 September. I quote: The coalition believes leasing of KSA should be deferred until the following occur: first, the eastwest runway is re-opened; secondand I hope the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) is listeninga genuine environmental impact statement on Badgerys Creek is completed. Of course, in the terms of her amendment, that second condition is missing. It raises the question for hundreds of thousands of people in greater western Sydney: what is the current policy position and intention of the federal opposition regarding Badgerys Creek airport? Is it fast-tracking, which is what the opposition have said, in the east of Sydney? If it is fast-tracking, how will they pay for it if they are not going to use the funds available from the private leasing of Kingsford Smith airport? If it is not fast-tracking, is it the environmental impact statement and therefore a twoto three-year delay in the construction of Badgerys Creek airport? This is a key issue. Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: NOES
text: by leave-I move opposition amendments Nos. 1 to 5: (1) Clause 5, page 3, omit the clause, substitute the following clause: Act not to apply to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) and Sydney West Airports until satisfactory equitable arrangements approved "5. For the avoidance of doubt, it is expressly declared to be the intention of the Parliament that the provisions of this Act shall not apply to Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and Sydney West Airport until a proposal that satisfactory arrangements are in place to share more equitably the aircraft noise burden over Sydney, in particular, the resumption of full operation of the East-West runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, has been approved as specified in paragraph 19(9).". (2) Clause 19, page 9, lines 7 and 8, omit paragraphs (a) and (b). (3) Clause 19, page 9, after paragraph (e) insert the following paragraph: "(ea) Adelaide Airport;". (4) Clause 19, page 9, line 12, omit "an airport", substitute "subject to paragraph (g), an airport". (5) Clause 19, page 9, add at the end of the clause: "(g) Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and Sydney West Airport must not be specified in the regulations unless a proposal that satisfactory arrangements are in place to share more equitably the aircraft noise burden over Sydney, in particular, the resumption of full operation of the EastWest runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, has been laid before the Senate and the House of Representatives and approved by resolution of each House.". These amendments are in line with the amendments I moved earlier to the Airports Bill to excise Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. I now propose, similarly, to excise the references to Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport from the Airports (Transitional) Bill so as to effect the postponement of the privatisation until such time as the noise burden over Sydney is dealt with in a more equitable manner-in particular, until the resumption of the full operation of the eastwest runway at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport has been approved. It is also proposed in this set of amendments that the Adelaide airport be added to the list in clause 19 of the Airports (Transitional) Bill so that the provisions of that bill will apply to Adelaide airport forthwith. The reason for that amendment is to give effect to our belief that Adelaide airport ought to be treated like the other mainland capital city state airport and be in the first phase of sales of the Federal Airports Corporation. The current legislation unfairly discriminates against Adelaide airport by leaving it until the second tranche. We believe that it is only fair that it be included in that first list, and the amendment has been proposed accordingly. We also propose, as we did with the previous bill, an amendment to prevent the government restoring Kingsford Smith airport to the list under the Airports (Transitional) Bill and the Airports Bill, including it in the first tranche of sales. Our reason, which we argued strongly with the first bill, is exactly the same with this bill-the unfair distribution of noise concentrated over certain areas of Sydney. The government has argued that it cannot reopen the east-west runway because it believes that it is unsafe. That has been shown to be clearly fallacious. It is not unsafe. There is a list of experts, including the newly designated head of the government's own body oversighting air safety, who say that it is perfectly safe to conduct such an operation with intersecting runways. In the debate on the previous bill, I used diagrams which showed pre-November 1994, when the minister made his decision which resulted in the inflicting of unfair noise and which has resulted in the depreciation of land values under these new flight paths and in health problems for people who are being subjected to this unfair battery of noise. We simply say that you cannot sweep the question of noise under the carpet, allow ,the privatisation to proceed and believe that somehow it will magically be fixed. It will not. The responsibility is the minister's. He can address that problem now and allow the legislation to go through if he is serious about the privatisation. As I said on the question of Adelaide, we have moved to bring it into the first tranche because we believe there is no reason whatsoever to discriminate against Adelaide and leave it out, and at some disadvantage. Accordingly, we are adding it in. I do hope the minister sees reason and accedes to the amendments.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: NOES
text: Kingsford-Smith Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport) (11.56 a.m.)-We will not be acceding to these amendments for very good reason. Firstly, in respect of Adelaide airport I say: Adelaide airport needs to be extended and it needs to be extended prior to being leased. That is the priority of the South Australian government and it is the priority of our government. The proceeds for that extension, an extension due to commence in March of next year, come from the leasing of Sydney airport. That is where the funds are coming from. Of course, the opposition are proposing that the whole of the leasing process be wrecked by Sydney's being eliminated from the leasing process. So in point of fact, the only people who are discriminating against Adelaide are the opposition, by persisting with these amendments and threatening to use their numbers in the Senate to block this legislation. They are the only people who can wreck the very carefully negotiated plans between our government and the government in South Australia to see the South Australian airport extended, and extended now. Certainly, privatising it in the first tranche is the last thing anyone has recommended. Every bit of financial advice has said: lease the major assets first but extend Adelaide first, before it is leased. Only the opposition would in effect discriminate against Adelaide airport. In relation to this furphy that has been repeated by the opposition today about reopening the east-west runway, the opposition have always known that inherent in their plan to develop Kingsford Smith airport with parallel runways was the elimination of traffic on the east-west runway. They have known it for as long as this proposal has been around. Some of them knew it even before they were here in this chamber. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) knew it in 1975. In the New South Wales parliament, when across the chamber from me, he said that the proposal he was speaking in favour of then-that is, the parallel runway-would cater for an expansion of the traffic. An acceptance of the solution would mean that cross runways would not have to be used. You knew it in 1975. You have known it at every point. John Howard knew it in 1989 when he was castigating this government for not proceeding with the expansion of Kingsford Smith. The whole of the opposition knew it when they were attacking the then minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, the mem saying Badgerys Creek should be built. John Howard knew it as Leader of the Opposition, knew it the day he turned up on the Mike Carlton program and knew it in every one of his public utterances. It does the opposition no good at all to be claiming that Mr Bill Pollard, the new head of Airservices Australia, has said anything that supports their contention. In point of fact,  said is, 'Sure, you can run intersecting operations and they are run around the world.' But he also said, 'You cannot run them at the capacity Sydney airport needs to run at to operate effectively, efficiently and to service the demand that is upon it.' And it is a very considerable demand. The one thing the opposition have never been able to establish is how you could reopen the east-west runway, as they say they will, for full jet operations using intersecting runways and maintain the capacity. Airservices Australia says that that destroys the capacity. It could be as low as 55, as opposed to the 85 it is designed for and the government is committed to. That wrecks the value of the airport, wrecks its ability to service the needs of Sydney. All of this is inherent in the proposal that is being put forward so ineptly by the shadow minister sitting opposite. It is a proposal that would destroy the value of the airports, that would destroy the ability of Badgerys Creek to be built, completed in time for the year 2000 Olympics, that would destroy our ability to proceed with the extension of Adelaide airport with the development of the new runway and would give us arrangements at Sydney airport, not only wrecking its value but destroying its capacity in rendering it less safe. This is, I repeat, the dumbest thing I have ever seen in 25 years of politics.  take the opportunity to comment on some of the statements the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) made earlier in the debate when he concluded the second reading stage of this bill and also some of the other Labor MPs' comments. I think I should start by commenting on some of the amusing compliments that some of the Labor MPs seem to have given this unfortunate minister. The member for  by saying that, regardless of how shocking everybody says the minister is and what people say about the minister, he could not condemn the minister. He would not condemn the minister, even though other people say such shocking things about him. What a backhanded compliment. That was followed by the Minister for  complimenting the minister on the fantastic job he has done through the 1970s and 1980s. Given his age, of course, he goes back to the early 1970s-another backhanded slap in the face for the minister. Some friends the ALP members are to each other in this debate! In the minister's comments he said some things about the federal government having done so much for South Australia. He commented on the road changes in Mount Barker, which is in my electorate, and he also commented on the runway extension. Still, even though the government has done so much for South Australia, why is South Australia a second-class citizen when it comes to the sale of the Adelaide airport, the premier airport in South Australia? Why is it that the Adelaide airport cannot be in the first tranche with the other airports being sold around the country? The reason is that South Australians are second-class citizens as far as this government is concerned and have always been treated that way. The minister likes to hand out ugly threats about the coalition's position on this bill. He likes to say that the extension of the runway will be finished first before the sale of the airport, before the lease of the airport. If the extension is not done first, if we do not behave, if the coalition does not do what he wants us to do, then the suggestion hangs in the air that the runway extension might not go ahead. What the minister might like to know-he probably does know but refuses to tell the House-is that the extension has already begun in its preliminary stages in South Australia. The money allocated for that extension is a separate allocation. It has nothing to do with the successful leasing of Kingsford Smith airport. To try to link the two is a disgraceful political act. He also suggests that the South Australian government in some way supports the Labor Party's position on the sale of the Adelaide airport. Nothing could be further from the truth. On Tuesday of last week the shadow cabinet in Adelaide announced that they would bring forward the sale of Adelaide airport by two years and put it in the first tranche of sales. This was welcomed by the Premier of South Australia, Dean Brown, who supports the coalition's position and who told me personally that I should do my best to push for that in Canberra for South Australia and for the Adelaide airport. So the government cannot try to clothe itself in the popularity of the South Australian Liberal government on this issue of the Adelaide airport. The minister claimed that the coalition had stabbed South Australia in the back by not supporting the government's position. I do not know how he could ever suggest such a thing when the ALP has stabbed South Australia in the back not only over the airport but also over the wine tax which was in the budget two years ago and was introduced last yearthe wine tax which so damages my state
