South-East Asia is a market for fresh food produce, which is produced in abundance in South Australia. One of the great problems in trying to get that produce to places like Singapore and Hong Kong is that the size of the planes that take off from Adelaide airport is not sufficient to make it worthwhile for corporations in that region to use Adelaide airport. text: Kingsford-Smith Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport) (12.15 p.m.)-They are being done in the eye by you. It is worth going through the history of this question of the extension of Adelaide airport because it was a prime matter for debate at the time of the last national conference of the ALP. Selling the airport without the extension does not solve any of the problems alluded to by the member for  runway for international fully-laden wide bodied jet take-offs. It does not solve those problems at all.

text: At the ALP conference last November, and he negotiated very successfully. It is for all these reasons that John Olsen responded to this proposal, as reported in the Adelaide Advertiser of 27 September. "We wouldn't want the problems in Sydney," he said, "to delay what is a long overdue runway extension and the upgrading of Adelaide airport." Those are not my words. They are John Olsen's words. We won't extend.' It does not matter that the money won't be there now for the extension. It does not matter that this whole process is to be delayed. Of course, this is a great betrayal. It is an enormous sell-out of the interests of South Australia. Let me say this: it is well and truly on your heads.

Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: NOES
text: Mackellar) (12.20 p.m.)The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) really does make it up as he goes along. No wonder nobody ever believes a word that passes his lips. First of all, we have this wonderful statement that he did all these negotiations for this fabulous deal for South Australia with the Leader of the Opposition, whose name eludes me. And where did he conduct all these marvellous negotiations? At an ALP conference. Isn't that just typical of the way this government does business? You don't talk to the legitimately elected members of the parliament who form government, you don't talk to the Premier of the day; you go off into some little smoke filled backroom and have a little chat to your Labor Party mate. That is the way it has always operated in the New South Wales Right, and well we know it. Any time we need to be reminded of it, we take a good look at Peter Baldwin's face and we remember the way you play. How dare you come into this place and -;-y you stitched up a deal with the man who was Leader of the Opposition, whose name nobody can remember. How dare you come in here and tell us you bypassed the proper Westminster and parliamentary processes so that you can do deals on the sly with your mates. What an affront you are to this parliament. It is no wonder you have the reputation that you have-well documented in that book Mates. It should be compulsory reading for anyone who has to do business with you. The extension to the Adelaide airport has already begun. This process of sale of airports is not, even under your plans, meant to begin until 1 July 1996. We have at the moment no regulations, no details, no nothing, of what it is you will be seIling, just a broad skeletal outline. And you have the audacity to come in here and tell the people of Adelaide that you will stop funding and stop building their extensions because you are going to sell Kingsford Smith airport in 1996 and that will provide the money to pay for it. Does that mean contractors are not going to be paid in the interim? Does that mean they have got to wait? Where is the explanation for those people? You really do make it up, Minister. This is all justified on the basis that you did a nasty little deal in a backroom with one of your mates, somebody who is not in government, rejected by the people of South Australia-and for good and proper reasons-who were bankrupted by the Labor Party, just as Victoria was bankrupted by the Labor Party. You left generation after generation imbued with debt. And this is the same Labor Party. It does not matter whether it is the South Australian Labor Party, the federal Labor Party or the New South Wales Right of the Labor Party. Each and every one of you operates with the same lack of morality-no ethics. You bypass, as I said, the properly elected people of the day and do a little deal to hypothecate the payment of the bills for the extension of the runway out of the proceeds of a sale that is not even meant, under your plan, to take place for years to come. You have the hide to stand here and tell us you care about the people of Sydney who suffer under those traffic patterns-the traffic patterns that you forced on them after November 1994, the ones that you say have to be. I remind you again, Minister: two runways at an airport plus an extra one makes three. Only the Labor Party is unable to count. Obviously, you cannot count with regard to the Adelaide airport either. I think it is incumbent upon each and every body in this place to take note of a couple of your comments about your grubby little deals and the way you think you can run it for the Labor Party's benefit and to hell with anybody who is not part of your coterie. I have got news for you. We are sick of deals that were done between former Prime Minister Hawke and present Prime Minister Keating with Bill Kelty and Peter Abeles at Kirribilli. We are sick to death of other sly little meetings that take place in other people's - ouses, trying to influence the outcome of thmgs of which we never know the consequences. We are sick to death, and the Australian people are sick to death, of the sort of hypocrisy you bring into this place, saying that you care about battlers when you could not even find one if you fell over one. Since when have you ever been in contact with small business people who are every day risking their very house and home in order to make interest repayments on loans they have taken out in order to conduct a small business and employ a few folk? In that area you are pretty special too. You put every enc-m­ brance in their way to stop them from being able to employ young people. The people of Australia have had enough. We are sick to death of the fact that the Labor Party thinks it is their preserve to get rich while the people get poor. When it comes to the question of Adelaide, we are not going to wear your cant. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: NOES
text: Kingsford-Smith Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport) (12.25 p.m.)-That was a particularly irrelevant diatribe. I thought the deal that Mike Rann did for South Australia at the last ALP congress was a pretty good one. It was a very good one, in fact. What it did was to secure for South Australia something that South Australia had wanted, asked for and been denied for many years, and that is the extension of the airport.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: NOES
text: Why did you deny them?

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: NOES
text: It had been denied by the FAC.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: NOES
text: No, by you. You're in charge.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: Order! The member for Mitchell will cease interjecting.  commercially they did believe it was within their priorities until very well into the next century. That was the FAC's position. The  debate. It was about the only factual thing that he said. Mike Rann went to that conference and he secured a very good outcome that was all about South Australia. Let me tell you this: there was nothing grubby about it. It was a very honourable process with a very honourable outcome. I know it; Mike Rann knows it; everyone who was at that conference knows it; everyone in South Australia knows it; and Mike Rann's political opponent, the Premier of South Australia, particularly knows it. This is what he had to say about the outcome. A media release on Premier Brown's own letterhead said: Premier Dean Brown today welcomed the agreement between the Commonwealth and South Australian Governments for the funding of the Adelaide Airport runway extension. "This agreement represents the start. of a new era for Adelaide Airport," Mr Brown said. "The extension of the runway will open up South Australia to significant new international tourism opportunities and increase airfr-ight <;>f peris-able goods, particularly seafood, Into internatIOnal markets, especially in Asia. "The State Government made improvements to the Adelaide Airport and lengthening of the runway a key priority when it took office 18 months ago. "Now, after intense negotiations with the Federal Government we have secured agreement on major elements of the upgrading work. He was elated; he was delighted. Everyone can take great credit for this, including Mike Rann. Dean Brown was delighted and John Olsen thought it was terrific. Everyone was extraordinarily happy. But then what happened? We reach this chamber on the eve of the forthcoming election and, for the sake of a few lousy votes in John Howard's own electorate of Bennelong, the whole process is derailed. Sydney airport is excluded from the sale by an abuse of the opposition numbers in the Senate. The proceeds are not there to go on with this work. Sure, it will be extended, because we are people of our word. But there is no doubt that, because the sale will be delayed and, if they go ahead with their threat, this legislation will have to be reintroduced in the next parliament some time after the next budget, there will be a delay of at least a year in these processes. That delay will be purely and simply the work of those sitting opposite. The aspirations of Dean Brown, the aspirations of Mike Rann, the aspirations of the people of Adelaide and the aspirations that go right across the political course will all be dashed as a result of this act of absolute and utter stupidity by the shadow minister and John Howard. But for what? For the sake of a handful of lousy votes to try to convince people in Sydney that John Howard does not mean what he said over 20 years of active political pursuit; that is, that Kingsford Smith should be expanded and that a parallel runway should be built in the certain knowledge that its construction would involve the north-south axis. He said that again and again. He knew what he was saying. Everyone opposite and everyone in Sydney knows that th.is was always the position of the opposition, as it was the position of the New South Wales Liberal government. Their own submission to the EIS said that traffic on the east-west would be eliminated, that people would be worse off with the north-south but that it was all right because more people would be better off rather than worse off. There was always an acknowledgment-a political acknowledgment, absolutely clear, pure and simple-by everyone in the opposition and by everyone in New South Wales that this traffic was going to operate on a north-south axis, as it has to on safety and capacity considerations. Today you think you can pull the wool over the eyes of the people of Sydney and have them not believe what you have been telling them for 20 years. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: Order! Before I call the honourable member for Mitchell, I remind the House that the stage we are at is the consideration in detail of the bill. We have before us the member for Mackellar's amendments Nos 1 to 5. As such, the comments should be directed to the amendments before the House. I ask honourable members to bear that in mind during the debate.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: NOES
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I understand your requirement to take note of the matters before the House. The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), who has just resumed his seat, said that everybody in Sydney knew that there was going to be a change in the configuration with the construction of the additional north-south runway and everybody knew that aircraft were going to be directed onto the north-south runway.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: NOES
text: You knew.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: NOES
text: You were in government and your own minister, Gary Punch, resigned because he did not know that. He did not know it, and neither did anybody else. You are saying that Punch is a dill for resigning because he should have known there was going to be a change in the configuration. That is what you are saying. It is illogical, Minister. Nobody knew that. The three runways were going to be used in conjunction. That has always been the position of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Fraser government and successive members of the Liberal Party. We were quite clear as to how Sydney airport was to be used. You interfered politically. You interfered in November 1994. You thought influencing seats was a smart thing to do to win the New South Wales election. You could not believe your success when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) endorsed that process. Laurie Oakes, in an article in the Bulletin, had it exactly right when he described what happened. It is no use you denying that. This is exactly what occurred: the Prime Minister and cabinet came in and said that we were going to do it this way, we were going to close the east-west. The Prime Minister has a record of closing runways. He closed one at Bankstown because it aligned with his house when he lived there. That is the fact of the matter: he closed a runway at Bankstown. He has a record of closing runways if they do not suit his personal convenience. That is the way in which this whole thing has operated: it is a matter of personal convenience. In relation to the minister's description of the deals done in Adelaide, it is not a process of inclusive politics. It is a process of doing deals. Minister, you described it that way. You do not stand for the whole community. You represent the Labor Party here. You do not represent your fellow Australians. Nothing could be clearer in the way in which you are now trying to blackmail the Australian community into agreeing with you because it is a Labor Party policy. Let me refer to the precision of these amendments and what the bill proposes. Your proposition, Minister, is that if we prevent leasing of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) all of your works programs will stop. The budget does not say that. The budget is not predicated on any sales. I have here your transport budget, which you signed off. Here it isyour budget for 1995-96 for the transport portfolio. It is all your stuff. It has pretty pictures in it. There is not a thing in it about the sale of airports being essential for you to complete your program. You do not say that in your budget. Is your budget wrong? Let me have a look at the works proposed at Badgerys Creek which you say cannot proceed unless you get this legislation. The EIS was supposed to have started in July. It has not yet started, so there has been no loss of money. Even though much of the work has not started, the works program for Badgerys Creek until the end of this year, 1995, was supposed to have been community consultation, negotiation and funding of lease, environmental assessment, design and documentation, infrastructure design, flight path and airspace management, EIS on Elizabeth Drive, west Sydney orbital stage 1 EIS, the west Sydney orbital stage 2 EIS and the negotiation of contractual arrangements-none of this requiring a single dollar. It is all paper and telephones. Until the end of this year you do not need a cent for Sydney airport; you do not need a cent for Badgerys Creek. You do not need a cent until well into next year. But you are now saying that not selling Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport is going to stop the construction of Badgerys Creek and cause havoc in South Australia. Nobody will believe that. We just need to get that lorry of lies running around the suburbs telling the people what the real truth is, because you are certainly not telling them the real truth. The coalition's decision that you need to open the east-west runway is a logical and carefully thought through decision. It is not going to create disruption to anybody or anything. The fact of the matter is that you could give our proposition the tick here in the House, it could go through the Senate and it would be all done. Overnight you would achieve your results. But, no, you prefer to the blame others and say that it is going to cause havoc. It will cause havoc only if you choose to let it. (Time expired)  to wrap up some of my comments about the previous speeches made by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) in this debate.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: I am sure you will.  debate that he linked the sale of the Kingsford Smith airport to the extension of the Adelaide runway. Nothing could be further from the truth. Six months ago or more, when the Adelaide airport extension was announced, the government made no mention of this being linked in any way to the sale of Kingsford Smith airport. It is now just a convenient ruse of the government to say that the coalition in some way has some responsibility for the Adelaide airport. The reality is that this government is trying to yet again adopt the thuggery tactics that it has adopted for 13 years as a government in Australia. Mrs Bishop-It is far too late.  announcement and it is far too late for the minister, as the member for Mackellar says, to make it up as he goes along and try to link that into the debate. The minister also spoke about the extraordinary role Mike Rann played at the ALP conference in. the announcement of the extension of the Adelaide runway. It is extraordinary that Mike Rann would now be trying to involve himself in the credit for the airport extension at Adelaide airport. He was in government for 12 years, he was the minister for tourism, and he is now trying to come along and pretend that for some reason the government is going to say, 'This is a bipartisan issue. Let's all get the credit for it.' The reality is that the ALP did nothing as the South Australian government, except destroy the state's finances. The minister says that the aspirations of Mike Rann have been fulfilled. Big deal! For goodness sake, Mike Rann is not the Premier of South Australia and he never will be the Premier of South Australia. He was once a minister, he had his chance and he failed dismally. We are not going to let them try to ride on our wash, try to ride in on our success. The South Australian government, as I said before, supports the coalition's position of bringing forward the sale of Adelaide airport by two years and putting it in the first tranche. I never said that we should privatise without the extension of the Adelaide airport runway, as you claim that I did in your previous contribution. I never said that. They are separate items. The extension of the runway is in place and it is proceeding. Plans have been drawn up.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: NOES
text: We need money for it.  nounced six months ago had nothing to do with the Kingsford Smith airport. You did not say that back then. The plans have been drawn up and the system of road diversions that surround the airport is under way. The money was allocated. If you are now trying to go back on that, you will pay a large price in South Australia at the next federal election. There is no doubt that this government stands bereft of any principle with respect to this matter and so many other issues, as I have observed in my short experience as the member for Sturt. I am disappointed in the government, as are the people of South Australia. They have every reason to be. I hope the government will reconsider its position on some of these amendments and support the coalition's position.

Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: NOES
text: I am sure that the residents of the North Shore-whom the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has today tagged 'a lousy handful of votes' - will be very pleased to know that that is the way in which they are regarded by this minister. Apparently, they are to be denied the democratic principle of being able to express their point of view, just as we have seen the minister say that a duly and properly elected government in South Australia is bypassed in the doing of an unseemly deal in a back room of a Labor Party conference, with a Labor Party apparatchik who now holds himself out to be the Leader of the Opposition. The government has refused to accede to our amendments. We did let these bills pass the second reading stage to give the government the opportunity to see reason and pass the amendments. We then could have allowed the bill to receive a third reading. But the government has chosen not to do that. So, accordingly, we will again be opposing this bill at the third reading stage. I think what has been shown in the course of this debate is, very simply, that this Labor Party is unto itself, a law alone. It has no truck, it cares not at all, for anybody who is outside its sphere of influence or the people over whom it can exert influence. As I said earlier, if you really want to remember the lengths to which this lot will go, take a look every day at Peter Baldwin's face: bashed and meant to be dead. We have come to the stage in this debate where ordinary mums and dads-who are suffering at the hands of this minister's political decision to inflict noise pain on them-are becoming unhealthy; where psychiatrists are being involved; and, as I have said before, where property values are dropping. And all of this does not even register with the minister because he calls them 'a handful of lousy votes'. Well, Minister, I suspect that there are a lot other Australians whom you consider to be 'handfuls of lousy votes' who are going to rise up at the next election and just tell you what they think of you and your government. As for your interjections about 'shooting in the foot', you have not got any feet left. You have done it so often that you stand there on stumps at the end of your legs. It is time that you realised that you cannot ride roughshod over individuals' hopes and aspirations and simply disregard them because you have done some deal with some group. It just is not an acceptable Australian way. We will go forward to this election remembering many of the words that you have used in this debate to describe your contempt, your utter contempt, for individual Australians who are merely trying to get on with the business of running a family, of keeping a household together, of having some quality of life-and you have termed them 'a handful of lousy votes'. As far as I am concerned, Minister, every individual Australian has the right to be considered. It does not matter if they belong to the same political party or not. We have forms of government and governance in this country which have to be observed. Along with a lot of other people, I have read the texts of Mates and other books which show how you and your mates operate. As we go into the next century, we are going in there to have a clean government. We are going in there to have one that governs for all Australians-not just for their sectional interests and their mates. The Australian people have had enough. This cavalier attitude-this one that rides roughshod over the rights of individuals who are trying to be responsible-is simply not going to wear you lot any more. This debate has encapsulated it. This debate is about fairness and equity-concepts which I am afraid this government lost touch with a long time ago. Question put: That the amendments (Mrs Bishop's) be agreed to. The House divided. Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: PAIRS
text: I do not intend to delay the House on dealing with these amendments either, but I do think, as the bulk of these amendments relate to two issues-firstly, tax related issues, which presumably is the government acceding to representations made to them by potential bidders and, secondly, restructuring or new requirements for the FAC board-I think the minister does owe the House an explanation as to the reason for these amendments in a fairly concise way.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: PAIRS
text: Kingsford-Smith Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport) (12.55 p.m.)-As it has been requested, I will be more than happy to do that. The two tax related amendments are being introduced to clause 45 to ensure that holders of leases over the airports will be treated in the same way for taxation purposes as if they had been granted leases by a nontax exempt body-that is, the Federal Airports Corporation-and that lessees of the FAC are not disadvantaged by becoming lessees of an airport company, Clauses 74 and 76 are being amended to clarify requirements under the Archives Act 1983, and schedule 4 is being amended to provide future flexibility on the number of members who may be appointed to the FAC board. I commend the amendments to the House.

Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: PAIRS
text: I thank the minister for reading us those few things, but there are a couple of questions I would like him to answer. In relation to those provisions dealing with the definition of an asset, I wonder if the minister could clarify for the House the implications of that section and that amendment on concessionary leases which are presently held. Secondly, could he tell us why we need the additional flexibility for the board of the continuing FAC? I note from the amendments that it is proposed to enlarge the size of the FAC board. I wonder why that is necessary when, in fact, they are going to have less responsibility and not more.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: PAIRS
text: Kingsford-Smith Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport) (12.57 p.m.)-The advice to the House is that the amendment in respect of leases will have no effect whatsoever on sublessees. In respect of the second matter raised by the honourable member-that is, the question of FAC board membership-that merely allows for a variation of the numbers on the board in the future. In other words, the board does not have to comprise its full complement as the FAC proceeds down the track of its role being diminished through the disposal of the airports to the various lessees in tranche one and tranche two.

Are you going to have a hands-on approach or will you expect them to operate commercially and refer only certain matters to you?

Speaker: Ms WORTH
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.2) is a very important bill. I am pleased that I am able to complete my speech, which was interrupted by the adjournment debate two nights ago. Clearly there is already a lack of responsiveness in the system and the 'clever country' rationale for expansion is not being realised. Finally, I would like to comment on the government's failure to foster an economy which is able to absorb the young people being educated in our universities. When the Dawkins revolution was sold to the Australian public in 1988, a major argument for the changes was that Australia's young needed to be educated to fill the highly skilled positions that were to be generated under a Labor government. Parents and young people accepted this story and invested money, energy and hope in the acquisition of a university education. Too many have found that the government's sales pitch was a gross distortion of reality. While graduate unemployment is lower than unemployment for young people without degrees, there is overwhelming evidence to suggest that graduates have simply shifted into positions formerly held by non-graduates, rather than into the highly skilled positions promised them by the Labor government. Not only is this a tragedy for the non-graduates who are pushed into unemployment by the influx of graduates into positions previously held by non-graduates; it is also a tragedy for the young graduates who worked so hard towards a dream which they are now finding to be empty. When reading about the 1995 AustralianN ogel Literary Award last month, I was struck by the sense of betrayal expressed by the 27-year-old winner of the award, Richard King. Richard was quoted as saying: My generation was brought up being promised so much ... we found it wasn't there. This is a damning indictment of the Labor government that has been in power for the last 13 years.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: I join with the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) in saying this is a very important piece of legislation. The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.2) 1995 is the sort of bill that goes to the heart of the social justice debate in which the parliament has been engaging in recent months. On that, in my experience, working people in Australia at'e concerned not so much with ownership issues as with skills and opportunities, and the active role of government in enhancing the economic and social capability of those genuinely in need. Australia's education system is at the heart of this task. I had two reminders of this recently, both of them relevant to the higher education sector. The first of them was the comments made by Rupert Murdoch, expressing concern about the development of an underclass and the high level of youth unemployment in some parts of Australia. I thought people on the coalition side had a hide in making some of their comments on social justice issues, but for someone who sponsored the Thatcherite revolution in Britain and actively supported Reaganomics in the United States to be complaining about the development of an underclass is, indeed, exceptionally rich. The second reminder on these issues arose on Monday. I noticed in the Sydney Morning Herald that the average TER-the equivalent these days of what had been known as the HSC-mark was twice as high in the north shore and eastern suburbs of Sydney than in western Sydney and south-western Sydney. The interesting thing about those figures---of course, they are in relation to school education-is that once people from western and south-western Sydney gain entry to university they do as well as people from any other part of Sydney. This reinforces the importance of the link between higher education and school education and, in both sectors, the importance of the home learning environment. It is very important to broaden our concept of education beyond formal institutions, be they school education or higher education, to include the home learning environment where issues of advantage and disadvantage are so important. I outline four principles that I believe are significant in the parliament's consideration of higher education in Australia. The first of those principles, of course, is the need for quality outcomes. What we have found, with the internationalisation of the Australian economy, is that all factors of production have now become mobile, except human skills. In many respects, the quality of human skills determines a nation's wealth. The new growth theorists, who are becoming very popular in economic debates and forums, have emphasised the importance of a culture of innovation in a country in order to have successful trading and economic arrangements. A culture of entrepreneurship is very important for a nation's economic success. Higher education in Australia should be at the absolute vanguard of the shift in culture. Also, I think, on the issue of social values and leadership our universities need to playa more prominent role in the public debate. I was recently part of the parliament's delegation to the European parliament. As part of that, we listened to Chancellor Kohl, the German Chancellor, at the Council of Europe. He explained how all Western societies have an opportunity, in the 1990s and beyond, to define our societies by combining 'the humanism of antiquity with the rationalism of our times'. That is a beautiful phrase and a beautiful set of ideals and values that are all about excellence, quality, compassion and a more enlightened society. Our universities should be at the absolute vanguard of defining such values and actively promoting their worth throughout all parts of Australian society. The second principle I would define for the higher education sector is in terms of responsiveness to economic change and responsiveness to the internationalisation of the Australpromoting Ian economy. I have used this example in the parliament previously but I think it is worth repeating. Alcatel is a telecommunications company just to the north of my electorate. Its training cycle, its education cycle, is of just six months duration. Because of rapid technological change in that industry the company cannot sensibly plan ahead for the training needs of its staff for any more than six months. This emphasises the problem for those in school or higher education who want to focus excessively on fixed content. I notice that Bob Carr, the Premier of New South Wales, is trying to focus on content. Content, of course, is always changing as technology and our economy change in response to international pressures. In many respects, with regard to fixed content in the curriculum of schooh or universities, once people leave those institutions they remember very little of the content they picked up at school or university. The way of learning is all important and that is really where our universities should be placing more emphasis. Are our universities in Australia responsive to these influences? Are they responsive to the sorts of economic and social changes that Australia has gone through over the last 10 to 15 years? I have some reservations about institutions that are based on guaranteed income, institutions that are based on tenurethat is, guaranteed employment for staff no matter the quality of their outcomes. I have reservations about outdated management methods in the university sector in Australia. Our universities, essentially, are based on 19th century small '1' liberal values embracing diversity at any cost, a belief in learning for the sake of learning and a feudal protection of tenure and academic freedom. It is my very strong belief that our nation, with the challenges it faces over coming decades, needs much more than learning for learning's sake. We need learning and skills that are relevant to our economic position and our social requirements. This is where universities have such an important role to play. They must be relevant to the economy and, of course, provide social leadership in terms of more enlightened social values. The third principle I will address is this issue of a lifetime commitment to education. I think it is a peculiar thing in Australiaindeed, it is an unusual thing-when we look at some of our trading competitors. In Australia, education is seen as something that people undertake until their early 20s and it is somewhat of a task. What we need in Australia is an ethos of continuous, lifelong education throughout all parts of the population. There must be continuous updating of the skills and knowledge required for people to be successful in internationalised economic arrangements, successful in a post-industrial society. This issue of continuous education, a lifetime commitment, and the promotion of a government framework for lifetime education basically requires a revolution in our thinking about education, including the higher education sector and the systems of service delivery that we have inherited over the decades. The fourth question I will raise-and I mentioned this earlier on-is equity, the problem of intergenerational disadvantage in our post-industrial society. We really do need to tackle the fact that, while our schools can have a disadvantaged schools program and while we can have equity funding for universities, we need to link those initiatives to the home learning environment. That is the root cause of educational disadvantage in Australia in the 1990s. New forms of information technology are the great opportunity for linking the home and the formal learning environment. Some of these methods may be intensive in their case management. Some of these methods may be expensive in their case management and their administration for government, but it is an expense that is well worth meeting if we are to meet the challenge of a more inclusive society. If we are to find the sorts of remedies that Rupert Murdoch would press upon us in his pious complaints then we should realise that ever smaller government is not the answer. Some of these remedies have a fiscal cost. Those who want to argue the case for social justice and a more inclusive society should be willing to meet the cost. It is important to recognise those realities. Smaller government is not an answer when it comes to building a more inclusive, a more socially just Australia. I would suggest also that universities should be more active in addressing these issues of educational inequity and educational disadvantage. I was quite inspired to read a com Wilenski, one of the great educational administrators and reformers in Australia's history. He made the speech in my part of Sydney at the University of Western Sydney, in its formative days, on 10 October 1987. I think it is a very good statement to provide to the parliament. He stated: Issues of equity of access should not be afterthoughts forced on a university by reformist governments. They go to the heart of what a university is about. The socio-economic maldistribution in our university student population, the fact that children of poor parents are many more times unlikely to go to university than children of equal ability from wealthy families, represents not only a major social injustice and enormous waste of talent for society, but also a deviation from the pursuit of excellence by universities who as a result have less than the best students. It is little wonder that the half of the community which is less advantaged has not come to the defence of the universities when the universities appear to have so little relevance to their lives or those of their children. Of course, the fault lies to a large extent with the pre-university education system but universities can have a major role in influencing that system. There are big challenges for higher education in Australia in meeting each of these four principles. I was delighted to learn that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) has appointed a higher education management review team which is due to report in December. I also noticed with some degree of interest that the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and some of the other authorities in higher education were very concerned about the fact that there would be an external review of their relevance to our economic arrangements and to the training and skill requirements in Australia. I think it is a good sign that the universities are apprehensive about the external review. They should not be immune from the review process-the sort of reform, the sort of initiative that has affected all sections of our society, the school education system, TAFE, and all forms of learning. Universities should not be sheltered away, hiding behind walls of academic tenure and attempts to secure academic freedom at any cost. The legislation before the House is interesting and very important because it addresses some of these key issues of equity in the distribution of resources between states and the distribution of resources by the federal government between universities. The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.2) makes amendments to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 to adjust funding levels as a result of the allocation of new places, additional research funds, carry forward of quality funds and the inclusion of funding for 1997 and 1998. Funding will be provided to close to 6,000 new higher education places, plus those in the pipeline, in the years 1996 to 1998 to states with strong population growth and currently low participation rates. Queensland will major beneficiary of these places, as will South Wales and Western Australia. They will also be receiving additional places. I delighted-I note that my colleague the academics member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) is at the table-that the University of Western Sydney has been a major beneficiary of the additional growth allocation in New South Wales. I congratulate the minister, Mr Simon Crean, on his initiative. He is a minister is prepared to take on the difficult public policy task of redistributing much needed policy. university resources to areas of rapid population growth like the west and south-west of Sydney to areas like our region which has low participation rates for tertiary education. Good on Simon Crean for doing these things. I look forward to the formalisation of this type of funding formula, to build into the institutions this sense of redistribution. We have a chanpopulation ging economy, changing growth in population and changing social needs. A region such as greater western Sydney should never be population overlooked as part of that process. The package provides the consideration given to faster growing regions with low rates of tertiary participation. The challenge now to institutionalise these transfers in education funding formulas. The model adopted in 1990 by the government served as It an aggregate historical cost system adjusted through teaching and research related cost areas components. Added to this base level is tion approved funding for growth. Once growth has been allocated it becomes part of the base for the following year of the rolling triennium: that is, each university's funding generally equals last year's base, adjusted for changes in the teaching profile and research requirement, plus a growth component. Under these arrangements, the arrangements that the minister has now altered, it was very difficult to move resources between institutions. The tendency was to entrench the funding position of larger, older universities and aggravate the financial challenge facing newer universities in regions of rapid population growth. Only the redistribution of public resources can ensure that the rate of population growth in outer metropolitan areas such be a as my seat in the south-west of Sydney is New matched by the growth in government services. Politically this is never a simple task. am Entrenched interest will fight hard, even will fight hard, to preserve existing facilities and benefits compared to regions which have gone without and are struggling to secure new services. Nowhere are vested interests more entrenched than in Australia's universities. The mystique of research and administrative autonomy has produced a who feeling that somehow universities should be treated differently from other areas of public The time is long overdue to bring higher education into the mainstream of political principles, and a number of reforms stand out. The first of those is to institutionalise, to build into funding formulas, the redistribution of funds to universities on the basis of high growth and low tertiary particiT)ation-it is a basic equity principle. The second initiative is to make sure that growth in outer metropolitan areas is accommodated by growth in outer metropolitan universities, not inner city institutions. I noted that the joint DEET-Higher Education Council working party at the end of last year is expressed a remarkable view. This is what the the higher discussion paper had to say: is not considered that all, or even most, of the resources made available to a State should automatically be allocated to regional institutions in of high population growth or low participain higher education. In the major capital cities in particular. a number of universities will be in commuting distance for most students. There is no reason to exclude institutions in inner city areas, for example, from access to additional resources simply because of their location ... What the discussion paper is effectively saying is that location is not relevant. Try telling that to a university aspirant living in my electorate in Campbelltown, where in driving time people are closer to Goulburn than they are to Sydney University or the University of New South Wales. Try telling that to the thousands of students in that region of the 1970s and 1980s-I was one of themwho did not have a university in their part of Sydney and had to commute for 1Y2 hours one way, three hours each day, to Camperdown for Sydney University or to Kensington for the University of New South Wales. The travelling time and the expense were a great disadvantage, a great hardship to the students of Sydney's west and south-west. It is my very strong belief, as it is within the government, that resources for regions of fast population growth need to be allocated to the universities which directly service those regions. I reject this spurious argument that somehow inner city institutions can equitably and fairly service the needs of university students on the urban fringe. The DEET-HEC approach would impose large costs in travel time and expenses on students from outer metropolitan areas. It does not sit well with policies to provide equality of higher education opportunity. The 1994 ALP national conference resolved to develop a series of social justice benchmarks on access and equity issues. Higher education funding should set basic standards for the availability of university places and reducing the time and expenses faced by student commuters, particularly those at the urban fringe. My third initiative would be to develop funding formulas on the basis of regional rather than state needs. The DEET-HEC discussion paper used state boundaries as its unit of locational analysis. This contradicts the government's general support for regionalism and funding arrangements that support regional equity. Real geographic distinctions in Australia are regional, not between the states. State boundaries-lines drawn in at Whitehall last century-have shown themselves to be an irrelevant guide to locational inequality. For instance, while the New South Wales population is projected to fall, some parts of the state, such as the north coast and also the south-west of Sydney, face some of the highest rates of population growth in all of Australia. My fourth initiative-and I trust the minister is keen on this idea-is to build socio-economic indicators and notions of regionality into the higher education funding formulas. The Kelty report on regional development in 1993 recommended the government should take into account the regional services provided by higher education institutions when assessing their eligibility for funding. The availability of skilled labour is now arguably the single most important determinant of regional competitiveness. Educational agendas can be tuned to regional agendas while also addressing international competitiveness, thus becoming important instruments for economic development. Funding allocations to support these objectives can be tied to specific projects or linked to broader notions of socio-economic advantage and disadvantage at a regional level. The development of these indicators for higher education funding would present few difficulties. The ABS has done significant work on the measurement of socio-economic conditions by geographic areas. The major challenge in applying these indices lies in the relationship of a higher education institution to its student catchment area. There would be little purpose in providing growth funds to an institution to increase regional participation if the bulk of students came from outside the region. It would first be necessary to establish the proportion of students of each institution which is drawn from the regional catchment. Big challenges, a good bill and good work on the part of the minister. (Time expired)

But I was interested to listen to his contribution to the debate because he started talking about the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.2) 1995 about 12 minutes into his speech. He did not speak much about the HECS debt contribution scheme.
