Speaker: Mr RICHARD EVANS
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: I will move on. But all are examples of hidden or covert collection of money, and that is what this HECS hoax is all about. I call it a hoax in that it all seems okay on the surface, but in fact there are a few issues quietly slipped into this bill that are not all that they seem. They I are actually yet another way for the government to squeeze more money from the already budgets of students and possibly of families who sponsor or support their It seems that the Prime Minister (Mr seen Keating) has taken a shine to all things debt, foreign students, foreign clocks, and foreign suits in some cases. So the government clan has decided that there is real loot to be made by having these 'foreigners' studying in the Australian education system. The government has decided, in its so-called wisdom, that it will have a mandatory up-front payment for all education fees paid by non-citizens-notice that I was careful to avoid that word 'foreign'--or permanent Australian residents who do not take out Australian citizenship. This has been designed to stop people from overseas undertaking education in Australia and then leaving the country without paying their HECS. But here is the hoax: how does this relate, translate to or help our long standing permanent residents who, for various reasons-and often very personal reasons-have not taken out Australian citizenship? Those students, regardless of their citizenship status, who have already commenced their studies must be protected. These people must be protected and a degree of balance and equity must prevail under these circumstances. On a different level, the changes in this regard may have reaching results that few would anticipate. Let us face it, education worldwide is a growing business. Educational institutions are chosen by reputation. However, this is usually balanced with the amount those potential students can afford. Students, particularly those from overseas or the children of resident Australians, want a quality education. But they also need to know what it will cost and when. Reality dictates that very few people-I stress very few-can afford an up-front payment. And the member for Werriwa was talking about equity and access! In fact, few would pay for a service they had not yet tested, and even fewer would actually pay for a service they had not yet received. If Australia is to compete in the field of education on an international scale-and I believe that as a nation we should and we can--our fee structure must be flexible and structured to entice and encourage students, and it must not develop into a system which poses a threat to potential users. However, as you probably realise, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am a bit of a pragmatist, and if this payment is to be put in place, regardless of the potential for resistance by overseas students, it must not be used to the detriment of existing students. It must be introduced only at a time that all potential students are fully aware of this up-front payment and the up-front payment requirement should not apply to existing students. The bill has another slight hoax in the making. In most bills presented by the Labor government, there seems to be some point that relates to money collection. This one is no exception. It may be couched in different terms, but the reality always seems to shine through. The government has actively encouraged students to move into tertiary education. It has done this, firstly, through their inability to provide jobs and openings in the employment sector for young people and, secondly, by encouraging most employers to consider only those people with training or academic qualifications as worthwhile employees. This has forced many young people to continue in long-term education programs and older adults to return to study as the only far- option for career development and advancement. So our tertiary institutions are full and we have increased retention rates. I think I recently heard the Vice-Chancellor of ANU saying that there were now more people studying in university than ever before but fewer people actually going to university. The question then is how is that the case when there are more people staying on at university to do their double degrees and not allowing people to enter university? What an ideal environment for the government to collect a little more revenue and put a few more dollars in their greedy little moneybags. And the result? With this bill, students will be slugged for the second time in three years, through the government seeking to accelerate the rate of repayments of HECS. This may be all very well as a revenue collection ploy. However, by changing the rules midway, our current students are denied any option to plan for their future, and are faced with constant uncertainty as to exactly what they have to pay. How can they be expected to plan ahead? We are always thinking about the future, yet we are not allowing our students-who are the future of our great nation-to plan ahead. How can students be expected to have any sort of financial management, especially when so many students are supported by families, or survive on part-time employment? It is imperative that current students and graduates are protected from the government's latest HECS grab for dollars. On a more sobering note, there is an overall tragedy in this whole scenario. The tragedy is that at a philosophical level the bill is sound, and most of the proposed changes, in essence, are not under debate. I am speaking of the HECS hoax that has been revealed in this debatethat is the tragedy. What is highly questionable is the suite of tactics which is constantly and conveniently used by the government. The government would have the people of Australia believe that it is doing a great job, but as with the HECS hoax, when you look closely into the issues, time and time again the government is revealed as caring little natural justice, fairness or balance in its thinking and policies. To sum up, there are two key areas of concern in relation to this bill. Firstly, for purposes of fairness, equity and honesty government, the repayment thresholds should and must apply only to students who comexisting mence their studies from 1996. Secondly, for the sake of fairness, equity and honesty in government, the up-front payments for students who have not taken out Australian citizenship should apply only to people who commence studies after 1996. The government should forget about the grab for dollars and address the issues-issues such as our debt and our increasing tax burden. It should learn to treat the community as thinking people and not as a group sheep who would fall for this HECS hoax.  opportunity offered by the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training government Allowance) Bill to briefly voice a number concerns that I have raised before over the government's graduate tax, the higher educathat tion contribution scheme. A constituent, who wrote to me more than two years ago, summed it up best when he said: I am scared out of my wits about the HECS schemes . . . Messrs Keating and Co can add to your debt at any time, raise interest on late payments, etcetera. We see in this bill yet more examples of the retrospectivity that makes HECS such a onesided contract. As one of the few members of this House that has paid a HECS debt, I believe the current system is unfair. It is clear to me that the system the government has put in place is inequitable and denies students and recent graduates any real sense of certainty. Tertiary fees should not be levelled in an unjust way-and HECS is. Two sections of this legislation are of particular concern to me: part 5, which provides for the new repayment thresholds for HECS, and part 9, which requires that permanent residents who have not met the requirefor ments for citizenship, one year or more before enrolment, pay up-front fees. Part 9, establishing a discount for people who commence HECS repayments before reaching the compulsory threshold, also deserves more than a the cursory glance. Part 5 of the bill provides in three new repayment thresholds for HECS. These new thresholds are inserted within the levels. This measure, in effect, entails also an accelerated rate of repayment. I remind the House that this is the third time the government has attempted to introduce an accelerated repayment rate since the HEC scheme began operation. Two years ago, I raised the same issues of certainty, the onesided nature of the HECS contract and the fact that in this contract the government was the powerful proponent, able to alter a contract, where the other side had no say in it of and could not say, 'I'm going to give up studying, because I'm not going to pay this HECS debt any more.' The students are in a totally vulnerable position. Two years ago, the tried to do the same thing, and I of raised the same issues then. At that stage, they promised that it would not happen again, there would be one change and that would be it, and that they would not move to have such an accelerated repayment again. Yet here we are debating the same issues. The coalition proposes to amend the bill so that this whole range of new measures applies only to students who begin studies from next year onwards rather than having it affect those students who have signed HECS agreements under a set of entirely different conditions. This retrospectivity in principle is wrong, but in this case it is utterly unacceptable. As I said before, the student is the vulnerable party in this contract. A student cannot start a law, arts or science degree and, when the government jacks up the HECS to be paid back through the tax system, then say, 'Right; it's time for me to move on, I'm not going to complete my degree.' Obviously, the government has complete power over that student while ever the student is studying at university and it can change the student's HECS at will. Part 9 of the bill seeks to prevent those overseas persons who undertake education in Australian tertiary institutions and then return overseas from leaving unpaid any HECS debts they may incur. DEET figures show that there are currently 26,000 permanent residents studying in Australian universities. It is estimated that around half of these meet the residency requirements that allow them to defer their HECS, and that most of the remainder will take out citizenship by the 1996 academic year, leaving only around 2,200 liable for up-front fees. This measure creates a number of concerns. The amendment, at best, can only partially prevent rorting of the system. The amendment only relates to persons who have met the citizenship requirement of two years residency as permanent residents, making it possible for students from overseas to complete a degree as a permanent resident before becoming eligible for citizenship. What is the point? Under this bill, overseas students from countries which permit dual citizenship-for example, Hong Kong-would have little difficulty in taking out Australian citizenship and returning to their country of origin, leaving their HECS debt unpaid. At the same time, the bill creates hardship for students from those countries-for example, Malaysia-that do not allow dual citizenship, who may need to retain the citizenship of their original country for a variety of reasons. So we are creating two classes of overseas students in Australia: those who will be able to avoid the government's proposals, and those who will have to make a choice and possibly suffer deleterious effects by so doing. The minister has claimed that the amendment will save $1.8 million in this fiscal year and $3.8 million in 1997-98. It appears to be a particularly cumbersome method of saving what are relatively small amounts, and when the potential for rorting that will still exist is considered it may well prove unable to even match this much. The amounts claimed are $3.8 million and $1.8 million. Only yesterday, I heard from a report that was tabled by the Australian National Audit Office that the Department of Social Security could save $86 million by changing some of the systems that it has adopted. Yet the government is happy to punish students and make their lives almost impossible and is happy to have legislation which is still full of loopholes and which students will still be able to get around-all for a measly $3.8 million and $1.8 million, when they will not make the changes that would save $86 million in the DSS! Rather than applying this measure to current students, the coalition is again seeking to amend it so that it will only affect students commencing studies in 1996. I should also mention in passing that part 4 of the bill makes provision for a discount to be offered to students and recent students who voluntarily commence the repayment of their HECS debt when their income reaches $20,000 per annum rather than when it reaches the current level, which is $26,853. Persons who are tempted by this discount to attempt to repay HECS while on incomes of this level may well find they lack the economic capacity to continue. More concerning is that fears have been expressed that this measure may well be the first step towards lowering the compulsory threshold. In other words, it may be the thin end of the wedge. Who can trust this government on HECS, on how they deal with tertiary students, when at almost every opportunity they have had to break a promise to students they have broken it? They have said it will be voluntary if you want to repay your HECS when you are earning less than $26,853. How long will it be before they lower the compulsory threshold, before they say, 'So many people are able to do so voluntarily, we will make it compulsory for everyone'? It is a very dangerous situation for students to be in when they are faced with a government that has no regard for the contract signed with students. These three aspects all demonstrate the weaknesses of the existing HECS. As I said earlier, it is inequitable and it denies its participants any real sense of certainty. Where are the NUS on the issue? Why is it that the National Union of Students have absolutely no capacity to defend students against this government? They are hopelessly inadequate. The reason they are hopelessly inadequate is that they are an arm of the ALP government and the government takes them utterly for granted. As they have demonstrated in election after election, they are more than prepared to campaign for and support the Labor Party, even though the Labor Party constantly humiliates them, takes them for granted, uses them up and spits them out. The NUS should be ashamed of themselves. It is high time they started representing students rather than representing their own ambitions for factional advancement. Under HECS, students contribute around one-fifth of the average cost of a higher education place. Each semester, students choose either to pay up-front or to defer payment. Students who can pay their fees directly to the institution receive fee, with the Commonwealth paying the balance on their behalf. Students who defer payment accept a loan from the Commonwealth which pays their liability for the semester to the institution, and they begin repaying these loans when their taxable income reaches a certain level. When students sign up for the options form, everything is fine if they can afford to pay up-front. But, if they choose to pay later, they are signing a weighted contract with a party that can change its conditions and does so at whim. Such a situation would not be tolerated in the private sector. It only government that allows such abuses to take place. However, students have no choice. They can either sign the form or they can forget about their education. I do not believe that I need to spell out to the House who benefits and who loses from such a situation. If you can afford to pay HECS up-front, it is all well and good. But students who cannot afford to pay sign a contract with a party that can increase repayments and can change conditions of the contract at any time. As HECS currently exists, it discriminates against the less well off and the underprivileged. Mr Bruce Scott-Particularly rural people.  member for Maranoa points out, which I why I imagine there is such a swathe of speakers from his party on this bill, and I am sure they will pick up that very important point. Once again we have an example of where Labor is penalising the poor and advancing the rich. They call us the party of toffs, but in every example that can be named in the last 13 years it has been the Labor Party taking their grassroots for granted, penalising the poor and advancing the rich. They claim the mantle of Chifley and Curtin, yet almost every time one can think of an opportunity they have had to help the poor they have kicked them in the teeth and they have helped the rich. That is why the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who comes from Bankstown, has beautiful mansions and lives the life of luxury, while the poor struggle on. The member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) may well laugh, but I imagine the electors from a discounted your electorateMr Sawford-You said it with a straight face. I can't believe you're saying it.  as I do, the electors from your electorate would be horrified, and most of them, as you well know, are about the Prime Minister's behaviour. Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not want payment to digress from the bill

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: Mr Nehl)Very wise.  NUS represent in this? Who are they lining is up with? Not with the coalition, which stands up for students. The coalition supposedly cannot stand students, but at almost every opportunity we have combined with the Democrats in the Senate to protect students from this voracious government. The NUS are not lining up with the coalition; they are lining up with the government, as they have done time and time again. Mr Sawford-Did you read the Sydney Morning Herald editorial?  al yet. They would do well to remember how HECS can deny certainty to students and graduates, a matter that seems to be given virtually no consideration when education funding policy is discussed. Under the current HECS arrangements students do not have any clear idea of how much extra will be going out of their pay packets once they have reached the threshold. Too many young people have learnt over recent years that a degree or other tertiary qualification is scarcely a ticket for a job. Yet at a time when budgeting is vital, when they are establishing careers, when they are getting married, saving for a deposit on a home or incurring a mortgage, the government can suddenly-and does-increase their repayments. HECS paying students and graduates are entitled to a greater degree of certainty. They should have a fair idea of what their HECS commitments will be and when they should commence. The retrospectivity I have highlighted in today's bill denies them any such right. The government must stop moving the goalposts. By putting forward amendments to parts 5 and 9 of this bill the coalition is not interfering with the basis of the government's proposed changes. Instead, we are introducing a degree of balance and fairness that presently is lacking in this legislation. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), predictably enough, has decried our proposals as being inane and has accused the coalition of vandalising budget measures. It is hard to see how the outcome of a budget, predicated on the dodgy figures that we have exposed over the last eight months, can be anything other than shaky. He has also condemned us for not consulting with the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, academics or students. These charges are easy to respond to. Unlike the government, the coalition has been listening to students. That is why we have already stated that our higher education policy will rule out undergraduate fees and promise greater financial autonomy for individual universities. Unlike members of the government, I have been listening. I have been travelling throughout Queensland from Cairns to Brisbane and meeting with young people, meeting with students. I imagine the member for Port Adelaide was rather jealous that he could not be with me because I met an enormous number of young people and students who gave me their very strong views on these matters, and we listened to them genuinely. In Bundaberg, Gladstone, Cairns, Townsville and Brisbane we listened to young people. It is probably not a bad idea if some of your people got out and started listening to young people too. I note in passing that the minister has announced that the government is going to conduct public rallies with young people to find out what they think. Mr Bruce Scott-After 13 years!  subsequent to our bus trip through the eastern states. I imagine he will get a very rude shock. Mr Sawford-Unlike you, we've been doing it for the last 15 years.  the last 15 years, and you are so confident about your position

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: The member for Sturt will not let the member for Port Adelaide provoke him.  Speaker. He is not worth it. Students like the correspondent I quoted earlier are sick of being at the mercy of the chopping and changing of government policy. Academics and administrators, if they still retain their integrity and a commitment to the ideas that exemplified higher education in the days before John Dawkins, will recognise the justice of what the coalition is talking about. Yet again it is coalition members who are standing up for students and the battlers while Labor is establishing the elites and taking the student vote for granted. When students undertake studies they will be certain of what the HECS repayments will be under a coalition government. This government has constantly denied them this right and the coalition is seeking to restore it to them.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: I have much pleasure in rising to make a contribution to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.2) 1995. It is interesting to note that from this side of the House we have had a long list of speakers contributing to this debate. Yet on the other side of the House there is little interest-one speaker following the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean). Quite clearly, the Labor Party has very little interest in students' capacity to meet this higher education contribution tax-the graduate tax that this government wants to impose on hard-pressed students. I think we all recognise that improving our base of knowledge, our skills and our expertise is necessary if we are going to meet the needs of the 21 st century. A sophisticated education system is central to this task. It is our challenge to develop an education system that not only is innovative in a technological and industrial sense but also maximises the potential of our greatest resource of all-the people and, more particularly, in reference to this bill, the next generation of Australians. To accomplish this, we must encourage the entry of talented and dedicated people to the education system and we must maximise the contribution they make to national life. However, it is because the legislation before us today hampers that contribution by limiting access to education places as well as creating instability in the HECS arrangements that the coalition is opposed to many features of this bill. It is grossly unfair in its application and generates a level of uncertainty which cannot be tolerated. It is particularly and future students from rural and remote Australia who are already greatly disadvantaged in terms of their access to educational opportunities. One of the great impediments, apart from financial constraints, that those students face is the tyranny of distance that they confront in gaining access to further education. This bill represents the third time in the short life of the HECS system that significant alterations have been made to the higher education contribution scheme repayments schedule. These constant amendments and alterations create uncertainty for all Australians participating or wishing to participate in higher education. The decision about whether to enter a university or other institute of higher learning is not an easy one and involves a lot of consideration and planning. In deciding to undertake a course of study a student will often sacrifice immediate comforts and financial rewards in favour of the opportunity of a better and higher paid job in later life. Entering a university also involves planning for such things as accommodation and travel, and often the need to seek and undertake part-time work. But such forward planning is made extremely difficult by the Labor government, which refuses to guarantee stable and predictable HECS arrangements. No-one can be sure what Labor is going to do with higher education funding from one year to the next. One of the most disgraceful elements of this legislation is that it proposes to change the HECS structure midstream. In other words, it will apply to all those students who are in the middle of their study program. In other words, it is retrospective legislation. This is grossly unfair to those students who have organised their lives according to a different HECS arrangement. It is not only unfair to these students but also unfair to the many parents who are deeply involved in the planning of their children's education. This is why the coalition seeks to amend this section of the legislation to ensure that the new threshold levels apply only to students who will commence their studies in 1996. The coalition's position on this amendment is a unfair to present fair and proper one. Students in the middle of their courses have the right to certainty in their HECS repayment schedule and this government is failing to provide that. HECS is like a personal loan from the government, but Labor wants to change the repayment rate in the middle of the borrowing period. Imagine the outcry from society if banks wanted to force this legislation on first home buyers in this country. The same principle applies here. If banks were to attempt to try this sort of approach, they would not get away with it. Yet this is precisely what the Labor Party is proposing to do. If ever proof was needed of the government's lack of commitment to students in higher education, the attempt to impose these threshold changes retrospectively is it. As usual, the government has tried to shift the blame by claiming that extra higher education places will be jeopardised if the opposition blocks the retrospective parts of this bill. What humbug! What scaremongering! In reality, it is the government which has totally mismanaged the higher education system. It has proved that by slugging this increase on existing students so that it can afford to pay for extra tertiary places. The coalition will not respond to the government's attempt at blackmail. The Minister for Education in that lame duck Labor Party government in Queensland tried to scare the people of Queensland by saying that, if the coalition blocks this legislation, places at universities will be at risk. It is nothing more than blackmail and nothing more than blatant scaremongering, at a time when parents and students are trying to plan the future education needs and requirements of their children. For the coalition to respond to blackmail would be to abandon the students who have been so shabbily treated by this government. I am particularly concerned by Labor's proposed changes in the bill which will impact very heavily on students and families from rural and remote Australia. Many of these young people and their families are already burdened by unique financial and social pressures. Drought has seriously cut the incomes of thousands of rural families. For example, more than half the broadacre livestock enterprises in this country have had a negative income for the last three years. In my own electorate of Maranoa, many broadacre producers have recorded substantial negative incomes for the last four years. When their financial returns for the coming 12 months are recorded, the way the season looks, there will be another year of negative incomes. In addition to this, people in rural areas have average incomes which are significantly lower than the rest of the population. We have only to look at the 1991 census figures. They show that the median family income in my own electorate of Maranoa is about $26,450 per family. If you compare that with the median income of families in the seat of Brisbane, you will see that it has a median family income of $35,909. It illustrates my point that, based on official statistics from 1991, the parents of students from rural and remote areas of Australia, as a result of their backgrounds, have a lower median family income than the families of students from our capital cities. On the 1991 census figures, the median family income in the New South Wales seat of Gwydir, the seat of the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Anderson)-just to assure the House that I am not just talking parochially about my own seat-is $25,782. The median family income in the electorate of Greenway, a safe Labor seat in western Sydney, however, is $40,365. I could provide example after example demonstrating that students from families of rural and remote Australia are disadvantaged not only because of the tyranny of distance but also because their families have a lower median income than those of people who live in our capital cities. Rural families will have even less money to live on and to keep their farms and businesses going if the government gets its way and increases the tax on those graduates who have been fortunate enough to get a decent job. This in tum will make it more difficult to pay for the education costs of the next generation. With declining incomes and increased taxes, farming families also have less opportunity to pay up-front fees for higher education and so escape these HECS increases. So families in rural Australia are doubly disadvantaged by this bill. The situation created by the legislation is typical of Labor's approach to education, and particularly to the education of rural and remote Australians. After 13 years the Labor Party has demonstrated that it has no commitment to providing a fair deal for rural students. In 1993, the year 12 retention rate for students in urban areas was 66 per cent, but for students who live in remote areas the figure was only 52 per cent. A similar story can be told with respect to higher education. In 1989, the number of students enrolled in higher education who came from urban based locations was 78 per cent of the total. This meant that rural and remote students filled only 22 per cent of the total of all higher education places. The Labor government made some noise about responding to these poor figures. In 1990 it launched its equity program called 'A fair chance for all: higher education that's within everyone's reach'. Remember that? I am sure the House well remembers it. The minister for education at the time, Mr Baldwin, promised, 'All Australians with the potential to succeed in higher education should have the opportunity to benefit from higher education qualifications.' With the release of this program, and in light of the minister's fine words, many parents in rural Australia believed that their children's educational prospects would be much rosier. But these hopes have been dashed. The overall participation rate of rural and remote students in higher education actually fell in the years following the report. Despite the government's commitment to providing equity in education, only 21 per cent of all higher education students in 1991 came from rural and remote Australia. Yet the total for the non-urban population of Australia was actually above 30 per cent. But the story is even worse for those students living in the really remote areas of this country. In the 1991 census the population of remote Australia was 12 per cent, but the percentage of remote students enrolled in higher education was only two per cent. A 1994 report from the Department of Employment, Education and Training revealed that this situation has not improved. It is important to note that the most common reasons given for this low participation rate are locational disadvantages and financial restrictions. In other words, it had nothing to do with the demand for these places and it had nothing to do with ability. But remember the minister's words: 'All Australians with the potential to succeed ... should have the opportunity to benefit from higher education ... ' Well, rural and remote students have done all they can. They have demonstrated that they have the potential to succeed in higher education, but this government has failed to give them the opportunity. What is more, it is unlikely that this opportunity will ever be provided by this government. While demand for tertiary places is at an all-time high, Commonwealth student assistance has been substantially reduced. Following the May budget this year, Austudy assistance is also set to decrease by $35 million over four years. This comes at a time when access to higher education is becoming increasingly difficult for lower income groups. In 1980, under a coalition government, 48 per cent of students from the least affluent sector of the population entered higher education. In 1989, under a Labor Party government that had been in office for six years, the percentage had fallen to 35 per cent. Students from rural areas are increasingly falling into this lower income group. The Labor government has paid insufficient attention to the falling participation rates of students from lower socio-economic backgrounds. One need only look at Labor's farm assets test which now excludes-and this is a DPIE figure included in a Senate report last year-about 5,400 students from receiving Austudy support. That is a federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy figure, not my figure. This means there are 5,400 students prevented from receiving a tertiary education. Mr Deputy Speaker, you have only to look at the figures I quoted earlier-four years of negative farm incomes-w:hich means that many of those families are unable to provide financial assistance to these students to keep them in higher education. I can produce example after eJample in my electorate of students who have been pulled out of university places because their families could not afford to keep them there. They have lost the opportunity to gain that further education. No amount of bleating from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, the other day, when he tried to tip a bucket on some of the comments I have made publicly on this issue, will convince me that my comments are not accurate; they are. Even his own department shows that 5,400 students are being locked out of receiving Austudy assistance because of the farm assets test. The upshot of all this is that rural students are hamstrung by the restrictive and inequitable education policies of the Labor government. The bill before us today is only going to worsen that disability. Yet quality education is of vital economic and social importance to all Australians, including rural communities. We are all only too aware that many in our rural and remote regions are in a serious state of decline. Depriving the best and the brightest in these regions of adequate education is not the way to reverse this trend. Rural and remote Australia requires innovative ideas and increased opportunities to unlock its great potential. A highly educated and well trained rural population can contribute to this task. But this requires a commitment to providing access for rural and remote Australians to higher education places. Obviously, this government does not have that commitment. These changes to HECS will only represent another obstacle to students and families hoping to obtain a higher education. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: I welcome the opportunity to speak in this debate on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.2) and particularly to follow my colleague the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) and to reinforce a number of issues that he has raised. I agree with him that one of the great losers in tertiary education has been the students of rural and regional Queensland. This bill is important for two reasons: firstly, it contains a number of measures that will impact significantly on both current tertiary students and recent graduates and, secondly, it dispels once and for all the great myth that only the Labor Party can look after the interests of students. Labor politicians and their student union lackeys on campuses throughout Australia continue to peddle the myth that only the ALP can look after the interests of students. However, if you take a quick look back over the last 12 years of federal Labor government, you begin to wonder what students have to be thankful for. Let us examine some of these myths. The first myth I wish to dispel is in regard to university fees. When Labor first came to office in 1983, it promoted itself as being the no fees party, and I stress that point. We were told that free tertiary education was part of the Labor manifesto. In 1988 the Labor Party introduced HECS, and it was forced to remodel itself, to reinvent itself, as the no upfront fees party. So it moved from the no fees party to the no up-front fees party. We were told that no up-front fees were part of the Labor manifesto. Then the Keating government removed restrictions on universities charging fees for postgraduate courses-much to the anger of students right across Australia because they could see what was coming later. Suddenly, the Labor Party became the no up-front fees for undergraduates party. So it moved from a no fees party to a no up-front fees party to a no up-front fees for undergraduates party. We were told that no up-front fees for undergraduates were part of the Labor manifesto. In 1995, as contained in the bill before us today, the Labor Party wants to introduce up-front fees for at least one category of undergraduate students: those permanent residents who are not Australian citizens. So the ALP manifesto is now no up-front fees for Australian undergraduates. With this trail of broken promises on the fee paying structure issue, how would any students trust this government again? What will be the little variation in the next budget or the budget after that, should the Labor Party be fortunate enough to be re-elected? Having singled out one category of undergraduate students to pay up-front fees, how long will it be before this Labor government finds another group of undergraduates who should be paying up-front fees for their tertiary education? That is the very point I made when universities were allowed to charge for postgraduate courses. Let us look at the second myth. Labor's fee paying hypocrisy is not just limited to upfront fees. If we look in detail at the Labor record on HECS, we find that the government has moved to gain more and more revenue from students. Since the 1993 election, Labor has either introduced or attempted to introduce double HECS for undergraduate degrees; 1Y2 times HECS for those taking longer than the minimum time to complete their degree; a pro rata repayment, a method of substantially lowering the repayment threshold; a lower repayment threshold; a raised rate of repayment across the board; and a changed method of repayment. The coalition has been successful in blocking a number of these proposals, including the doubling of HECS, the 1Y2 times HECS and the pro rata payments. Before us today in the context of this bill, the government is seeking to introduce some further revenue grabbing measures that students need to be aware of. In particular, I refer to part 4 of the bill, which makes provision for a discount to be offered to persons who voluntarily commence to repay their HECS debt when on an income of $20,000. Of course, the current threshold at which HECS must be paid is $26,853. Not surprisingly, the National Union of Students has expressed fears that this could be the first step towards the government lowering the compulsory repayment threshold. What a tragedy that would be under a Labor government which is supposed to be looking after their interests. Part 5 of the bill provides for three new repayment thresholds for HECS. These new threshold levels, at 3.5 per cent, 4.5 per cent, 5.5 per cent and six per cent, will be inserted within the existing levels of three per cent, four per cent and five per cent, effectively accelerating the rate of repayment. Students around Australia should note that it was a Labor government that introduced this measure to increase HECS revenue by stealth. Once again, it is a Labor government that is changing the rules on students and on recent graduates by now asking them to pay back more of their debt at a faster rate. In fact, this is the second time in three years that Labor has sought to accelerate the rate of repayment of HECS. This altering of the rules is of great concern. A graduate battling to buy a house, to marry or to establish a career can suddenly find that his or her HECS debt repayments are suddenly increased, causing financial hardship and stress. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) is in the House. I know that, from my own children and many friends' children, by the time students get to the end of their undergraduate courses they are very much strapped for cash. They are seeking to pay off a car or, as I have said before, they may be trying to buy a house or a unit, to marry or to establish a career. The coalition will move an amendment to part 5 of the bill to ensure that the new student threshold levels will apply to only those students who commence their studies from 1996 onwards. What we are about is creating certainty for students-not changing the rules here and there to suit the government's budget shortfalls. Part 9 of the bill requires permanent residents, including New Zealand citizens, who have met the residency requirements of citizenship one year or more before enrolment to pay up-front fees-in other words, to prevent persons from overseas undertaking education in Australia and then leaving without ever paying their HECS debt. This seems to be fair and logical, but that is hardly the way the government has gone about achieving that aim. Like for part 5 of the bill, we will move an amendment to this measure to ensure it does not affect students already enrolled but so that future students-that is, from 1996 onwards-are aware of the new rules, are aware of what they will be paying. The HECS hoax is something I would also like to talk about. Interestingly, these two minor coalition amendments to parts 5 and 9 of the HECS bill, designed to give students greater certainty, is the source of angst, which has been generated by an extraordinary reaction by Labor politicians, both state and federal, to the coalition's measures. The coalition has been accused of politicking and threatening Queensland's hard won university places. I might depart from my notes for a minute to read a lemming-like letter from my state colleague Mr Campbell, the Labor member for Bundaberg, who says in heightening this scare campaign: Hundreds of teenagers' hopes and aspirations will be dashed in the Bundaberg region unless the Opposition relent and allow Mr Crean's changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS). But Member for Hinkler Paul Neville has denied the claimas indeed I do here. Joining the lemmings going over the cliff is the state minister, Mr Hamill, who said in support of the minister: The changes were part of a higher education package to raise an extra $20 million to defray the costs of the 12,000 extra tertiary places for Queensland, the total number of places phased in over a number of years. Mr Hamill made his comments after talks in Canberra with his federal counterpart, Simon Crean. He went on to say: Thousands of final year students throughout Queensland are this week writing their applications for positions at our universities in 1996. This is recent stuff. That is terrible intimidation, terrible stuff, Minister. I am surprised that your colleagues would fall for such a thing. We have been accused of politicking and threatening hard won university places, but I think you would agree with me that we are talking about $20 million at the end of the scale. That's funny: it has been claimed that the coalition, rather than the federal minister, is taking away these extra places. You have been going around the country and you have been quoted in Adelaide, Melbourne and Brisbane as threatening to cut university places because you cannot have your way on these minor amendments. DEET estimates that the coalition's amendments could cost the government about $20 million over three years in forgone revenue. That is $20 million less the government would be able to rake in from students' pockets if the bill remained unchanged. On the face of it, $20 million sounds a lot of money. But, when you talk about $20 million in the totality of the higher education budget of $4.4 billion, you are talking about roughly less than half of one per cent. In case the minister or his Labor colleagues have not heard, most Queensland universities, especially regional institutions such as Central Queensland University, are still not happy with the original allocation because they have simply not received enough places. This brings me to the third Labor myth which I seek to dispel, and that is in relation to university places. The student to population ratio in my Central Queensland electorate was, until recently, less than half the national average. With the minister's new allocationif indeed it takes place, if this threat is not invoked-it will be about 60 per cent of the national average; yet my region continues to be grossly under-funded in terms of university places. Even with the government's much heralded budget allocation of 4,200 extra university places over three years, the Central Queensland University appears to me not to be getting its fair share of the funding cake. Our allocations for 1996 and 1997 were 420 extra places; but 100 of these were announced previously by the minister's predecessor, Kim Beazley. So, out of the recent budget, CQU got 320 places over two years to be distributed between five campuses. Think about that, Minister: two years, five campuses-IO units, if you like-into 320 places. It is not big. It becomes even more frightening when you look at today's unemployment figures from the ABS. In the Central Queensland area and, in particular, in the Wide Bay-Burnett region, which is in the southern part of my electorate and which has one of the campuses of CQU, we find that the youth unemployment figure for 15to 19-year-olds is 41.1 per cent, which is the worse in Queensland. For 20to 24year-olds it is 23.4 per cent, which is the worse in Queensland. Total unemployment spread over all the state and all age groups is at 15.9 per cent, up from 14.3 per cent. While I acknowledge that an increase in university places would have only a minor effect on this, and while I appreciate that the minister has said he will cooperate with me on unemployment and workplace measures to alleviate this problem, nevertheless we could do with more university places. There is an interesting quote from Professor Geoff Wilson, who wrote to me recently. He said: A considerable proportion of these students could be expected to enrol at a campus within the region if the option was made available to them through the allocation of additional funded places at Central Queensland University. As I said, 320 places over five campuses over two years is not a big deal. Indeed we are grateful for them, but I think we can do more. How, on such a paltry number and with Queensland still so far behind the other states, could you threaten to withdraw them if you do not get your way on those two minor amendments? I find that very hard to understand. I quote again from a recent letter to me from the Vice-Chancellor of Central Queensland University, Professor Wilson: . . . Central Queensland University would need a doubling of its 1995 allocation of funded student load in order to provide the population of the Central Queensland region with same availability of higher education places on a per capita basis within the region, at the current Australian In this regard, whilst the Ministers recent announcement of additional funded places being allocated to Central Queensland University over the coming triennium has been most welcome, this still goes only a small way toward overcoming the shortfall in the region-base provision which I have highlighted above. I do not think Professor Wilson could have said it much more clearly than that. Many Queensland institutions are still grossly underfunded, and now the government wants to play games over the future of other university places. As I said before, Minister: how could you threaten, over these two amendments, this package in Queensland? I know you have threatened in Brisbane, in Melbourne and in Adelaide as well. Nevertheless, it came home very potently to the people of my region who felt that it was a form of intimidation. Just by way of comparison, we are talking about $20 million, after having been told over recent years how tough the budget was, and all these sorts of things. While I do not for a minute deny the right of the arts community to funding, out of the blue you recently plucked $250 million-just like that: superhighway and arts, $250 million! Yet, if you do not get your way on these amendments, you are threatening to cut university places in Queensland and presumably in the other places where you have issued the threat. In conclusion, the bill before us today and the measures it contains will send a clear message to tertiary students right around Australia. That message is that Labor is more interested in finding new and more devious ways to get students to pay for their education, rather than listening to the real problems and needs of our tertiary sector. This bill should dispel once and for all the great myth that only Labor will look after the interests of students. Students need only examine the coalition's actions in regard to the bill to understand that there is a choice other than Labor .

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: Let me start by reminding the House that this government has done more for higher average. education in this country than any other government. I quote Professor Alan Gilbert, who is currently Vice-Chancellor of the University of Tasmania but soon to take up the position as Vice-Chancellor of the University of Melbourne. In a speech he made when joining me in opening the Burnie campus in Tasmania on 15 September, he said: I am sure that when the history is written accurately one of the main things said about the government that has been in power since 1983 is that it has done more for education and for higher education I think than any government in Australia's history. I noted the disbelief of the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) when I quoted this on a previous occasion. But the opposition should recognise that even the critics of government policy are able to recognise what this government has done for higher education in this country. Just to summarise it: we have been in power since 1983 and we have seen the total number of students in higher education increase by 68 per cent-from 350,000 places to almost 600,000 places. That was the position before the last budget. In the last budget, we have demonstrated that we are not prepared just to rest on our laurels, as impressi ve as they are. We have gone even further with the last budget. We have committed $16'h billion to higher education over the next three and a half years; we have increased the number of places by 5,850 which, when you take the pipeline effect, means 11,000 more places over the course of the next 3Yz years; in addition, we have provided $109 million on top of the existing $191 million for research infrastructure-an increase of 57 per cent; and we have provided an additional $40 million for research programs, on top of the $350 million already committed for the triennium. We did all of this against the background of a tight fiscal set of circumstances. We did not cut funding to higher education. We did not introduce up-front fees for Australian undergraduate students. We did not reallocate existing places from one state to another. We honoured our commitments in relation to HECS so far as Australian students are concerned. We did not increase the size of the HECS burden-the debt. We did not lower the first compulsory repayment threshold below average weekly earnings, and we did not introduce a differential HECS. It was another confirmation of our huge commitment to this sector. This was a package that was funded by two basic approaches. First, there was a reallocation of existing funds available to higher education through the National Priority (Reserve) Fund. Second, there were some savings measures introduced, two of which are under attack today by the opposition. The resultant package reflected what became known as a cocktail approach to funding the higher education sector, and it was developed in full consultation with the higher education sector last year and this year. It was embraced by them as the sensible way forward. Again I remind the House: it was Labor that undertook the consultation. Despite what the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) said about listening to the higher education sector, the opposition consulted no-one when they took this stance of opposing the amendments. They did not consult the AVCC, which has welcomed the package and which has since attacked the opposition for the very things that they are opposing. They did not consult the academic bodies, which again welcomed the package. Even the students, while opposing the citizenship measure, recognised the strength of the package before the House. The opposition claim the right to represent the sector, but they will not even talk to it. As a consequence, this package is now in danger of being unravelled by the Liberal Party. It is opportunism at its best; it is policy at its very worse. The opposition is seeking to undermine two important funding areas. Its proposals are a direct attack on the places which have been secured for those Australians who have not had the opportunity to go to university. Again, I will correct the member for Hinkler. The savings measures risks involve up to $20 million per year-not over three years. It is $50 million over three years. I do not know who has been feeding him the information on his side of the House, but $50 million is not an insignificant amount. It will see 2,000 places in jeopardy.The new places in Queensland, Western Australia, New South Wales and Tasmania will have to be reduced and places reallocated from Victoria and South Australia. So to the member for Hinkler I say: do not come in here crying crocodile tears about needing to get extra places in your own area, which has been a beneficiary of the new places we have offered. Do not come in crying crocodile tears and supporting this nonsense on your side of the House. Mr Gibson-We'll let his constituents know.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: We will let his constituents know, and we will let the university know. We will let them know who is putting those places at jeopardy. I had the opportunity to visit the member for Hinkler's electorate over the last couple of months and to visit that university. These new places will enable students to complete the full three years of a degree in Bundaberg for the first time. They were not able to do it before. These are the places you are now putting at risk. I do not think you understand the consequences of what you and those on your side of the House are really supporting. The opposition can talk intimidation all they like, but I am not playing politics in this regard. If the money is not there, how do we fund the additional places? I had to put this package together on the basis of reallocating within my portfolio. I had to do it on the basis of finding savings that came back to my portfolio, and I did what the sector did not believe could be achieved. Now you want to come in on the back of it and unravel it. The cocktail approach developed in the resource allocation consultations last year also proposed the reallocation of places from those states with higher levels of participation. They could not see that we could actually get the extra money to give Queensland its places without taking those places off South Australia and Victoria. That set of proposals in the cocktail mix did raise considerable concern from those two latter states. The Victorian education minister made strong representations to me, arguing against the possibility of reallocating up to 10,000 places from Victoria. The South Australian minister wrote to me, similarly concerned that they would lose 3,000 places. But they lost none under our package. We did not reallocate one existing place. I note that the other day the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) was also in the Housepart of the bleeding heart brigade, like the member for Hinkler-crying crocodile tears about concern in her state. She quoted in relation to the resource allocation discussion and referred to it in her speech. She called for greater allocation and flexibility of resources between institutions. Yet, do you know what the member for Adelaide did, when it came to really considering these issues? She made a very explicit call for places not to be removed from her state. In other words, she was saying, 'We understand that if we take this step there will be a loss of places, but don't take them from Adelaide.' How can she pretend to represent the interests of students in her seat and in her state and yet agree with an opposition stance on this bill that will see places cut? It is absolute hypocrisy. Look at the opposition speakers in this debate-representatives of Victoria, South Australia, Queensland, Western Australia-all of them telling me before the last budget, 'Find us a means to get the extra places but don't take them off Victoria and South Australia.' When I actually produced the result, not only did I not get congratulations, but you also followed the lunacy of the man sitting on the opposite side of the table, the member for Goldstein, by proposing the amendments that are before the House that oppose what we have tried to introduce. But you do not tell us how you would fund the places if you were to get into office. The member for Goldstein claimed that there are tens of thousands of qualified students clamouring to enter our universities, yet he will not allow us to fund the places that we have delivered. What cant! What hypocrisy! I saw a newspaper report, in the Tablelands Advertiser of all places, that the shadow spokesman for education, Senator Hill, had said: The federal coalition has committed itself to providing extra tertiary education places to Queensland ... the coalition's higher education policy would include a specific commitment to fund the extra places. But they will not tell us how. They will not tell us where they would get the money. Mr Gibson-Full fees.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: Exactly! All we have to do is remind the students-the same group that you say you express support for-of the policy of the opposition when it was trying to win office at the last election. It was a policy that proposed vouchers and fees. Not only was it rejected by the Australian electorate but its author, the member for Goldstein, was dumped as opposition spokesman for education. That was your policy then and, quite frankly, I believe it is still your policy today. The tragedy of this debate is that the opposition pretends to have the interests of students at heart. But, through its spoiling tactics and its political grandstanding, they disadvantage Australian students. On the question of this citizenship issue, let me just state the record to the House. Migrants to this country have immediate access to the higher education system. Under the proposed legislation they have three years in which to take out citizenship. That is three years-I remind the House that it is possible to complete a degree in three years-for which they can defer HECS. And on top of that they can also be eligible for Austudy. No other country in the world is as generous as we are in relation to non-citizens. We are miles in front. I also remind the House that no Australian citizen could go to any other country in the world and enter universities under the same conditions as we allow people to enter them here. Indeed, British, US and New Zealand citizens, who will be the major focus of this measure, cannot even get back into their own countries' universities under the same conditions. It is nonsense to imply that you are really protecting something that is not already generous. I do not think that you understand the full implications of what you are going into bat for on this issue. You are proposing to further protect an already generous proposition-a world leading proposition-but, by doing it, you will be denying Australian citizens. I cannot understand the logic of a party that will support measures that benefit people who do not even vote in this country. You would do it at the expense of people who vote here, who have been born here and who want to grow up and live in this country. It is also nonsense to imply that the measure itself is the beginning of up-front fees Australian higher education. Our proposal does not require non-citizens to pay full fees for their university education. They will only pay up-front HECS. As we all know, HECS is equivalent to only one-fifth of average course costs. The Australian taxpayer pays the other four-fifths for these people who are noncitizens and, through HECS, funds are returned to the higher education system for the provision of additional places-places for Australian students. So why should we not make non-citizens do the same? Clearly, a person who has come over here, studied for three years and got a degree can avoid payment of anything back into the system if they leave before earning any income. Don't you understand that that is the consequence of what we are doing now? Having got all the benefits out of the system, they can get out of the country without paying anything, having no obligation back to this country and to the higher education system. Australian students cannot do that. This is a case of double standards on your part. On the one hand, the member for Goldstein says permanent residents who are not Australian citizens should not have to pay their HECS up front, yet he then complains that overseas students are taking places from Australian students. He is on the record as saying that 40,000 overseas students are taking up places in our Australian universities while the Australian students find the doors barred against them. That is absolute nonsense because he knows that the overseas students pay full fees, 100 per cent fees, to enter our universities. They do not do it at the expense of our students because universities require them to pay the full cost of the degree, including the capital costs. The students who pay to come to this country from overseas to study are not subsidised by public funds in any way. But it does raise the interesting question of what we should read into the member for Goldstein's statement in this regard. Is he really saying that Australian students should be allowed to pay fees as do overseas students? I think he is, because he believes that. That is why he was dumped as the shadow for spokesman for education after the last election. In a radio interview in March this year, Senator Hill indicated that the coalition had changed its policy away from fees because unmet demand had dropped. I asked at the time if this meant that if unmet demand should rise again the opposition would introduce fees. We still have not had a reply. That was in March. But we know it would, because it believes it. It wants to charge students to go to university. It does not believe in a fully publicly funded university approach in this country, which we do. Is the opposition really saying through this set of measures that it has the students' interests at heart? It is obfuscating. It is misleading them and it will never support them. History shows that it has not done so. I believe it owes the students an explanation. It claims that Australian students are paying fees for undergraduate education. I issue the same invitation to the opposition as I have to the students who have made this allegation: provide me with the information on courses for which undergraduate fees are being charged. They still have not provided any evidence of their assertions. In a speech I made to the Victorian Young Labor conference earlier this year, I indicated that I would ask my department to raise any questionable activities with relevant universities and I have indicated a preparedness to take action in relation to any information coming forward. Does the opposition have examples to back up its assertion or is it simply more rhetoric-no substance, no backup? We are used to that. In a radio interview I referred to earlier that involved Senator Hill-it is the only public statement he has made in two years on higher education-he in fact said that he had some sympathy with universities charging fees by the back door. I will conclude on this point. The Sydney Morning Herald editorial on 28 December comments on the opposition's proposals on this legislation as 'an attack on the responsible use of taxpayers funds'. That same editorial went on to say: The federal opposition is (cynically) wooing the student unions with its stance on this matter. This opportunism means that it dismisses the real issue-which is the equitable and responsible distribution of funds for tertiary education. That is not coming from our side and it is not coming from a newspaper that is known to be terribly supportive of what we do. That comes from an editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald in relation to the position the opposition is adopting on this matter. In a policy vacuum, the opposition's proposals are nothing more than a cheap, opportunistic stunt. The opposition's proposed amendments should be seen for what they are: a spoiling tactic which will work to the disadvantage of Australian students in circumstances in which we have honoured our commitment not to increase the HECS burden. The opposition, quite frankly, simply cannot be believed in relation to their policies on higher education. They will not divulge them because they are anti-student. They have done nothing to dispel their previous policy prescriptions. They think they can get away by remaining silent, and now they want to jeopardise student places on top of dismantling of student unions and the services they offer in conservative states. We reject their approach and I urge the House to vote accordingly. (Time expired) Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Consideration in Detail Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: -by leave-I move government amendments Nos 1 and 2: (1) Schedule, page 18, item 33, omit proposed paragraph 41(3)(c), substitute the following: "(c) a student (other than a New Zealand citizen) who; (i) is a pennanent resident; and (ii) will be resident outside Australia for the duration of a course in that semester for a reason other than a requirement of the course; but does not include a student who has been granted a certificate of Australian citizenship under section 13 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 and who has yet to make the pledge referred to in section 15 of that Act. ... (2) Schedule, page 19, item 36, after proposed subparagraph 101 (d)(i), insert the following subparagraph: "(is) a person who has been granted a certificate of Australian citizenship under section 13 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 and who has yet to make the pledge referred to in section 15 of that Act; or". Items 33 and 36 of the schedule to the bill give effect to the decision requiring New Zealand citizens other than those who are also Australian citizens or who hold a permanent visa, and Australian permanent residents who have met the residency requirements for Australian citizenship more than one year before enrolment, to pay their HECS contribution up-front rather than be able to defer the contribution. These people are also precluded from access to the open learning deferred payments scheme. The consequence of this would be to prevent a person whose application for citizenship has been accepted by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs but who is yet to attend a citizenship ceremony from deferring the HECS contribution or being able to use it. The person must attend a citizenship ceremony to pledge commitment to Australia before becoming a citizen. The amendments to the bill circulated by the government alter part 9 of the bill to allow students who have had a citizenship application approved by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs but who may have to wait some months to attend a citizenship ceremony to defer the HECS contribution or use the open learning deferred payments scheme. I commend the amendments to the House and present the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I direct my question to the Deputy Prime Minister. Is the Deputy Prime Minister aware that the Australian ambassador to the United States, Dr Don Russell, has today added to his extraordinarily improper statements by attacking the Clinton administration for having no concern for the underclass in the United States? Is it indeed the government's policy to attack the Clinton administration in this way? If not, will the minister ensure that the ambassador is reprimanded, yet again, by the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade? When is the government going to act on these reprimands and withdraw him immediately?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The opposition is getting a bit inconsistent on this. We had the opposition spokesman on trade, the Leader of the National Party, saying it was a terrible thing that Don Russell was coming home, because he had done such a fine job, such an excellent job, as the ambassador to the United Statesa position which we thoroughly endorse. We would agree with that. Then we have various other spokespersons for the opposition, including the gentleman who asked me the question, saying he ought to be recalled immediately. For two years we sustained, as ambassador to the United States, a person who had been a Liberal Party minister, and our treatment of Liberal Party appointees was very generous indeed and decent. Mr Downer-What has this got to do with it?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am just setting the scene. As far as the Clinton administration's position on the poor in the United States is concerned, the whole position in the United States was put most effectively by the US Labor secretary in recent times. Whilst there had been a slightly better employment performance in the United States than in Europe at that gathering at the OECD where he held these discussions, when you looked at the situation of wages in the United States you had to say there was an extraordinarily large number of working poor and that poverty was a very substantial problem in that nation. As a simple point of analysis, if you compare the performance in Australia over the last decade in terms of distribution of income with the situation in the United States-and both of us have been through a similar deregulatory program, similar deregulatory policiesin Australia we have nevertheless sustained the position of those in society most likely to be affected by it and there has been no increase in that gap between the rich and the poor. In the United States that is not the case. The rich have got a great deal richer and the poor a deal poorer over that period of time. I think you would find the Clinton administration deeply concerned about poverty in the underclass in the United States-deeply concerned. Its concerns in that regard are deepening as a result of the policies being pursued by your ideological soul mates in the Congress. As far as Don Russell is concerned, we are absolutely delighted that he is coming on board. He was a very good adviser when he was here, he has been a very good ambassador to the United States, and we expect that form to continue. Western Australia: Blockade

Speaker: Mr SNOW
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can he advise the House of any national implications flowing from the Western Australian government's second wave of industrial relations reforms? Is there any likelihood that the reforms will be enacted nationally?

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Well might the honourable member ask that question. I tell you this: they certainly will not be implemented by any Labor government. No Labor federal government will ever implement such an approach. What is worrying is that, having wreaked havoc on Western Australia's industrial stability and on working conditions there, the Western Australian government's reforms, both the first and the second wave, are being held up as a model for the federal coalition government. There it is in this newspaper article. Mr Reith-That is what you had yesterday.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Too right. And I will have it every day until the election. We need only to look at the comments of the Leader of the Opposition when he spoke to the Western Australian Liberal Party in August to be sure of that. It is there in black and white in the West Australian for all to see. If we need any further confirmation, just look at what Graham Kierath-the architect of the Western Australian model-had to say. In the West Australian of 17 August, he claimed that Mr Howard supported the second wave and supported it wholeheartedly. Later, in the Perth Sunday Times, he was even more forthright. He said: I've had no warnings at all. This is Graham Kierath on the second wave. It is a great quote. He went on: The only discussions I've had is with John Howard ... and he seemed very supportive of the principles. Thank you, Graham Kierath-the architect of the second wave-on John Howard. It is not terribly surprising that today's Australian reports another interview with Mr Kierath in which his frustrations with the Leader of the Opposition's sneaky backtracking appear to have boiled over. Before he jumped on that international charter flight up to Jakarta, fleeing the blockade yesterday, Mr Kierath decided to set the record straight. In the report, he insists that nothing has changed about his industrial relations proposals since he developed them four full long years ago. He said that nothing has changed. That is well before newspaper headlines on John Howard referred to Western Australia being his very model, his very template.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The minister will not wave that around.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Indeed, on the topic of John Howard, Mr Kierath went on-wait for this; it is a terrific line-to say: When he was shadow spokesman for industrial relations, John Howard's policy was more right wing than ours was. I was considered soft and left wing by those advocating more radical change. Just imagine that-Graham Kierath considered to be soft and left wing by those advocating more radical change. You know who that is that is John Howard. It might be hard to view Mr Kierath as soft and left wing, but it certainly is not hard to believe that John Howard endorsed the second wave or that he is advocating more radical change yet. He effectively endorsed every part of the second wave on that radio program yesterday morning where he ended up knocking himself out. We all saw it on Channel 9 last night. Worse still, he told another deliberate untruth when he said

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: This is not the only occasion that the Leader of the Opposition federally has been caught out in respect of the second wave. Yesterday the opposition was outraged by a one-day blockade of Western Australia, caused by the second wave. The opposition was outraged to. the point where the Leader of the Opposition said workers should be sued. Yet the Leader of the Opposition seems to think that there is some sort of communications blockade with Western Australia every day of the week. How else can it be that he thinks he can say something in Perth, Western Australia-that the Western Australian model is his model-and then come into the parliament and say he denies it, and expect anyone to believe him? The truth is that he is aiming to achieve the third of the great IR lies. The first one was Jeff Kennett on the eve of his election saying, 'Your awards are safe. No worker will be worse off, believe me.' We all remember it. The second of the great lies was Richard Court's lie when he said, 'I'm no Jeff Kennett' - remember that one, on the eve of his election?-'You'll be right with me.' The third lie was John Howard saying, 'I didn't say Western Australia was our model.' Of course it is his model. It is his model of industrial conflict and of slashing conditions. The only difference is that under John Howard it would be a nationwide model. For the final word on that, let me point out what Chris RichardsonMr MCGauran-You're just going on and on.
