Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Minister, do you consider expenditure by the Governor General to be excessive and, if so, why didn't you take steps to alter the guidelines and rein it in? If not, why are your cabinet colleagues engaging in unsourced and cowardly attacks on the Governor General over the issue?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: This is a product of some banter, is it? The honourable member is an expert in banter. I have already answered this question once publicly today, which is fair enough. I will go through it again here, which is fair enough too. The position with the Governor General's finances is that the office is responsible, like any other government department or agency, for its own administration within the framework of guidelines by the Department of Finance. As far as we are concerned, there are no problems with the administration within the framework of the guidelines that are laid down by them. The finance department does not administer the departments of the Commonwealth. It is obviously ridiculous to assume that it does. All the restrictions that apply via those guidelines apply to the Governor General' s Office. For example, they are subject to the efficiency dividend in their running costs, as are the other departments which are responsible in observing Department of Finance guidelines. I have had a chance to look at the article in the newspapers today. The answers to the story go reasonably as follows: firstly, there was obviously no account taken by the journalist concerned of the ordinary increases in expenditure that flow from wage increases and general increases in the cost of living. They have the same deflator that applies to most of the other departments. A substantial amount of the additional expenditure can be explained by that process. Secondly, a substantial proportion of the differences between the period of time that Mr Hayden has been in office and that of his predecessors goes to renovations of Government House. Those renovations are determined from time to time as required by an Official Establishments Trust which works out how to keep our old public buildings in decent operation. They are not a benefit to the Governor General. They are not renovations of his private property; they are renovations of the property of the Australian people. Obviously, those renovations of old places like the Governor General's residence and establishment are from time to time likely to be substantial and do explain most of the expenditure additional to that. There are one or two other items. I am advised that the Governor General no longer utilises as personal aides members of the defence forces, so a slight increase in the civilian establishment has been associated with that. Other expenditures that were drawn to our attention by the article go to the utilisation of a 707 for a recent trip to the 80th anniversary of the Gallipoli landings. That was an entirely appropriate occasion for the Governor General to attend. That trip was accompanied by a swing through Indo-China, where he was, of course, representing Australian interests and concerns. Clearly, it was convenient for him, in those circumstances where it is difficult to travel in that region, to operate with an Australian government jet. The notion that he is, in some way or another, personally advantaged by taking a 707 as opposed to sitting in the front of a Qantas jet again draws a long bow. All of us here have been in the government 707s from time to time. Opposition members-No!

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: --My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Has the minister's attention been drawn to an article in today's Melbourne Age regarding the conferral of lik gold passes to the three surviving Australian holders of the Victoria Cross? Could the minister explain to the House the rationale behind the provision of such a privilege to these very special Australians?

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question and I thank members on all sides of the House for giving that very warm welcome to those who are, I think noone will dispute, three great Australian heroes. Honourable members-Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Only 106 Australians have been awarded the Victoria Cross since its inception in 1856 by Queen Victoria. Unfortunately, only three now remain. They are Sir Roden Cutler, Mr Edward Kenna and Mr Keith Payne. Sir Roden Cutler VC was awarded the Victoria Cross for conspicuous and sustained gallantry during the Syrian campaign, and for outstanding bravery during bitter fighting at Merdjayoun. At Damour, a few weeks later, a machine-gun injury led to a leg being amputated. Edward Kenna VC was awarded the Victoria Cross for his actions against the Japanese in May 1945 near Wewak, New Guinea. Private Kenna exposed himself to direct enemy fire while disabling machine-gun posts with a rifle. His magnificent courage and complete disregard for his own safety resulted in a successful attack on a Japanese bunker and avoided many casualties. Keith Payne VC saw active service in Korea and served in Malaya before going to Vietnam in 1969. In that conflict, Warrant is Officer Keith Payne was awarded the Victoria Cross for outstanding bravery. Directly exposing himself to the enemy, he was injured in the hands and arms but continued to cover the withdrawal of his troops. After nightfall, he located 40 lost and wounded soldiers beyond the perimeters whom he led to safety through the enemy lines. His sustained and heroic personal efforts saved the lives of a large number of his indigenous soldiers and several of his fellow advisers. The three surviving holders of the Victoria Cross are frequently requested to attend functi6ns and commemorations all over Australia, as is befitting Australians who have achieved as they have. The life gold pass will provide up to a maximum of 25 first-class return trips per annum on scheduled commercial and commuter air services, main line rail services and other government services, or by motor coach or other vehicles operating as regular carriers, to the VC holders and their wives. The government has taken this step to alleviate the personal expense that these Australian heroes incur in performing what is ostensibly a civic duty. We often revere our sporting heroes but I am very sure that my parliamentary· colleagues on all sides of the House will say that these are three truly authentic Australian heroes. Can I also say-I am sure they will not mind me saying it-that today also happens to be the 50th anniversary reunion of HMAS Cowra. Many of the veterans from there are in the gallery and I am sure the House welcomes them as well. Honourable members-Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr SCIACCA
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I finish by simply saying again that I thank the House for giving these three people in particular the thanks that they deserve from this country.

Speaker: Mr NUGENT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement on radio 3LO on 5 October of this year that 'the housing afford ability index ... is very good now.' Is it not a fact that the Real Estate Institute of Australia and the Commonwealth Bank-HIA indices of home loan affordability both show a massive decline in home loan affordability under your government? Is it not a fact that, .lccording to the REIA index, home loan affordability is now 36 per cent lower than in March 1983, when Labor came to office? Is it not also a fact that, since September 1984, home loan affordability has reached the levels of the previous coalition government in only one quarter of the intervening 11 years? How can the government assert that housing affordability is very good when its record is so abysmal?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The situation when we came to office, which the honourable member refers to, was that home loan interest rates were touching 14 per cent. But that 14 per cent was not the half of it. What you had to do was cocktail it to get to anything like a situation where your deposit was likely to meet the amount that you had to borrow. In cocktailing those loans, you were taking your interest rates well over 14 per cent. In the course of this last term of parliament, interest rates for home loans in this country have never gone above what was the lowest figure under John Howard's tutelage as the Treasurer of this nation. Home loan affordability in the sclerotic system they had was knocked to pieces by the fact that it was almost impossible to lay your hands on any money in that highly regulated environment, unless you were prepared to put yourself way above what were the advertised and allegedly fixed rates. In comparing our position here with your position when you were in office, the situation of borrowers for home loans now is vastly better. Training

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the minister aware of reports of a document concerning the government's record on training and alternative strategies in this area? Can the minister advise the House whether claims in the document are accurate? If not, why not?

Speaker: Mr FREE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Lyons for his question. I am aware of such a document. It is being circulated in T AFE colleges and it seems to be authorised by a Mr Figart of Unley, who is, I understand, an employee of the Liberal Party in South Australia. At first glance, it looks like . one of those lost scrolls-a Liberal Party policy. We know that it cannot be a policy, of course, because when the Leader of the Opposition farewelled his colleagues on their blunder-bus tour a few weeks ago, he admitted that he could not set any targets for youth unemployment because he did not have any policies. It certainly does appear to be part of a campaign of lies about vocational education and training. Under Labor's track record, the document states that the number of young Australians in employment based training-that is, apprenticeships and traineeships-is at its lowest level for three decades. This is a porky. This is an absolute canard that coalition members have been told to repeat like parrots up and down the country. It is totally wrong and it is high time that those who were putting it around were well and truly nailed. The facts are that three decades ago apprenticeship commencements stood at some 29,000 nationally. Commencements for 199495 were just over 53,000 and when we add the commencements for traineeships, which were introduced in 1995, we have almost 70,000 people entering workplace training. In the last year the coalition was in office, commencements were 34,794-less than half of today's figures. I have a graph that shows that. Here we are; there you were. I table the graph. You could not defend a record like the opposition's because it is so pathetic. The Liberal Party in South Australia can publish untruths about the situation but the truth is that the Leader of the Opposition did not care about apprentices back then and he certainly does not care now. When this government established the Australian National Training Authority, we committed ourselves to developing the work skills essential for a competitive Australia. This year our funding for growth in vocational education and training has provided an extra 147,000 places for young people to obtain those skills that business and industry require. This government has committed $1 Y2 billion to provide extra training places for our youth. Over the five years of growth from 1993 to 1997, this government will have funded an extra 735,000 places. Earlier this month, the Prime Minister met some of the products of this government's investment in training when he fare welled 40 of our young people who have just finished their training and who are representing Australia at the International Skill Olympics against 27 other countries. Those young people are currently competing at Lyon and I am sure we all wish them well. ANL Ltd

Speaker: Mr QUICK
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. The minister would be aware that a sixth Australian scientist been appointed to the leadership of an interand national agricultural research organIsation. What were the reasons for that appointment?

Speaker: Mr BILNEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Members will be aware of highly the very important day that occurred this week-World Food Day. The figure that supportive springs to mind in connection with that anniversary is the 800 million people who each day in this world go to bed starving. Dealing with that fact is one of the most difficult issues which faces the world community. It is one in which Australia has a particular role to play. I thank the member for bringing attention to this particular appointment. One of the ways that this problem can be addressed is by agricultural scientists worldwide applying their talents and their science to increasing agricultural production to make more efficient, more productive, and to make agricultural methods more sustainable. Australia does, as the member indicates, make significant contribution in this field. Only this week, our scientific credentials in the agriculture field were given a further boost by appointment of a sixth Australian scientist lead a major international agricultural research centre. That is six out of only 22 the worldwide, so we are really fighting very huge much above our weight in this area. The appointment of Dr Eric Craswell as the new Director-General of the International Board for Soil Research and Management, means that in the last year three senior scientists from ACIAR, the Australian for International Agricultural Research, have been appointed to lead international centres. Our contribution is not just I significant; it is second to none. IBSRAM promotes soil management research in develbe oping countries. In other words, it focuses on are the welfare of the soil, which is the most fundamental resource for agriculture and the prime consideration in natural resource conservation. One of the reasons we can take pride in this is the increasing part played by the aid program which operates through ACIAR. It is not just a funding body for agricultural research. It puts together collaborative, cohas operative teams of scientists from Australia other countries to work together to solve problems, and that has given our scientists international experience which makes them valued in the research community. This would not happen if it were not for the climate fostered by this government, and indeed supported by the opposition, through the aid program. As long as I am minister responsible for this, those opportunities will continue. I conclude by drawing attention to the science writer of the Australian, who is one of the few voices crying out for recognition of the fact that this is a field in which Australia leads the world. He points out in a recent article: The doctrine of excellence is to focus your efforts on the field in which you enjoy your greatest natural advantages-and do everything within your power to enhance them. Devising new ways to produce food sustainably could be Australia's true opportunity for greatness. In the time it tookfor question time4000 children died of malnutrition-related disease. Without a huge international effort, that toll will double and redouble ... But this country has the answers, if only it has the vision to apply them-and the will.

Speaker: Mr RICHARD EVANS
Title: PRIVILEGE
text: I wish to raise a matter of privilege and contempt and I ask that it be referred urgently to the Privileges Committee for investigation. I cite as justification for this request section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 which is listed on page 954 of House of Representatives Practice which says in part that contempt is recognised if conduct constitutes an improper interference with the free performance by a member of the member's duties as a member. I also recommend, when you consider this request, that you review the Coleman case which is listed on page 706 of House of Representatives Practice and the advice about the obstruction of officers of the House in the execution of their duty or other people employed by the House, or entrusted with the execution of its orders, or the molestation of those people on account of their having carried out their duties, constitutes contempt. The matter of concern is that thousands of Australians, particularly in Western Australia but quite possibly Australia-wide, have been and quite possibly continue to be denied telephone access and possibly access by correspondence to many federal MPs and possibly therefore to government agencies and departments. I am also concerned that some MPs belonging to the Labor Party have been and possibly will be prevented and impeded from performing their duties as elected representatives of the people and, tragically, may also be acquiescing in all of this contempt. I raise as support of my request an article in the West Australian, written by Mr Randal Markey and published on Saturday, 7 October. I refer you to the article. I will not read it out but I will quote it in small part: The Community and Public Sector Union, which represents staff in MPs' offices, has accused Assistant Treasurer George Gear of failing to comply with work bans over a pay dispute. The article went on to say: "No other electorate office in WA (including those of Ministers) is failing to follow these bans. "I would urge you to support our action as your other WA Federal colleagues are." Mr Gear said that it was not helping him hang on to his seat of Canning, which he holds by only 240 votes. He also said he did not tell his office staff what to do. The article continued: WA Labor Senator Jim MCKiernan said the bans were frustrating and would be counter-productive in trying to address the Government's loss of support among blue-collar workers. I also submit a fax message sent to my office from a staffer of the President of the Senate. On receipt of this fax the staff in my electorate office expressed anger and the feeling of having been intimidated by it, or at least the threat of intimidation. The fax read: To all SCABS, We are fighting for all Electorate Staff so why don't you help us to succeed for you as well. Please support us. The contact number was in fact the President of the Senate's office. The action taken by the union and some staff members of ALP federal members amounts to a breach of privilege and contempt and should not be permitted to continue or happen again. For some time the offices of the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and the honourable member for Brand (Ms Fatin), plus the offices of Senators Beahan, Cook and Evans and others, have had answering machines advising of no immediate contact being available due to industrial disputation. I am advised that even today this practice continues in some offices. To cut off access and deny the people their right of access to their elected federal member for assistance on important and urgent matters and other issues is outrageous and scandalous and should be stopped. Furthermore, the Act-Department action of the minister, the member for Canmatching ning, in seemingly acquiescing in this virtual thuggery and saying 'he did not tell his office staff what to do' is a frightening admission by 1994-95. a minister of the Crown. The concept that ordinary Australians, battlers, can be cut off for from making contact with their member of parliament to seek redress and advice is national Air Air outrageous and is a startling admission that a 1994-95. federal member of parliament's work is and can be impeded by a union. Mr Speaker, whilst not denying anyone the opportunity to withdraw their labour priate or denying a much justified pay crease for our overworked staff, I ask that consider the matter in light of section 4 act and refer the matter to the Privileges Committee. I seek leave to table copies of the article and the fax. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the National Party 1994of Australia (Mr Anderson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The failure of the government to provide job security and improving living standards for regional Australians. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This is a government that has become very long indeed on rhetoric about things like social justice, regional development, boosting exports, even retaining the family farm. We hear about how that is important for economic and social reasons now from none other than the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). But there is in fact a huge gulf between rhetoric and reality. As, in the broader context in Australia, the rich get richer and the poor become more numerous, the same is happening in rural Australia. Many of those more numerous poor are rural Australians, our wealth creators, those who provide the overwhelming base for our export performance, and those who, in these increasingly environmentally conscious times, ought to be seen and recognised as the custodians of our natural resource base. Yet, thanks to the government, thanks to that policy drift, their inertia, their reform fatigue, what we really see, despite the rhetoric, in rural and regional Australia is increasing dislocation, increasing poverty, increasing loss of job opportunities, and nowhere do we see these problems more evident than amongst young people in the country. We see anecdotal and real evidence of young men leaving the bush in droves and young women leaving even faster. Tragically, it is often the most talented people with the most to offer for the future, the people who will be most needed in the future in rural Australia, who are leaving. My electorate is no exception. We have noted something of a contraction in the size of the work force in Gwydir since the recession set in over the last couple of years of some 4,500 people-many of them young people, many of them skilled, many of them people who will be needed when things tum around. This is despite the fact that two of Australia's wealthiest agricultural shires are in my electorate-Narrabri and Gunnedah. In the case of Moree, this is reflected in the town by the unbelievable number of vacant homes that are on the market-no purchaser available. In Gunnedah, a couple of hundred homes in what is not a very big town do not even have the power turned on any more. There has been an explosion of farm debt, but the government over the past 13 years has refused to do anything about arresting that decline in our rural fortunes. This has had a significant impact on job opportunities and returns for efforts made in rural Australia. We have seen farm debt go from $7 billion when this mob came to power to $17Y2 billion today. Again, the young are unduly affected. They are giving up hope and questioning their role in the so-called lucky country. Today we heard some statistics from our spokesman in this area about the unemployment of youth; that is, those from 15 to 20 years old. The national youth unemployment rate is 28 per cent. That is a disgrace. Look at what is happening in country regions. I understand that in one district of the Mallee area the youth unemployment rate is about 66 per cent. Two-thirds of the young people in that area do not have a job. The Wide BayBurnett region has a youth unemployment rate of 41 Y2 per cent. The central west of New South Wales has a youth unemployment rate of 32 per cent. In central Queensland that figure is nearly 40 per cent. Those figures probably disguise the reality. It is probably worse in many of those areas but it is covered up by various programs which are designed to disguise the full extent of the real problem and to train people for jobs that tragically will often not be there. Why will they not be there? Because the government is severely inflicted with reform fatigue. Murdoch was spot on when he said that Australia's economy is a disgrace. Didn'the stir up a hornet's nest when he talked about youth unemployment? We saw a mad scramble from those opposite trying to discredit what he had to say. It is very interesting. The people in the bush are losing hope. There is a loss of belief by country people, our wealth creators, in their future just when the experts are now widely beginning to talk about a bright future. A little while ago, Graham Blight made reference here in Canand berra to that fact. Graham Blight is well known and well respected in this place. He predicted that agriculture would be back at the forefront of governments' agendas in coming years for very good reason. He pointed to the fact that by the year 2025, when I will be 68-it is not 30 years time-the world will need another 300 million tonnes of wheat a year just to feed itself, another 260 million tonnes of com, another 210 million tonnes of rice and another 16 million tonnes of fish. Imagine the fibre that we will need to clothe people and the material that we will need to put roofs over our heads globally. Let us put all that into perspective: the biggest crop that Australia, as the world's second biggest exporter of wheat, ever grew was just 22 million tonnes in 1982-83. We will have to find another 300 million tonnes in 30 years time. What are we doing about this problem? There is policy paralysis, drift, a loss and a loss of direction. We are giving away our best talent-the bush-at the very time when we ought to be giving it positive direcshutting tion and confidence and when we should be telling people that there is a future, because there is. But what are we doing? We are seeing the government destroy the heartland of Australia. It is not just Labor in this place that is destroying our heartland. Their cohorts in Queensland and New South Wales are also contributing to the problem. There is appalling lack of consultation on matters such as SEPP46, the state environmental planning policy. There is no consultation with the people at the coalface, the people who actually have stewardship over the environment. They just say, 'Here's what you'll do. Here's how you'll do it. We'll control you. We won't give you the freedom to go out and act in the best long-term interests of either your industry or the people who will follow you in it.' Then we come to forestry. What an absolute debacle, what an absolute mess, we have seen from those opposite. Investment is drying up, and there is one indication of that. We hear all their talk about growing a bigger timber paper products industry. Whilst they talk about it here, it actually happens in New Zealand. They will establish 100,000 hectares of softwood plantation this year. In Australia it is estimated that 8,000 hectares will be established. Some 100,000 hectares will be established there while 8,000 hectares will be so far away, in established here. What is the difference in the job opportunities? What is the opportunity for value adding wood and timber paper products in this country? Unlimited. This year, 40 per cent of the timber and paper product needs of New South Wales alone will be imported-across the nation, it is $3 billion worth-and that figure is growing rapidly. How much investment is on hold because of the uncertainty? Around $2 billion worth in value adding of our product. What is the government doing about it? Well, it is slashed across the papers every morning, isn't it: total and absolute chaos. of hope When we ought to be talking about more opportunities, more jobs, more plantations and more timber, what are we doing? We are the thing down to the huge disadvantage-again, let me emphasise this-not just of country people and young people in the bush but of the nation's economic performance. In case you had not noticed-and here is one of the ministers who is very good on spending money-we have to generate wealth in this country if we are to then distribute it. And here we are again undermining the people who need to be encouraged to invest, an to employ people and to produce a bigger cake so that there is more to go around for everyone. I now tum to the issue of competitiveness. The tyranny of distance is a great problem. I have to touch on this. I cannot resist it as my opposite number over there keeps talking about how he has reformed Australia's waterfront. A recent study was carried out of 46 ports around the world. Although we have spent $400 million since 1989, the beginning of the government's reform program, what has actually happened? Sydney has slipped from 24th to 31st and Melbourne has gone from 28th to 37th in terms of world competitiveness. Did you hear the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) guffaw when I accused the government of having reform fatigue? Did you hear it? It is wonderful, isn't it? I cannot help but mention something we ought to be very proud of in this country: we are the world's No.1 exporter of beef product. But you know what? Such is your reform fatigue that we are no longer competitive at home. The first rule of being an effective trading nation in any given commodity is to make sure that you are competitive at home. But what do we find in the case of the beef industry? We are not competitive at home. So how are we ever going to make it? We have got American and New Zealand product on our shelves. How are we ever going to make it in the important Asian markets to our north if we cannot do our best here? The fact of the matter is that the industry on its knees at the moment and, with it, the well-being of thousands of producers. And here is the rub for you blokes: so are tens of thousands of Australian workers. We have had report after report and study after study which have clearly indicated that we are grossly underperforming to such an extent that the only reason we are competitive on world markets at all is that our beef producers receive as little as half of what their opposite numbers in New Zealand and America get. For years the government has ignored time and again the problem-although the government did decide a couple of years ago that they would have their own industry commission look at this whole issue again. What the commission had to say was really very interesting. The first thing it said was that we are competitive only because of the low prices paid to Australian producers. It went on to say a few other things that members opposite might be interested in. One is that change has been painfully slow and that greater industrial relations flexibility and productivity are the key to the industry'S future. But here is the bit that is really interesting: The Commission has found that greater flexibility. particularly greater use of enterprise agreements, could bring about significant productivity gains with benefits for ... Who would you expect would get the benefits? Farmers? The nation? Do you know who the commission nominated first? The workers of this country. The first who would benefit are the workers-then the producers, the processors and, after that, some consumers, as the commission put it. It is reported in another place that, if we could pick up the hundreds of billions of dollars that are out there to be gained by some improved performance, the benefit to workers would be about 25 per cent of that better return. What did the government do with all this? It sat on it for 14 months. There were 23 major recommendations, and the government picked up one, basically. After 14 months the government introduced some legislation into the second chamber in this place. This is Australia's major agricultuis ral export industry, except when wool overtakes it occasionally. How importantly did the government regard the reform process? Perhaps it is reflected in the fact they picked up just one of 23 recommendations and introduced it on a day when the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) was not even in Australia. It was appropriate that he was in America on that day. That is fine, but the government had 14 months in which to choose a day when the minister would be here to introduce it. But, no, they did not, and so it goes on and on. When we raised enterprise bargaining with them, which they claimed had basically been put in place in the industry-you heard it again from the minister here-he said, 'That's fixed it all up. We don't need to address the other areas here.' And it just so happened that on that day something had fallen off the back of a truck: an independent report on the Department of Primary Industries and Energy which said: In relation to this industryand this is a matter of only weeks old even nowwith some exceptions, progress has generally been limited, with little to show in terms of widespread and quantifiable increases in productivity and efficiency. The [general nature of] enterprise bargains achieved to date have not been particularly innovative or successful in encouraging improvements . . . In many cases, they have been little more than a means to achieve a general wage increase. So there you go-abysmal failure in one of Australia's most important regional industries and most important export industries. Confronted with the evidence from his independent report, Senator Collins over in the other place-and this is very interesting; this is just two weeks ago-went on to say: . . . AMH is engaged right now in its abattoirs at Rockhampton in an exercise to do just thatimprove work practicesin cooperation with the unions and under the supervision of the Industry Commission. I think he meant the Industrial Relations Commission. That is really very interesting. For years and years they can ignore the reform process at the cost of workers, at the cost of the industry and at the possible demise now of the industry; but in the space of two weeks they can act when a complaint comes in from the other side. I reckon that is an enormous vote of no confidence in your system in general and an enormous vote of no confidence in the commission in particular, because they were meant to be overseeing this. In short, the whole process is nothing short of a national disgrace. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Since I have been a minister in this government every MPI from the opposition I have debated has been based on a false premise. Today's MPI is no exception. Not only is today's MPI based on a false premise but also there has been an array of falsehoods asserted in the speech we have just heard. I intend to return to a few of those towards the end of my speech. The MPI refers to the question of job security. It is the case that this country has had one of the most rapid rates of job growth in the entire OECD over a period of several years. In the year to the three months to July-in other words, the most recent quarter for which statistics are available from the Department of Employment, Education and Training-employment growth in Australia as a whole was 4.4 per cent. This represented 347,000 new jobs in Australia as a whole. The implication of the MPI is that rural and regional Australia has missed out on its fair share of that employment growth. What are the facts? The facts are that employment growth in non-metropolitan Australia was much stronger than the average. In fact, in the non-metropolitan area employment growth totalled no less than 6.2 per cent over that period, which is almost twice as great as the 3.4 per cent job growth recorded in metropolitan Australia. That is the first point: rural and regional Australia have shared very substantially in the exceptionally strong job growth that has gone on. Of the 347,000 jobs created in Australia in the course of that year, 170,000 of them-that is, almost half-were in non-metropolitan areas. Indeed in all states, except Victoria and Western Australia-and it is interesting to note that the opposition spokesman and Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), somehow tried to blame Labor state governments for the poor performance-more than 50 per cent of the job growth was outside the capital city. Guess which political parties are in office in those two states! Furthermore, this is not a short-term trend. It is a trend that has been occurring throughout our term of office. It is true that there is considerable variation in unemployment across regional Australia, just as there is considerable variation in unemployment across metropolitan Australia. The Deputy Leader of the National Party's own region, which is north and central west New South Wales, has a rate of 6.6 per cent, which is well below the national average of more than eight per cent. In the Murray-Murrumbidgee area of New South Wales unemployment was as low as 4.4 per cent. The highest level of unemployment in Australia is not in nonmetropolitan Australia, it is in western Melbourne. Of course what matters about unemployment is the policies to reduce it. We are reducing unemployment. Unemployment has fallen in almost all the regions of nonmetropolitan Australia. We gave the economy a fiscal kick-start, which the opposition opposed, from the recession. We are maintaining an accord which has provided a framework that has facilitated strong employment growth. The opposition has opposed that. We have introduced the job compact to provide a fundamental structural change in the labour market in favour of job growth, and particularly job growth opportunities for the disadvantaged in the labour market. The opposition has opposed that. The fact is that the MPI today is from the political party that believes people who live in regional Australia are not part of a broader Australian nation. The National Party has always pretended that somehow regional Australians do not have the same interests as other Australians, which is a nonsense. Moreover, the National Party has always believed that the only people of worth in regional Australia are primary producers and other small business operators. They want to pretend that the indigenous population does not exist, that the social security recipients in regional Australia do not exist and that wage and salary earners in regional Australia do not exist. Mr MCGauran-You don't publish the regional figures.

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The fact is that what this government has done to enhance Australians' living standards is every bit as relevant to regional Australia as it is to metropolitan Australia-if anything, more so. It is interest- point. ing that the member for Gippsland (Mr MCGauran) raises this issue about the youth unemployment statistics. The speech we have just heard from the National Party spokesman is a clear illustration of the way in which those youth unemployment statistics are abused. He said that in certain regions two-thirds of young people in that age group are out of work. The statistics do not show any such thing and you know that. The reality is that, as a result of this government's efforts, participation rates in secondary-tertiary education have increased out of sight. The fact is that most people in the 15to 19-year-old age group are not in the labour market; they are in the education and training system, as they should be. The figures quoted are of those who remain in the labour market, who are a distinct minority. Mr MCGauran-Not to be worried about.

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: No, nobody is suggesting that for a minute. But what we are saying is that you have to interpret these statistics correctly. What we are talking about is that, in the 15to 19-year-old age group, around about nine per cent-obviously far too high still, and nobody disputes that for a minuteare out of work, actively seeking work. All these figures you quote fail to take into account that basic point: in interpreting these statistics, the great bulk of young people are appropriately in the education and training system. The fact is that what this government has done to enhance Australians' living standards is every bit as relevant to regional Australia as it is to metropolitan Australia-if anything, more so. The government's economic policies have centred on making Australia a more competitive nation. Which industries are the beneficiaries of that? The most competitive ones, of course, which are mining, agriculture, downstream processing and tourism, among others. Where are they primarily located? In regional Australia. The government's social policies have ensured that the benefits of the economic growth generated by these economic policies have been equitably distributed. Doesn't regional Australia benefit from that? Mr Anderson-They haven't; that's the

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I just made the point that, if anything, in terms of employment growth, regional Australia has done substantially better in proportionate terms than metropolitan Australia. Don't the pensioners in regional Australia benefit from the 12 per cent real increase in the value of the pension when measured against the consumer price index? Of course they do. I have not had time to check the figures, but I imagine that pensioners are over-represented in non-metropolitan Australia, given the relative attractiveness of the non-metropolitan lifestyle to many older people. That means that our policies of increased adequacy and financial security for pensioners benefit regional Australia more widely. Don't the low income families in regional Australia benefit from the approximate doubling in the real value of additional family payments and their extension to low income working families under this government or the introduction of parenting allowance this year? Of course they do. Self-employed and small business families earning low incomes are eligible for these payments. But you never hear the National Party talking about that. Won't the mothers in regional Australia benefit from the maternity allowance to be introduced next February? Of course they will. Don't families in regional Australia benefit from Medicare? Of course they do. Don't families in regional Australia benefit from expanded child-care assistance; won't they benefit in retirement from expanded superannuation provisions; don't families in regional Australia benefit from expanded education participation? Of course they do. If I recall some data from my previous portfolio accurately, education participation has increased more rapidly for those from regional Australia. In education, as in employpeople ment, a disproportionate-if anything-share of benefits have gone to regional Australia. For example, I recall introducing a higher education equity strategy in my previous portfolio, one which explicitly focused on raising participation rates of people from regional Australia. You have to take all these things into account if you are going to talk about living standards. This is as true of non-metropolitan Australia as it is true of metropolitan Australpayment. is Of course most of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's $930 million in this year's budget goes to nonmetropolitan Australia. But the National Party never welcomes that. The fact is that this government governs for all Australians. I know that it is a matter of great embarrassment to the National Party that we hold more seats in regional Australia than it holds. The very foundation of the Australian Labor Party straddles both regional Australia, most famously, Barcaldine in Queensland, and metropolitan Australia, particularly Balmain in my own electorate. We remain the largest political party in non-metropolitan Australia. That is because we regard Australia as one nation. Compare this with the opposition, who talk a lot about inequality but whose only policy is wage flexibility-which we know is code for wage cuts. We know that this means: accept the contract or get the sack. Who does this threaten most? People who have nowhere else to go. Workers in non-metropolitan Australia are the most vulnerable to these policies. But we do recognise that regional Australia has particular needs and particular circumstances. My own department, the Department of Social Security, for example, has a comprehensive access and equity strategy in place to ensure that all Australians who are entitled to social security payments do in fact receive them, regardless of where they live. We now have 216 regional offices of the Department of Social Security around Australia, 66 smaller offices mostly in regional areas, and nearly 400 visiting services, to ensure that in small towns can access the department. Teleservice centres mean that the department is contactable by telephone from anywhere in Australia for the cost of a local call. We have a network of field officers and community agents particularly servicing Aboriginal Australians. Most recently, of course, we have introduced the drought relief payment. Some 10,400 farm families experiencing exceptional drought circumstances are receiving this It has paid jobsearch allowance rates but does not have an activity test requirement, and the value of the farm asset is exempt from the income test. The National Party do not quote the drought relief payment because it is something they would never had the wit or the wisdom to introduce. This is because it is targeted on those most in need: farmers earning no income or, for that matter, making large losses. The National Party has never been in favour of that. Unlike National Party drought policies it is a cash transfer and so does not provide windfall gains to particular people or distort the pattern of rural prices and production. It is an efficient targeted instrument for helping those in most desperate need. An amount of $82 million was provided to these farmers last financial year. A further $36 million was provided in the first two months of this financial year. This will continue for as long as it is needed for up to six months after the drought declarations are lifted. It is part of a broader drought strategy, expected to cost some $770 million over four years. This is the sort of thing that we are doing for the people for whom you say we have no concern. But government policies for regional Australia do not stop there. In particular, Working Nation allocated $150 million over four years to the regional economic development program. Just to take one example from many, it was this government that provided nonmetropolitan Australians with the same choice of television broadcasting channels as exists in the capital cities. The fact is that the Labor government is interested in developing regional Australia. We are interested in economic development, we are interested in social development and we are interested in ecologically sustainable development. The National Party is interested only in feeding prejudices for the purpose of winning votes. I would just make this point: of course, the premise of this MPI is false. Early in the debate, among the many falsehoods in his speech, the National Party spokesman made this assertion: the poor have got poorer and have become more numerous under this government. Mr Anderson-Certainly more numerous in the bush.

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: These are both demonstrably false propositions which it has traipsed out. Most of these assessments are done on an analyses which are based on the so-called Henderson poverty line, of which Ann Harding, whose paper was quoted the other day, is a strong critic. The fact is that the Henderson poverty line since 1983 has risen 21 per cent in real terms-that is to say, in excess of the inflation rate. It has not stayed static. Ann Harding, in the paper that was quoted earlier, acknowledges that this has the effect of inflating the numbers in poverty. In the United States they have a poverty line which is indexed to prices; in other words, it stays constant in real terms. In contrast to the United States, which has shown an increase in poverty, with a poverty line increased just to maintain it in real terms, if you do that exercise here under this government, you show a substantial decline of the order of around about 30 per cent in the numbers shown to be in poverty. These poverty statistics and these international statistics have to take account of the different conventions and the different methodologies employed in different countries. On any realistic or reasonable assessment, this government has improved substantially the circumstances of people in this country who are the worse off. This is not just people dependent totally on social security payments; this is low wage work working families. If you convert the introduction of additional family payment for low wage working families, which is a measure that this government introduced, taking into account that that is a tax free payment, and consider what the gross wage equivalent of that would be for a family with two children, for example, it is the equivalent of a gross wage increase of $125 a week. That is the sort of thing that this government has done for low income Australians in both the metropolitan areas and the regional areas of Australia.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I must say that I was disappointed by the monologue of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), which amounted, really, to a pious justification, or an attempt at justification, of the rather dreadful situation in this country. The minister seemed to operate on the basis that, if you repeat an untruth often enough, some people will ultimately believe it. Mr Deputy Speaker, listen to these words: Its struggle has always been on behalf of the weak, against the strong for the poor, for those who have never had a chance as against those whose privileged positions have enabled them to prosper even though millions suffer. Whose words were they? They were the the words of Prime Minister Curtin, policy speech on 28 August 1940. The Labor Party has forgotten those words because in the 1995 of today many millions of Australians continue to suffer. Yesterday was the International Day of Poverty. Of course, that gave us the opporgovernment tunity in this country to highlight our very real poverty problem right here in our own backyard. The government, and the minister in particular, should hang their heads in shame on their appalling track record in increasing inequality between rich and over the last decade. Real wages have fallen in the last 12 years; the cost of a mortgage has increased by 50 per cent; and unemploywill ment remains at a record high, with youth unemployment running at least at 28 per cent-and, indeed, very much higher in many other specific parts of the country. Prime Minister Hawke in his policy speech in 1987 said: . . . by 1990, no Australian child need live poverty ... What a sick joke to be perpetrated at the expense of the Australian people. This government-former Prime Ministers, current ministers and current members-are prepared to say absolutely anything at election time in an endeavour to crawl back into government. It has been estimated that 1.9 million Australians, or 11 per cent entire population, are currently in poverty, and 592,000 of them are children aged up 14 years. Prime Minister Hawke said in that no child need be in poverty by 1990. Yet here we are in 1995, five years later, and have almost 600,000 Australian children up to the age of 14 years in poverty. My own home state of Queensland is the most povertyhad stricken state in Australia, with 350,000 people living in poverty. It is interesting to note also that coalition members-members of the Liberal and Naneighbourhoods tional parties-represent the poorest electorthe ates in Australia. My electorate of Fisher one of the poorest electorates in Australia. The minister has come into this place and has read out a whole set of statistics with a view to mislead us, with a view to persuade us situation is other than the reality which from his we face every day of the year. More than one-quarter of children and elderly people in Queensland live in poverty. Nearly one-quarter of young people under the age of 25 live in poverty. So much for this government which claims that it has been the of the underprivileged. So much for this government which, in its 13 years in office, has simply masqueraded around as the champion of the underprivileged. What a con! This con will be exposed once and for all at the federal election, whenever it is held. poor Whether it is held on 9 December, as has been tipped, or whether it is held in February or March next year, the government's failures be exposed once and for all. The government claims to be interested in sole parents, but in Queensland two out of every three sole parents live below the poverty line. The average weekly disposable income is lower in Queensland than in any other place in the country. The national in situation is also appalling. Since Labor came to office, the earning of the bottom 10 per cent of income earners has declined in real terms; yet the earnings of the highest 10 per cent of workers has increased by 17 per cent. We have repeated those figures in this place over and over again. The government has not come up with any satisfactory answer, and people are really seeing through this governof our ment as the fraud that it is. The OECD surveyed some 12 countries and to only three countries-Australia, the US and 1987 Canada-experienced a real decline in the earnings of the least well paid 10 per cent of we workers in the last decade. Let us compare the situation here with the situation in the United Kingdom, where people in that group increases of some 11 per cent. There has been a fall in real household incomes in 70 per cent of neighbourhoods and a real increase in income in only 30 per cent of in Australia. The minister has hide to say that things are better. The is Prime Minister (Mr Keating) says that things will never get better than they are at the moment. Put in plain English, recent research indicates that average household incomes in that the bottom five per cent of neighbourhoods have fallen by more than $7,500 in real terms, while the top five per cent of neighbourhoods have increased their incomes by more than $12,000 on average. The Prime Minister agrees now that the gap between the rich and the poor has widened, but he claims that the recession is over and that we are now in a brave new world. Does the Prime Minister-the person who likes the French clocks, the person who likes the Italian suits-have any compassion at all for people on the poverty line struggling to make ends meet; the people Prime Minister Curtin sought to support in 1940? The simple fact is that this government is a government which has lost contact with its origins. It is a government of the quick dollar; a government of the slick deal. It is no longer the government of the underprivileged, and traditional Labor people are deserting this government. In fact, 52 per cent of blue-collar workers have now deserted this government. That is a matter of concern for you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, representing the electorate Scullin, because 52 per cent of blue-collar workers will not have anything to do with this government-the government of big business and not the government of the little Australian. The government has deserted Labor's traditions of equality and is adopting the view that the widening gap between the haves and the have-nots does not matter. The Keating government, of course, is wrong. It is most important that we have social cohesion and equality in this country. The coalition, upon election to office, will seek to ensure that the disparities which presently exist are reduced. It is obvious that Australians are not better off under this Labor government. The government always talks about the social wage, but the government's most heralded social wage or so-called safety net is ineffectual for many Aussie battlers. Under Labor the education of children has taken a battering. In 1980, 48 per cent of students from lower income households who completed year 12 went on to higher education, but by 1989 the figure had fallen to 35 per cent. Do not be fooled by the government's false attempts to explain away these grim facts with the comments made by the minister. The government continues to fudge figures in the hope that it will continue to confuse the Australian people. I believe the government will stand condemned at the next election. The Minister for Social Security claimed that the federal social wage is $1,774 for every Australian and that this has increased by more than $700 since 1983. This figure is arrived at by adding all federal spending on health, education, housing and child care and dividing that by the number in the population. Again, this is another clever play with figures. It is obvious that, with the increase in the Australian population, the minister is misleading the Australian people. The simple fact of the matter is that this so-called federal social wage is not benefiting the people whom the government claims it is benefiting. It is also obvious that 40 per cent of the lowest income earners receive only 35 per of cent of the social wage, while 40 per cent of the highest income earners receive 46 per cent of the social wage. So we have a situation where the government has endeavoured to confuse the Australian people yet again. Don Russell, the current Australian Ambassador to the United States, has said that he wants to come back here to ensure we do not create in Australia the kind of underclass they currently have in the United States. Everyone agrees that the ambassador's comments are totally out of order for a diplomatic representative of Australia, but the simple fact of the matter is that we already have the working poor in Australia. One has to go no further than today's Australian to read about this. It cites the case of someone working on a single wage and actually earning $200 less than he would be ea..'11ing if he was receiving the dole. That is a matter that should appal every reasonable Australian. This government has failed to provide job security. We have heard the statistics about youth unemployment in region/,tl areas. The minister has endeavoured to hide the real facts by confusing the matter of training and education with unemployment and in doing so hopes the terrible statistics will somehow be improved. The people of Australia will not be fooled by that any more than they have been fooled by so many other comments of the minister. I believe that, if one looked at the principles that the Labor Party has historically stood for and one looked at the inequality in this nation at the moment, one would see that this Labor Party is no longer the Labor Party of the underprivileged and no longer the Labor Party of the battler. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Northern TerritoryParliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training) (4.57 p.m.)-I am very pleased to be here this afternoon to contribute to this debate becauseMr Reith-You are on your own now.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: You want to leave because you do not want to hear what I have to say. I have never heard such blarney as I did in the contributions of the member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) and the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). They made extraordinary claims which bear no relation to what is going on in this community. I will just talk about the policy sclerosis which struck the Liberal and National parties when in government before 1983. Which government had the gumption to reform many of the primary industries which these National Party members supposedly represent? Was it the Liberal Party and National Party coalition? Not on your nelly. Was it the Labor Party? It was. What are some of the industries in the primary sector that have been addressed by the Labor Party? They include the wool industry, the dairy industry, the meat industry, the sugar industry and the horticultural industry-including fruit, vegetables, vineyards and tobacco, just to name a few-plus we have created an aquaculture industry. We do not get any credit for that from the opposition. I heard a spokesman for the dairy industry on Good Morning Australia recently. He said that, whilst a lot of people have gone out of the dairy industry because of the industry's restructuring, its productivity has increased tremendously. I forget the exact figures, but the spokesman said that the industry now has less than half the number of producers, yet they are producing five or 10 per cent more dairy products. Is that a successful policy drive by this government? This industry has become more competitive, by its own admission. Who has achieved this? The Labor government-not the coalition. Which government had the wit and wisdom to introduce a national landcare program? Was it the coalition when they were in office? No, it was the Labor Party in office. How many Landcare groups are there around Australia currently? There are 2,200 active Landcare groups. How much money per annum is being spent on these Landcare groups, which are supported by primary producers throughout Australia? It is $150 million. Was that an initiative of the coalition when they were in government? Did they seek to reform the way in which people treat the land in this country? Did they look at sustainable economic development in a proper sense? Did they look at micro-economic reform when they were in government? No, they did not. They suffered from the same policy sclerosis that they are suffering from now. A number of statistics have been bandied around here this afternoon, some of which relate to unemployment. But I want to go to some figures referred to by the member for Fisher. He talked about household disposal income. Let me make it very clear for all to understand: full-time adult average weekly earnings have increased by 7.2 per cent between June 1983 and June 1995; real household disposal income has increased over that same period by 41.8 per cent; and real household disposal income per capita has increased by 20.9 per cent, almost 21 per cent. We are getting this tirade from the opposition about Australians being worse off as a result of the actions of the Labor government. In fact, they are measurably better off as a result of the deliberate policy determinations made by this government. I will go to some other facts which have implications for what is being said. The previous speaker, the member for Fisher, talked about the social wage. Let's make it very clear: the social wage includes expenditure on health, education, housing and child care. Under a coalition government, of which the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, was Treasurer, between 1970-78 and 1982-83 the change in the real value of the Commonwealth social wage per person was a reduction of 17.5 per cent. That is, there was a 17.5 per cent fall in the social wage under the previous coalition government. Since Labor has been in power, since 198283, the social wage has gone up by 73 per cent. Yet the opposition still has the gallwith the National Party supposedly representing regional Australia-to come in here and expect us to believe the nonsense they are perpetrating, that somehow or other Australians are worse off under Labor. Nothing could be further from the truth. I make the point that the National Party and, indeed, the Liberal Party purport to represent the inter-sts of business. One other area which has been reformed under Labor is the tax system. Let us just have a look at a couple of figures which demonstrate yet again why Australians, wherever they are-rural, regional or metropolitan Australia-are measurably better off under Labor than they have ever been, certainly a lot better off they were under the previous coalition government, and a lot better off than they ever be under a government administered by the opposition. One interesting figure is the amount of money the government spends for its own purposes. Government revenue as a proportion of GDP under the Howard government in 1982-83 was 26 per cent. Under the current government that figure is 25.3 per cent. We are spending less of our income as a proportion of GDP. Government outlays as a percentage of GDP when Mr Howard was the Treasurer were 28.6 per cent. Under this government, this year, they are 25.1 per cent. That is just another example. One of the interesting issues in relation to the ability of business to get on, to do its job and be competitive, and to families surviving, is income tax. What is the comparison between the rate of income tax under the opposition when it was in power and the rate of income tax now being experienced by Australians wherever they might live? Top marginal tax rates under Mr Howard were 60 per cent. They are now 47 per cent. The bottom marginal tax rate under Mr Howard was 30 per cent. It is now 20 per cent. The company tax rate under Mr Howard was 46 per cent. Under this government it is 36 per cent. What other points of comparison do we need to demonstrate how measurably better off Australians are, wherever they might be, than they were under a Howard coalition. And how much better off are they than they would have been had, God forgive us, the coalition been in government during the 1980s and early 1990s. We have heard these arguments about regional economic development. The point that was made, properly, by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) was that the employment rate has grown faster in nonmetropolitan Australia than in metropolitan Australia. I will give you a few examples, Mr Deputy Speaker, of unemployment in areas represented by National Party members. The leader of the debate for the opposition this afternoon was the member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson). In June 1994, unemployment than in the DEET region of Moree, which is in Gwydir, was 12.9 per cent. In June of 1995, will the figure was 8.9 per cent, a reduction of four per cent in that member's electorate In Taree, in the electorate of the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), the unemployment rate in June of 1994 was 15.3 per cent. It has dropped by 5.2 per cent in the last 12 months. We saw the member for Gippsland (Mr MCGauran) in here this afternoon. In his electorate, the unemployment rate in June 1994 was 14.4 per cent. The unemployment rate in June 1995 was 7.9 per cent, a fall of 6.5 per cent. These are the people who are trying to tell us that, somehow or other, people in the bush, in regional Australia, are worse off under a Labor government and that things are getting worse. Things are getting measurably better. Indeed, the policies of the government have been supported by our opponents. Members of the National Party have given high praise to the regional economic initiatives put in place by this government, especially in relation to employment.

Speaker: Mr SNOWDON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Of course they should. It is worth pointing out that one of the most significant initiatives undertaken by the Department of Employment, Education and Training has been the development of area consultative committees, which represent combined industry, union, community and government partnerships to deal with local employment and training issues. National Party members have given high praise to these initiatives. They have said to the government, 'We want you to do more in our electorates because what you are doing is good for our electorates and good for regional Australia.' Yet the opposition, this afternoon in this House, are trying to argue that somehow or other Australians are worse off in regional Australia than they ought to be or than they would be under a coalition government. Nothing could be further from the truth. That is clearly and amply demonstrated by the statistics which are available for all to in public documents-absolutely distorted in the way the opposition have spoken about them. Those statistics clearly demonstrate that the argument put by the opposition in this matter of public importance this afternoon is completely fallacious. (Time expired) NA Message from the Administrator reported informing the House of assent to the following bill: Trade Marks Bill 1995. NA AMENDMENT BILL (No.2) 1995 Consideration in Detail The bill. Consideration resumed.

Speaker: Dr KEMP
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING
text: In introducing the government's amendments to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.2) 1995, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) really gave the game away when attempting to justify them. This is a government which has made a deal at the expense of students. The government and the universities appear to have agreed that there will be additional places if today's students cough up the money. I do not need to remind the House that this government constantly tells us that it is opposed to up-front fees for Australian undergraduate students. This is the government that introduced the HECS scheme and has relentlessly boosted the level of HECS. This is the third time the government has proposed to increase the rate of HECS repayments. This government, despite the minister's disclaimers in his speech, has winked for a long time at the indisputable fact that Australian undergraduates are being charged up-front fees through the back door. Australian undergraduates are paying for courses not for credit, and when they pass those courses are being credited for them. It is a way of enabling them to get into the system. The government claims that it is unable to establish the validity of these claims. If that is so, then its see information sources about the higher education system are very poor. The coalition has no objection to the particular amendments which have been put forward. They were foreshadowed in the second reading speech-they were not clearly foreshadowed as amendments, I might saywhich introduced the bill. The point was foreshadowed and we do not object to that. What we do object to is the hypocrisy of this government in saying that it is unable to fund these additional places unless the students themselves cough up the money. That is blackmail against today's students. It is totally unjustified. When the Senate decides, as I believe it will, to support the coalition's amendments to this legislation, I challenge the minister to make it clear that the government places so little weight on access to the university system that it is prepared to take places away from Victoria and South Australia. If the government does that and decides that it will cut places out of the system, that will not be a result of the decisions of the coalition. It will not be a result of the decisions of the Senate. It will flow directly from the government's own priorities. What is clear is that these places are the lowest possible priority of the government. The minister feels free to spend tens of millions of dollars out of the national priorities reserve scheme, which is really the ministerial slush fund, yet he threatens students with the loss of places. This is contemptible. It will be noted by students around Australia and I have no doubt that it will be resolutely and absolutely rejected by them. Amendments agreed to. Bill, as amended, agreed to. Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I am glad there are so many members of the government in here to hear me speak about taxation. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3), which was introduced in this place on 29 June of this year, makes a range of amendments including changes affecting foreign controlled companies; changes affecting dividends paid out of capital accounts, which were announced in this year's budget; extending the accelerated depreciation of ships to 30 June 2002; a number of changes to the collection of tax; reducing the twice monthly remitter threshold from $5 million to $1 million as announced in this year's budget; increasing the infrastructure borrowings rebate to 36 per cent in line with the company tax and changes to the superannuation guarantee system allowing employees to elect that employers do not make superannuation guarantee contributions and by allowing the notional earnings base to be used to calculate superannuation contributions. There are three aspects of this bill in particular which I wish to address today. The first one relates to the part of the bill dealing with foreign income and in particular with tainted income. The Australian controllers of a controlled foreign company are not taxed on that part of the controlled foreign company's tainted income-that is, income including passive and certain other business income which is less than five per cent of its total income which passes the active income test. The commissioner may make adjustments reflecting arms-length values when determining a controlled foreign company's attributable income but it has not been clear whether the adjustment affects the active income test. A lack of power to make adjustment to amounts used in determining the active income test may result in a CFC satisfying the test where it should have failed. This bill seeks to clarify that where CFCs have entered non-arms-Iength transactions with related parties the commissioner is allowed to make adjustments reflecting armslength values to determine whether a CFC has passed the active income test. Aspects of this particular part of the bill have been raised with the opposition, in particular by the Corporate Tax Association. We are aware from comments made through the Corporate Tax Association that there is more than one company group adversely affected and the legislation would have produced inequitable tax consequences if it had been enacted in the form of the bill. Of particular concern is the aspect that the application of the amendment incorporated in the bill is to apply for statutory accounting periods ending after 30 June 1995. For a CFC with a statutory accounting period ending after that date, the amendment is therefore applicable as from the beginning of that particular statutory accounting period and therefore has retrospective application. I understand an amendment will be moved in relation to that matter and the opposition will be supporting that particular amendment. The second aspect of the bill that I wish to turn to relates to dividends paid out of capital accounts. The current position is t-at all dividends received by resident public companies from resident companies and franked or grouped company dividends received by resident private companies from resident companies are free from tax as a result of the intercorporate dividend rebate. Certain distributions debited to a company's share capital or share premium account or asset revaluation reserve are characterised as dividends. The result is that these distributions qualify for rebate and effectively give tax redistributions to corporate shareholders and pass on franking credits to shareholders ordinarily unable to access them. The bill disqualifies dividends that are debited or paid from amounts transferred from, first, share capital accounts, secondly, share premium accounts or, thirdly, asset revaluation reserves from being rebatable or frankable dividends. Share premium accounts include share premium accounts tainted by the inclusion of amounts other than share premiums or amounts which cannot be identified as share premiums in the company's books and which do not therefore satisfy the section 6 definition of 'share premium account'. As a consequence of the introduction of the new measures, most of the rebatable dividend adjustment provisions in the legislation have become redundant and are being repealed. The amendments will apply to dividends paid after 7.30 p.m. on 9 May 1995 unless they were declared prior to that time. Dividends from amounts transferred before 9 May from a share capital or share premium account or asset revaluation reserve are not subject to the amendments nor are dividends paid under certain transitional arrangements. These measures may have, we believe, some unintended consequences and the Insurance Council, in particular, has argued that the legislation could have the effect of preventing Australian companies from franking dividends paid from the ordinary retained earnings where movements occurred to and from the company's asset revaluation reserves as part of their ordinary business. I understand that the government is proposing certain amendments in relation to this provision in particular. What the Insurance Council pointed out is that there is a serious technical deficiency in the current drafting of part of the bill in so far as it relates to rebatable and frankable dividends. The council believes that the legislation, as currently drafted prior to any amendment by the government, could have the effect of preventing Australian companies from franking dividends paid from ordinary retained earnthe ings where movements occurred to and from the company's asset revaluation reserves as part of their ordinary business activity. The impact of this legislation, if enacted in the form that has been presented, could be disastrous for many Australian companies and the anomaly is clearly something-which the Insurance Council, in particular, believes and we would concur with it-that was never intended at the time the proposals were announced in the federal budget on 9 May. I will not take the time of the House to go into the technical detail that has been raised by the Insurance Council of Australia, as I understand this is the subject of the amendments which will be moved in the committee stage on behalf of the government. The third area which I wish to address in relation to this somewhat technical legislation relates to the notional earnings base of the superannuation guarantee charge. Currently, employers can use their pre-21 August 1991 employee earnings base if they continue to contribute to the same fund and under the same law award arrangement or schemes as for an employee for whom they were contributing immediately before 21 August 1991. If they restructure, they generally will have to contribute under the ordinary time earnings base. The bill amends the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 to extend the use ofpre-21 August 1991 employee earnings bases if employers restructure their superannuation funds.
