An employer will be allowed to keep pre-21 August 1991 earnings bases if the employer contributes under the same law award arrangement or scheme to, first, a new fund under the same earnings base as the original fund if employees transfer between the funds and receive substantially the same or improved rights to benefits; secondly, an existing fund in relation to an employee of a former employer who transfers to the fund from the former employer's fund because of a business acquisition if the base was used in the former employer's fund; or, thirdly, a former employers fund for employees who transfer to the new employer because of a business acquisition. The amendments affect the calculation of the superannuation guarantee charge from 1 July 1995 where qualifying restructures occur after 28 June 1994. The effect is that employers reorganising funds after the announcement need not lose an existing employee earnings base for contributions made for contribution periods after 1 July 1995. Employers who restructured after the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 28 June 1994, which was when this measure was announced, but before 1 July 1995 will have changed to the ordinary time earnings base from the time of restructure. On 1 July 1995 they will be able to revert to the pre-21 August 1991 earnings base to which they previously contributtd. The amendment affects an employer's contributions only from 1 July 1995 so that contributions already made by employers during 1994-95 and contributions due for that year will not be reduced. The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia has raised a particular concern in relation to the notional earnings base. ASFA believes that the changes should be effective from the commencement of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 and should cover all employer and/or fund reconstructions irrespective of the date of those reconstructions. The problem which ASFA points to refers to the definition of earnings base in the superannuation guarantee legislation in circumstances where there has been a reconstruction. Paragraph 3.3 of the Treasurer's discussion paper, issued on 4 December 1991, stated that the earnings base for superannuation guarantee contributions would be that set out in the governing rules of the scheme or in an award, provided that, firstly, the scheme was in existence on 20 August 1991 or, secondly, the scheme was not in existence on 20 August 1991 but is a successor to a scheme that was in existence on 20 August 1991 and the earnings base used is no narrower than that used by the original scheme. When the superannuation guarantee legislation was enacted in 1992 no provision was made for these successor funds circumstances. The current bill seeks to address this situation, but only from 1 January 1995. I should indicate that in their representations ASFA is not seeking the retrospective operation of the amendments in order to allow employers to claim refunds from funds. If considered necessary, a provision to prescribe such claims could be included in the legislation. My question in relation to this particular matter-the notional earnings base as it relates to the superannuation guarantee charge-is one which has been effectively raised: why shouldn't the changes be effective from the commencement of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act and cover all employer and/or fund reconstructions, irrespective of the date of those reconstructions? I hope that when the Treasurer or the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) come to speak again in this particular debate they could give some indication to the House and to the coalition regarding that particular matter because it does seem to be an anomaly in the way in which the provisions of this bill have been drafted. Apart from those matters, there are a number of other technical and mechanical aspects of this bill which I will not detain the time of the House this evening by going into in great detail, but those three matters are matters on which the opposition, whilst it does not oppose the legislation, would seek some clarification. In relation to the first matter that I mentioned, we will be supporting an amendment to change the actual date which is set out in the bill itself.

Speaker: Mr HAVILAND
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Macarthur) (5.32 p.m.)I am pleased to support the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1995. I was wondering whether, given that the previous speaker was the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), an amendment had been moved to bring back the GST. I guess we will have to wait and find out when we take the vote. This bill covers quite a number of areas of taxation issues. It covers issues such as foreign income, rebatable and frankable dividends, bankruptcy and losses, reduction of PAYE early remittance threshold, group certificates and other PAYE provisions and superannuation guarantee matters. One of the things that I have come to learn in the time. I have been here is how complex and big our tax act is. It covers some 5,000 pages at last count. In my first few months here, after I was appointed to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, at the tail end of the taxation inquiry, I learnt that the taxation law was very complex. People around the room in that PAC inquiry all agreed that something had to be done. I know now that there is a lot of work being done in the Australian Taxation Office on simplifying the tax act. In the meantime, we have to deal with the current situation and we have a number of these amendments which seem to come before the House and the Senate every year. The taxation law is a bit like social security provisions-the more you get into it and the more you look at different provisions, the more complex it seems. It does not matter what governments try to do, there always seems to be a complication and anomaly that can throw up an injustice, like something that will affect somebody differently from somebody else. We never seem to be able to get the balance quite right in terms of fairness and equity on the one hand and simplicity on the other hand without affecting somebody somewhere along the line. I know that there is a lot of work going on and there is a project called the taxation law improvement project under way at the moment. I guess it was partly because of the desire for simplicity-at least that was one of the attractions-that the opposition decided to promote a consumption tax, a goods and services tax, before the last election. One of the arguments in favour of the consumption tax was that it was simpler and everyone would pay the same amount of 15 per cent on all goods and services, except food. That was supposed to be simpler and therefore easier to collect. That was one of the great attractions put forward for it. Even though I do not agree with a consumption tax and never have, there are a lot of people, including some in the tax office, who argue quite genuinely that they believe that that is an attraction of a consumption tax and that we will eventually have one. I hope we never do because I believe it is an inequitable tax and a regressive tax. I do know that some of my friends and people in the community genuinely believe that, because of this supposed simplicity and equality-although it is not really, of course-with everyone paying the same flat right of consumption tax, it is therefore simpler and more easy to administer and harder to avoid. I do not happen to believe that. I think that it has been pointed out that even a GST is not foolproof or avoidance proof and there could still be a black economy associated with a consumption tax. I guess that was one of the arguments put forward-the need to simplify the tax legislation. Mr Andrews-I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. If we were debating a consumption tax, the honourable member's remarks would be relevant. But, given that there is no such proposal in this bill and the title of this bill is quite clearly defined and not open to all sorts of related purposes, I would ask you to bring the honourable member back to the point of the bill before the House.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I suggest that the honourable member for Macarthur adhere to the point of the legislation.

Speaker: Mr HAVILAND
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: With respect, this is a wide ranging bill on a number of issues relating to tax, and I was covering them in a broad ranging fashion, as is the custom on many bills in this House. I have already said that there is a need for simplification, but tax is also a very emotional issue. Unfortunately, in this country it seems to be fashionable to talk about reducing tax. We are, as we quite often hear, the second lowest taxed country in the OECD. We were the lowest taxed country; I believe Turkey is now apparently lower taxed than we are, because of some fiddling of the figures or whatever. So now we are the second lowest taxed country in the OECD. Unfortunately, some people in the government seem to think that is a badge of honour and we should boast about that. I believe that it is a bit of a lem and people in the community are increasingly seeing it, if they are honest, as a problem because the revenue is important. People do expect a certain level of service and quality of services from governments at all levels. If we are going to have that service, people do have to face up to the situation that people have to pay tax and the revenue has to be there. It has to be fair and equitable, of course. But to suggest that we pay too much tax, as a lot of people do, particularly on the other side of the House and in the business community, et cetera, is not only dishonest but unfair and damaging to the Australian economy and the fabric of society. Unfortunately, because of the 'greed is good' mentality, particularly of the opposition, we have this situation where expectations are raised. Any suggestion that we pay more tax or that individuals pay more tax is treated with horror and we have all sorts of people running for cover, saying, 'We are a lower taxing party than you are,' et cetera. I believe that is an undesirable feature of current Australian politics. We really do need to face up to the fact that people have to pay tax and they should pay the tax that is due. That does not mean that ordinary workersPA YE taxpayers-should necessarily pay more tax. One of the biggest problems is compliance and the avoidance industry, where companies or people on better incomes are able to minimise tax through all sorts of clever accountants and tax minimisation schemes. Of course, one obvious one that I have come across in the last few weeks is the move away from PA YE towards the PPS scheme. We have a number of examples, particularly in the construction industry, where workers are forming themselves into companies or becoming contractors and, therefore, somehow or other qualifying to be PPS taxpayers rather than PA YE taxpayers. That is totally against the spirit of taxation laws, and I understand that that is being looked at by the tax office. It cannot come too soon as far as I am concerned. Not only is this an organised attempt to supposedly bring more flexibility into industrial relations, thereby basically probsmashing industrial relations and smashing trade unionism by everyone becoming a contractor-which would suit the opposition's industrial relations policies perfectly-but also this is potentially eroding the revenue in a big way. That is one area that I will certainly be keeping an eye on in terms of tax policy to make sure that that does not continue and that people do as they are supposed to do-pay the tax that they are obliged to pay under the PA YE system, whether or not they want to call themselves contractors or subcontractors. I have talked to a few friends recently, including people that I know in the taxation area, about the idea of making the tax system simpler. Most PAYE taxpayers probably get a small refund every year. They get their Tax Pack every year, and hopefully the Tax Pack is correct and they can get around all the supposed errors in it. It used to be called Form S. It possibly still is called that. I have not done my tax this year yet. I should not admit that, should I? I have only about two weeks to go. The ordinary battlers, the PA YE taxpayers who earn an ordinary income, fill in their tax forms and they might get a small refund-somewhere between $100 or up to $1,000 a year, if they are lucky. It seems to me that the tax system is administered in a rather expensive way. A good idea might be to bring about, on a properly costed basis, a situation where ordinary taxpayers who earn only wageswho do not have other complications which preclude them from filling in a Form S, for example-be given the option of not bothering with a taxation return. By perhaps ticking a box at the beginning of the year on, say, their employment declaration certificate, they might opt out of the taxation system, in the sense that they would not have to bother with a taxation return, and in return they might get $500 or $1,000, whatever is a reasonable rate. I have not costed this, so I do not know. That would probably save the Taxation Office a lot of money. It would save a lot of paper. It would not cost ordinary taxpayers. Of course, you could always opt back into the tax system if you thought you could get more of a refund from filling in the form. But, if they are just average taxpayers who might get a few hundred dollars a year, they could opt out of the system and get more in their pay packets, which would add up to the same amount-an averaged out amount every year-and they would not have to bother with the form. That does not mean that you would have to cut staff in the Taxation Office. It would ensure that the valuable staffing resources in the Taxation Office were directed away from processing thousands and thousands of ordinary PA YE taxpayer forms towards looking at the tougher areas of taxation-getting some of the big fish and making sure that some of the people who make a bit of an industry out of ripping off the tax system and paying as little tax as possible actually pay their taxes. We do not necessarily need to raise tax levels in this country, if only we could get everyone to pay the tax that they should be paying. That has been the major problem. It was exemplified in the late 1970s when the current Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), was Treasurer. We had the famous bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, and a lot of pressure was put on the then government to do something about that when it became public knowledge. The then Treasurer did make some belated measures, and for his reward he got castigated by his own party in Western Australia. We are still seeing the effects of that in the 1990s with some of the internal Liberal Party politics in Western Australia, which are an echo of the bad days of the seventies and eighties. I lived in Western Australia in the 1970s, and I can recall the Liberal Party slogans and stickers that used to be put up at election times by the Liberal Party that 'taxation is theft'. Obviously, the people who run the Liberal Party in Western Australia, the ones who have got the numbers over there, do not think that anyone should pay tax or that it should be voluntary rather than a responsibility. The bottom-of-the-harbour schemes existed in the 1980s, and this government, from 1983 onwards, had to try to plug the hole in the tax system by bringing in various measures. The measures are ongoing, such as the ones in the bill that we are voting on today. Of course, we have problems also in the Senate with taxation issues. It is very difficult when neither party has a majority in the Senate to get agreement on some of these complex areas. That is understandable. Tax is a very complex area, and the sooner we get some simplification as a result of this major project being undertaken in the tax office then the better we will all be. There should be equity and honesty in taxation. There should be an equitable progressive taxation system whereby those who can afford to pay tax most pay the most and there should be relative relief for those on the lower end of the income scale. Our taxation system largely attempts to do that, although perhaps it does not always get it perfectly right. But, as I have said a number of times, it is a very complex system, and we will always find somebody who will say that they are disadvantaged. I guess that's life. The social security system is similar in that respect. What has made it difficult is this 'greed is good' mentality. The same thing happens in other countries. The conservative parties-the opposition in Australia-build up this expectation that we are all paying too much tax, and that makes it very difficult for governments to be responsible in taxation and, at the same time, have policies that ensure their re-election. I agree that at election times people do get a bit carried away with promises and expectations. But what has made it very difficult in this climate which has been created, particularly on the other side of the House, is the suggestion made to people-and suggesting it often enough so that people believe it-that as a community we are somehow paying too much tax. We are not paying too much tax. We need the revenue so that we can provide the community services and social justice that people expect and that Labor governments certainly stand for. It is not an easy thing, but anything that we can do to tighten avoidance and ensure that the revenue base is there but at the same time make it as equitable, fair and simple a system as possible is to be commended. I therefore commend these measures to the House.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) was introduced into the House on 29 June this year. It makes nine substantive amendments to our tax laws. The provisions set out to amend several principal acts, including the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 and Bankruptcy Act 1966. The changes in the bill include those affecting controlled foreign companies; dividends paid out of capital accounts, as announced in the 1995 budget; and extending the accelerated depreciation of ships to 30 June 2002. Further, changes are proposed to the method of collecting tax, reducing the price monthly remitter threshold from $5 million to $1 million, as announced in the budget. and increasing the infrastructure borrowings rebat(! to 36 per cent in line with the company tax rate. There are also changes to the super guarantee charge system in regard to allowing employees to elect that members not make SGC contributions under certain circumstances and by allowing the notional earnings base to be used to calculate SGC contributions. As to rebatable and frankable dividends, this bill proposes to amend the income tax laws so that dividends that are debited to share capital, premium accounts or revaluation reserves of a company are disqualified from being rebatable or frankable. The reason the government is taking this kind of action is apparently to stop companies providing tax free distributions to corporate shareholders or transferring franking credits to shareholders by inappropriate means. This particular measure is therefore aimed at limiting any potential tax avoidance. The only problem is that there is ample evidence that the government is yet again trying to crack a walnut with a sledgehammer. There are unintended consequences of the proposal before us which impact on ordinary commercial transactions that are totally lawful. The Insurance Council has had this to say: We believe that the legislation, as currently drafted, could have the effect of preventing Australian companies from franking dividends paid from ordinary retained earnings, where movements have occurred to and from the company's asset revaluation reserves, as part of their ordinary business. The council went on to say: The impact of this legislation, if enacted, could be disastrous for many Australian companies, and the anomaly is clearly something that was never intended at the time the proposals were announced in the federal budget . . . Because the effect of the provisions is to deny a company the ability to frank its dividends, the impact of the deficiencythat is, I think, the deficiency in the bill's wordingcould extend beyond Australia's corporate sector to many thousands of individual and institutional shareholders, in receipt of dividends which a company was unaware could not be franked. The Insurance Council has provided an example to illustrate this anomaly. Where a company owns a building at 30 June 1994 which cost, say, $100,000 to purchase but is now valued at $150,000, the amount to be credited to the revaluation reserve is quite obviously $50,000. There is also a corresponding debit to the asset account. However, by 30 June 1995, where the value of the building has fallen to $100,000 the company will debit the asset revaluation reserve and credit the asset account with the amount of $50,000. This entails a transfer of an amount from a 'disqualifying account', the asset revaluation reserve account, to a 'non-disqualifying account', the asset account. Under section 461 of this bill, as part of the write-down, the company will credit the $50,000 I have mentioned in the example to the notional disqualifying account. If no other events occur, and the company pays a dividend of, say, $200,000 in July 1995, with the full amount being debited to its retained earnings, section 46G(1), as currently drafted, will provide that $50,000 of the dividend so paid will not be rebatable and will not be capable of being franked. Mr John Hodgkinson of the Insurance Council, in describing that particular situation, has said: This situation will not be unusual and is likely to impact on many companies who have amounts moving into and out of asset revaluation reserves, for perfectly legitimate commercial reasons, e.g. complying with accounting standards. He has also made the observation that there is nothing to connect the asset revaluation reserve movements with the payment of a dividend. It is totally ridiculous for a company to be placed in the position of paying a dividend in a proper manner but then finding that dividend cannot be franked or rebated to recipient shareholders. The Taxation Institute of Australia also raises the concern that this legislation will impede legitimate corporate reconstructions. Where this takes the form of the insertion of a holding company between the shareholders and an existing company, companies should not be hindered in undertaking legitimate corporate reorganisations. The unintended consequences of this bill should be addressed. I have been informed that the government has prepared some amendments-and they came to hand late this morning-to address the concerns of the Tax Institute and the Insurance Council. I got them this morning at a quarter past nine. The bill was scheduled to be debated at 10 o'clock. I did not have an explanatory memorandum for those amendments, which go to 21,4 pages. Again, this is an example of the disdain with which the parliament is treated when it considers complex legislation. On the matter of the changes affecting the tainted income of controlled foreign companies-CFCs-there is a retrospective element. The explanatory memorandum states: The amendments will clarify that the Commissioner of Taxation may make adjustments, reflecting arm's length values to amounts used in determining whether a CFC has passed the income test. Without wanting to go into great depth now, because I will do so later in the detailed stages, the problem here is that this amendment will be applied retrospectively for the accounting periods commencing before but ending after June 1995. Therefore this measure is applicable from 1 July 1995 and as a consequence it will in some cases have a retrospective impact on the attributable income of CFCs where their financial year does not conveniently end on 30 June 1995. That is not uncommon, although it is not right either. That is most inequitable. I have constantly made the point that retrospectivity as a rule should be avoided in any legislation and in particular in tax legislation. Retrospectivity is only acceptable to me when it does not create losers but, even then, it should still be avoided. Retrospective tax legislation by this Labor government is far from unusual, as I am sure the House is aware. It has been a tool of Labor and it has not hesitated to use it. However, it is clear that such retrospectivity undermines certainty, credibility and fairness in the tax system. With the constant stream of tax amendment bills coming before this place, as well as the draft rulings from the Australian Taxation Office, it is obvious that the taxpaying community does not need the added uncertainty of retrospective tax changes. There must be community confidence in the certainty of the law--certainty that today's legal act does not tomorrow become the trigger for a penalty or obligation by law created subsequent to that legal act and applied retrospectively. With tax law, taxpayers need to be able to determine their obligations with at least a modicum of certainty. But with retrospective tax legislation not only must taxpayers assess their tax position according to current law but also they need to determine what the intent of the relevant law was at the time it was drafted and passed through the parliament. That is necessary because one day the legislation will be retrospectively amended along certain lines. The problem is that we expect too much from taxpayers and accountants. How can taxpayers be expected to pre-empt what was the real intent of the law with their scarce resources, when parliament and its supporting bureaucracy couldn't get it right in the first place? The parliament, and especially the government, should be accountable for their errors, not taxpayers. Retrospectivity is a denial of natural justice and a repudiation of fairness where it occurs in our tax system. Not only is the tax system almost unintelligible, compliance costs exorbitant and there is no stability in the tax regime, but also retrospectivity there is a serious element of guesswork, in trying to get an understanding of tax law. Stability and certainty in the tax system are key concepts this government simply has not been able to grasp. This bill comes before the House just over 10 years since the government announced its reform of the Australian tax systemotherwise aptly known as RATS. This announcement followed the much heralded 1985 tax summit, you will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, where the much supported option C of the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was rejected by Bob Hawke in a deal with the ACTU heavies. RATS was supposed to provide a tax system which is simpler, fairer, does not increase the overall tax burden, does not disadvantage welfare recipients, moderates wage pressures, does not stifle investment, growth and jobs, and has widespread community support. Key aspects of Labor's changes included the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and dividend imputation. Labor might postulate that it has succeeded in meeting its objectives, and quite often it does. However, the reality is they have failed dismally. The overall tax burden has increased. Taken as a percentage of gross domestic product, public sector revenues have increased from 33.4 per cent to 34.4 per cent. Of this, the federal component appears to have fallen, but only because grants to the states have been slashed. Then, of course, when compulsory superannuation is added-because, let us face it, it is a tax on earnings-the overall tax burden has increased. Mr George Megalogenis put it accurately in the Australian of 19 September 1995 when he wrote: The total tax burden on workers is greater now than it was 10 years ago todaythat was on 19 Septemberwhen Paul Keating unveiled his historic tax reform package to slash marginal rates and restore fairness and credibility to the tax system. Mr Megalogenis went on to say: Australians are also paying more in indirect taxes than they would have under the coalition's goods and services tax plan ... How is that? Australians are now also paying with more in indirect taxes than they would have under the coalition's goods and services tax plan. Well, we know Labor always rants about the reduction of the top marginal rate from 60 per cent to 49 per cent, yet Labor still collects more income tax in real terms than the Fraser government ever did. Why is that? Bracket creep is the answer, as it always has been. Many middle income earners are now in the highest tax bracket. Labor's cuts to the marginal tax rates were removed by stealth, as you will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker. Anti-tax avoidance and evasion measures have been taken to ludicrous degrees, when the most simple method of limiting avoidance is, and always was, a goods and services tax. A goods and services tax would force many tax dodgers to start declaring their real level of income, thereby allowing the government to get off the back of honest taxpayers. Labor's tax system is definitely not simpler, and it is in no way fairer. Shifting huge wads of the cost of compliance on to employers may be electorally clever but economically it is disastrous. As a partial consequence, the objective of not stifling investment, growth and jobs has been a farcical failure.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Mr Nehl)Order! I draw the attention of the gentlemen on my left to standing order 57 and ask that they pay the speaker with the call the courtesy of observing it.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Real tax reform, encompassing a GST, or a broad based retail sales tax, would better achieve an increase in national savings, investment and economic growth. As for limiting the negatives for welfare recipients, as claimed a little over 10 years ago by the present Prime Minister, a GST or retail sales tax can be introduced, with welfare recipients receiving compensation, of course. However, the introduction of a GST would be a bonus to those on welfare because it would better provide an environment for them to get out of the welfare poverty trap in so many cases. To put it lightly, this government has totally failed to grasp the real reforms needed to provide a simpler, fairer and more equitable tax system. Of Labor's 10 years of so-called tax reform, the Financial Review of 15 September 1995 had this to say in an editorial: Australia's taxation system stands as probably the most all encompassing symbol of what has been both good and bad about the Labor Party's long period of power at the federal level. In the same way, the tax summit in Canberra 10 years ago epitomises both its initial enthusiasm for reform and its increasing unwillingness to embrace those changes where the electoral equation seemed uncertain. With tax, the upshot is a system which contains a number of intelligent initiativesand they refer to dividend imputation and capital gains taxone notorious fiasco (the FBT) and a huge omission (a consumption tax). Ten years ago, the present Prime Minister saw the merits of a consumption tax, yet in 1993 he actively campaigned against a measure he knew to be for the national good. Because Labor has botched tax reform and made meaningful reforms politically unacceptable, we are now stuck in a time warp, trying to simplify current tax laws. Yet even in this endeavour, Labor is incapable of doing the job properly. The primary goal of tax simplification should be to make the law easier to understand, reduce the cost of compliance and bring logic and rationale into the tax system. In this, Labor has failed. Labor is not prepared to examine policy issues which must be rectified if the tax system is to be simplified. The Financial Review in the editorial which I referred to a moment ago conclud-d by saying: What is needed now, a decade after the tax summit, is not more talking, but rather the will to tackle the major tax issues which remain outstanding. While these include the need for a common sense review of FBT, by far the most important is the need to start laying the public relations groundwork for the eventual introduction of a broadly based consumption tax ... Until this is done there will be little scope for a proper, and long overdue, restructuring of our onerous income tax scales. The editorial in the Australian on that momentous date of 19 September, celebrating 10 years of Labor's failure, said: Tax reform is notoriously difficult to achieve. It always will be difficult, no matter how apparently propitious the moment for introducing reforms might be. But the distortions are getting worse and the pressure to reform will only build. The most obvious target for reform, as the growing number of nations that have adopted it will testify, is in the area of broad-based indirect taxation. We know that a broad based tax system is off the agenda because of the way Labor behaved during the last election. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr THOMSON
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Wentworth) (6.07 p.m.)I am sorry I was not present to hear the entirety of the remarks by my friend the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) but I did catch the last topic he discussed-a broad based consumption tax. May I say forthwith and with some alacrity that that is not a subject that I intend to touch upon in my remarks this afternoon. I note the presence of my good friend the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) at the table. When I spoke on an FBT cost of compliance bill a couple of sitting weeks ago, I began my remarks by saying it is hard to imagine anything more depressing than a tax bill. I can think of other depressing things around this parliament, such as the salad bar in the members' dining room and the answers that we are sometimes forced to listen to at question time from some of the more narcotically boring members of the government front bench. There are certainly many other equally maudlin prospects but a tax bill is probably about the worse. Our tax system is embodied in the monstrous Income Tax Assessment Act, the first volume of which I have with me this afternoon. It is really now not so much a matter of a grimace of horror but a matter of black humour. It has become so complex and so far beyond the comprehension of ordinary Australians, be they individuals striving to earn income in some field or workers for a large corporation, that resort to expensive and certainly very well qualified advisers is really the only answer these days if you have a problem with the tax office. I believe it is really so complex that perhaps we could say that the tax act itself is one of the chief causes of this country's e-onomic woes. The attitude of the tax office towards this complexity is quite clear: they love it. There is nothing a tax bureaucrat likes more than a good dose of complexity. This was revealed in a startlingly topical article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald, which contained some comments made by a senior Treasury official, the head of the federal Treasury's tax policy division. He may hot be from the Australian Taxation Office, but he certainly fits the description of a tax bureaucrat. Mr Ken Henry, in defending the complexity of the tax legislation, said, 'Well, that was what was needed to deal with a complex world.' They have no sympathy whatsoever for the ordinary citizen who suffers the burden of this act and the general taxation scheme-whether it be income tax, fringe benefits tax or sales tax. I believe that the complexity of the scheme keeps those bureaucrats safe in their positions of power and authority. If Mr Henry said 'bad luck' when people complained to him about the complexity of the act, then it is quite clear that there is no sign of a move towards a simpler system under this government. There does not even seem to be any sympathy for the prospect of a simpler system. When we debated the Taxation Laws Amendment (FBT Cost of Compliance) Bill last month, I pointed out that, in seeking to reduce the cost of compliance and the burden on the public, we are actually adding another 60 pages to the legislation. That legislation was 342 pages long when I was born in 1961. It now exceeds 5,000 pages. Enough said about that. I refer back to Mr Henry's comment that, as life is complex, we have to have a complex tax system. During the debate on the cost of compliance bill, I proposed that, as technology changes and the nature and incidence of an employment and earnings grow more complicated as the years pass, the revenue raising means of a government will have to adapt to these changes. The government is choosing a most mechanical and intrusive approach and is enacting highly technical legislation. In the case of the compliance bill, the legislation imposed a liability on the employer. This will necessarily fetter or restrict an employer's or an individual's ability to produce earnings or a return on the capital that they may invest. The employment opportunities and further investment prospects are likewise restricted. That is the true meaning of the cost of compliance. The cost of compliance of any tax system or any part of a tax system goes beyond the monetary penalty and the opportunity cost to the existing taxpayers. Every legislative act or administrative act of government has an effect on the psychology of investment. I describe it simply as the atmospheric effect. Consideration has been given to the atmospheric effect caused by our tax system in a report by a group called the APEC Capital Markets Working Group, whom a newspaper article describes as 'a group of business and financial market leaders who will lobby the Australian government to strengthen efforts for Australia to become a major financial centre in this region'. It is something that you hear quite a lot about in the government's rhetoric. This group of business and financial market leaders wrote a report which they presumably gave to the government. They pointed out quite clearly that Australia's tax system has a number of competitive disadvantages, including an international reputation for being unsympathetic to regional headquarters, and is considered to be a significant disincentive. There is really no point in saying anything further after hearing those comments from that group. You have to consider the position of the taxpayer-whether it be a corporate taxpayer or an individual-and how that person is treated by the tax office. Only yesterday I had a telephone call in my office from a constituent who was having his first tax audit. It sounded as though he was about to have his first child or his first dip in the sea at Bondi Beach. He was a little bit nervous about how the tax office was going to treat him, and he probably had good reason to be nervous about it. In June, the Australian Financial Review published an article by a former officer of the tax department, Mr Douglas. Mr Douglas is a lawyer who now practises as a partner with one of Sydney's larger law firms. He pointed out that, during his time in the tax office, culture had changed as a result of some rather radical administrative changes. He said that they did not report in a horizontal fashion. The compliance officers, the lawyers within the tax office, are the doves. The hawks are the accountants, the bean counters, who in a rapacious fashion are out to squeeze every last cent from the taxpayer. The lawyers within the tax office take a more measured approach that emphasises the rights of the taxpayers. In the past, the compliance people had their own little section. The other section of the tax office, which dealt with individuals, large corporations, small corporations, rural producers and any other special working groups, would go to see the compliance group-that is, the lawyers-to check their work as they were carrying out audits. In that sense, there was a nice system of checks and balances on them. This was described as the horizontal style of organisation. For some reason, this was changed to a vertical system. The tax office was reorganised so that each section which dealt with large corporations, small corporations, individuals and so forth had their own little in-house compliance officer or officers. They were much smaller in number. This meant that the burden on them to check the work of the hawks, the people carrying out the audits, was so great that they began, through no fault of their own, to fail in their task. Mr Douglas also told me that working in the same physical environment with the compliance officers over in the corner of the office made them feel somehow intimidated when making decisions or giving advice that was adverse to the interests of the hawks. If one of the audit officers came up with a proposal to issue a draft ruling that would be adverse to the interests of the taxpayer and he was very keen to do this, the compliance officer with whom he might go out and have a beer on Friday or with whom he might socialise-like any other Australian office, people who work together occasionally spend time together outside work-might feel a little less inclined to perform his duties in a strict fashion. He may say to the audit officer, 'Look, I think you're going a bit far with the your proposed draft ruling.' He would go soft on it. In that sense, the hawks were getting their way. The reason given for this change in the culture of the tax office was enormous pressure on the tax office's revenue raising activity. That is clearly driven by a very loose fiscal discipline here in Canberra. From the top down, enormous pressure is placed on the tax office to raise as much revenue as possible with no regard to fairness. This reorganisation has given ascendancy to the hawks within the office. There is much to be done after the next election in reforming the way the tax office behaves when it deals with our citizens. No doubt after the election the government of this nation will change and a more sensible approach to this monstrous piece of legislation and its administrative underpinnings will be taken. In speaking to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1995 before us this afternoon, I would like to make a few remarks about the provisions regarding the pay-a.,-youearn tax system and the peculiar proposal for a system of tax vouchers, which is really a cloak for a system of granting the tax office free loans. I would like to also speak about some provisions to do with the superannuation guarantee levy and reiterate a few other things about the absurdity of the tax act. Regarding the PAYE tax system, it seems as though this amendment is just another burden imposed on small and medium businesses. The existing law, as I understand it, says that companies which remit pay-as-youearn tax deductions of under $5 million per month are obliged to remit them once a month. So the cost to their business of making the calculations and the bank charges that they will pay on that occur once a month. Suddenly, this threshold is to be reduced to $1 million. This will of course require many more companies to send in that money twice a month. For some of them, it will go close to nearly doubling the cost of performing that transaction. Again, the explanatory memorandum gives the reason for this. It is all because the government needs another $275 million in the 1995-96 year of income. There you have it-the loose fiscal discipline in Canberra working again to cause a· bigger burden on the poor old innocent taxpayer. The consequences of this grab for more money in this climate are serious. They really should not be underestimated because the prospects for next year, despite the rhetoric from the government front-bench-we have grown used to it and we take little notice of it these days-are looking rather grim .. I point out to the House that the ABS has a relatively new indicator. It is called the composite leading indicator. It is composed of eight different indicators: economic statistics, which have some element of predictive capacity to them, and others that have great bearing on the prospects for Australia's real GDP movements-things like housing finance, the changes in the United States' real GDP and of course real interest rates, which are inverted in the calculation. The ABS put this together and then recalculated the figures going back to 1971. They do it quarterly. The significant thing is that in the June quarter of this year the index suffered its greatest quarterly fall since the June quarter of 1974. For the June quarter of 1995 this composite leading indicator suddenly falls off a cliff, as it does for 1974. If this indicator is a reliable guide to future movements in our own GDP-in the next, say, four quarterswe can say that it is not unreasonable to expect that our real GDP in the second or third quarter next year may be close to even negative. Despite all the rhetoric, if this leading indicator has the predictive capacity that the ABS claims it does-they are a reasonably conservative lot when it comes to describing the power of their statistics-and the indicator has really fallen as much as or a little more than it did in 1974, I would need to be convinced that we are not going to have negative growth about this time next year. Tomorrow morning we have an opportunity to ask questions of the Governor of the Reserve Bank when he makes an appearance before the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration of this House. I look forward to taking the opportunity to ask him what he thinks is the significance of this sudden fall off a cliff. If you look at the elements within it individually, you will see that the movement in real interest rates caused by the bank's hiking of the official discount rate about this time last year has made a large contribution to that. But, generally speaking, I would just like the question answered. Here we are debating another depressing tax bill-a bill which will raise another $275 million for the government in this year of income in an atmosphere which is looking increasingly grim. In this climate, I would describe imposing an extra burden on small and medium businesses as lunacy. I would like to talk a little about the proposed tax voucher system, which I understand is intended to replace the old tax stamp system. This sets up a scheme whereby selfemployed people, or non-employee taxpayers-those brave individuals who are out on their own in the economy trying to earn a dollar

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: In decreasing numbers. Mr THOMSONIn decreasing numbers. Never more so than in the marginal seats of this country. These include all those tradesmen who ply their trade in the building industry and who have suffered so grievously during the past year since those official discount rate hikes have pushed the building industry off a cliff. They are the sorts of people whom this new scheme of tax vouchers is aimed at. The scheme says they can trot along to the tax office and purchase a voucher issued by the tax office. This means that purchasers will get a credit against their tax liability when they submit their return at the end of the year. It seems to me that this new system is something of a nonsense because the purchase of these vouchers will not give any relief from provisional tax. Taxpayers would be better off putting the same money into an interest bearing account at a bank. Despite the awful fees and charges that such a depositor would suffer, that would certainly be better than making what is in effect an interest free loan to the gentlemen in the tax office and the lunatics who occupy the front bench of this government. I hope that is not an unparliamentary term.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I think it might be. You might just withdraw it. Mr THOMSONI withdraw it for the time being.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: No; you will withdraw it. Mr THOMSONI withdraw it absolutely and say the 'misguided gentlemen who occupy the front bench of the government'. What is the point, then, of setting up a scheme whereby you are making what is, in effect, an interest free loan to the federal government? The net effect of it is that the Treasury will get this year's revenue a little earlier but still collect the provisional tax. I think that is just a sneaky little tactic. There is much more in this bill to cover but, with the little time left for me to speak, there is certainly no time to do that in any detail. I point out to the House that I have been looking through the table of provisions of the first volume of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I have tried to look up a provision that deals with infrastructure bonds - because there has been some discussion among the branch members of my party in my electorate about infrastructure development in and around Sydney. Mr Rocher interjecting Mr THOMSONThere has been a discussion about many other topics, none of which encompass a broad based consumption tax, my honourable friend, but in particular deal with infrastructure bonds. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: My colleague the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Thomson) was just getting started, and he was warming up nicely with some encouragement from the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). Here we have another raft of tax legislation. The government seems committed to increasing the size of the tax legislation willy-nilly, day after day, week after week. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is poorly drafted. I cannot remember, and I do not know whether the member for Curtin can, a single piece of legislative change that has come into this House that has not been amended by the government when the House has considered it. I do not think we have had one tax bill that has not been amended with the government's own amendments before it has been passed by the parliament. It is poor drafting, sloppy processing and poor administration, and my colleagues acknowledge that. It does not seem to worry the government because, after all, they do not have to pay for drafting mistakes. It is the taxpayer who pays for drafting mistakes. The cost of collecting tax does not appear to worry the government either. The government can increase willy-nilly the compliance cost and not be worried about it in the slightest. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) covers a range of things such as the changes affecting control of foreign companies; changes affecting dividends paid out for capital accounts; extending the accelerated depreciation for ships; a number of changes to the collection of tax, including reducing the twice-monthly remitter threshold from $5 million to $1 million; increasing the infrastructure borrowing rebate to 36 per cent in line with company tax; and changes to the superannuation guarantee system, including allowing employees to elect that employers not make superannuation guarantee contributions and allowing the notional earnings base to be used to calculate superannuation contributions-all very interesting and burdensome for the Australian community. Because this is a money bill I want to talk about the debt and where Australia is economically. It is a disastrous situation. Our high foreign debt is limiting every capacity that Australia has. The government keeps saying that it is not borrowing much overseas. In fact, about half of the total Australian debt is government

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Nothing like it.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Look at your statIstIcs. Half of it is government. You do not know the facts. Half of the total borrowings in Australia-public and private-is government. If you look at your outgoings in your own budget, you will find that about $9 billion is going out just to pay the interest charges. That is almost the size of your education or defence budget. And y-u are content to live with that! If one looks at the fact that we are running a current account deficit of about $26 billion a year, one could say that we are actually borrowing funds overseas-we have to fund that deficit somehow-to pay our interest charges. The worse type of management a nation can have is one which borrows to fund its debt. There is only one place where that finishes up. I think Mr Micawber mentioned on a number of occasions the 'grave circumstances' - g-r-a-v-e. Those are the circumstances you have put Australia in. The Australian debt currently stands at over $180 billion. This is about an eightfold increase since 1983 when the debt was $23 billion. That is the record of the current government. Our total debt-foreign liabilities, which is the debt plus foreign equity in Australian companies, stands at about $260 billion-five times the level of 1985. This is what this Australian government has done to this great nation. The current account crisis, the deficit we have, for 1994-95 was $26.8 billion-the highest annual deficit that Australia has ever run. I do not know how this year is going to finish. The government, with an election on its hands, is likely to blow its predictions right out of the water. Any talk of the country being in surplus next year or the year after is crazy. The ratio of our gross domestic product to our current account deficit, as calculated by the OECD, is a lot worse than Mexico. In 1994 we were about equivalent to Mexico. This year Mexico is way ahead of us. We are just really at the bottom of the list. These are the OECD figures. This is the ratio of our foreign debt to the proportion of our GDP. That is a reasonable relationship to make. Standard and Poor's international currency agency rates Australia 49th out of the 51 countries it surveyed in terms of current account deficit--49th out of 51! No wonder Mr Murdoch had some comments to make about your Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his descriptions of Australia's success. Mr Murdoch does understand what the real needs of Australia are. He does understand the levels of youth employment. The Prime Minister says, 'One of the reasons we've got high youth unemployment is Mr Murdoch is not getting involved in our make-work programs where the taxpayer funds a company to take on employees.' That is not a solution which is a workable solution. Australia has been left behind by many other countries in addressing its deficit. There is the deficit blow-out to 6.6 per cent of GDP. Comparable deficits were recorded by Finland, UK and Canada in 1989. We were at about the same level of deficit as a proportion of GDP as Finland, UK and Canada. In 1995 the OECD projects that these nations will be able to get on top of .their current account deficits. The projections are: Finland, a current account surplus of 1.8 per cent; United Kingdom, a deficit of 0.1 per cent; and Canada, a deficit of 2.2 per cent. All of these performances are far better than Australia's. But the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Prime Minister fail to acknowledge any of it. We have had discussions over the last week or so about whether or not local interest rates are affected by the foreign debt. Of course they are. The Prime Minister-despite all his shoving, skating and weaving-finally had to acknowledge that internal interest rates are affected by our foreign debt. Australia has the equal highest prime rate for corporate in the advanced industrial world. Australia's shortterm three-month interest rate is exceeded only by Italy, Spain and Sweden-all countries that are running a higher deficit regime than Australia. I know that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), who is at the table, is from the left side of his party. He has a compassionate heart and has a real wish to see those in need, the battlers of Australia, taken care of and supported. He would not be supporting the ripping down of homes in the Sydenham area by the federal government to make way for airlines. He would not be supporting the processes of battlers being out of work. He would not be naturally supporting those, but he is bound by his ministerial oath. I understand that. But I would have thought he would be working very hard and encouraging the government to work very hard to reduce the debt so that opportunities to employ in Australia were greatly increased. When one looks at the impact of the debt on interest rates, one just has to quote the budget papers. The 1995-96 budget papers; on page 2.36, states: ... a high level of foreign borrowing relative to GDP can impose costs on an economy by making it more vulnerable to external shocks and by interest rate premia on borrowings. It is there in the budget papers and it has been there all the time. The Treasurer tried to avoid the fact that he knew it was there. In the 1993 report to the government on national savings, Vince Fitzgerald, the government's own employed consultant to look at savings and the direction the government was taking, said: We need to pay higher interest rates to compensate for the risks inherent in our high external debt. So it is there. We are paying much more for houses, cars and consumables of every sort because of the high interest regime the government has. Large current account deficits place upward pressures on rates. The Prime Minister jacked up interest rates in 1989 to rein in the current account deficit. Mortgage interest rates reached 18 per cent and led to the recession that we had to have. I guess at that time it was of no surprise to Australians to hear the Prime Minister make the claim that an economy which cannot travel at four per cent without spilling over into imports should give the game away and that we ought to be able to run this economy at least at four per cent. It is not running at four per cent growth now. It is dropping off. And look at the mess that is still there. When the recovery got under way the Prime Minister still kept interest rates high to stabilise the current account in that way. The Commonwealth has been the prime driver in so many ways of Australia's deteriorating foreign debt. Vince Fitzgerald said: In short, the foreign debt position of Australia, and for that matter the current deficit, which is dominated by interest payments on the past accumulated debt, are attributable only to a small extent if at all to private sector net borrowing; rather they are essentially attributable to government and, indeed, to a significant extent represent borrowing to finance public consumption rather than investment, at least at the Commonwealth level. So what has that done? That has forced Australian borrowers off the Australian market and onto overseas markets. That has been detrimental to the nation as well. It has been the Australian management of it: not only has the debt been created by the government in its own thirst for funds to finance its own consumer programs, but also it has had the raising double whammy of forcing Australian companies offshore where they have had to borrow and where the government, of course, is paying a higher rate for money that it is borrowing-which means a higher interest rate the Australian taxpayer at one time will have to return. Mr Willis claimed at one stage-and I heard him say this: One of the most stupid, ridiculous assertions that has ever been made by an opposition is ... that foreign debt means that there is a higher interest burden on ordinary Australians. He said that in the House of Representatives on 21 September. One can run through those who disagree with Willis

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Mr Nehl)Order! I am loath to interrupt the flowing eloquence of the member for Mitchell, but I would be pleased if he could refer to the Treasurer by his correct title.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Yes. One wonders whether in fact he is Treasurer only in title rather than in both title and action. But that is his title and he should be referred to by his title. He is the Treasurer of Australia. But one wonders whether, with statements like this about interest rates, he really understands what he is doing. Those who disagree with the Treasurer are the Prime Minister; Vince Fitzgerald; Allan Ostler, Chief Economist of the National Bank; Professor MCKibbin of the ANU; Steven Morling, Reserve Bank Research Economist; and Robert Subbaraman, Reserve Bank Research Economist. The Prime Minister contradicted his Treasurer and, on 20 September 1995, in Orange-and I was in Orange on the day before he was there-said: We must work to deal with the problem of the current account deficit so that we're not paying too Ithigh a premium on world interest rate markets. There it is from the Prime Minister. It does affect our Australian economy, it is serious and it is the thing that is worrying more Australians than anything else: the high debt and what it is costing them-the amount of the farm we have had to sell off, the amount of the Australian economy we have had to sell to overseas interests to balance the books.

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: You want to sell the lot.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: No, Minister. You have changed the Foreign Investment Review Board rules since you have been in office. You have allowed more of Australia to be sold. Before you came into office, you used to be able to invest in Australia if it was of benefit to Australia. But now you just say that, if it is of no detriment to Australia, you can do anything you like. This is the Labor Party that is so nationalistic! We do not make any claims about the goals that you have made claims about. What I am pointing to is the hypocrisy of the Labor Party: they have no beliefs at all, except in saying anything or doing anything to hold office or to get themselves into office. Nothing could be a better illustration of the attitudes of the Australian Labor Party, in regard to the economy and their care for their fellow Australians, than Mr Keating's own words on the current account matter. Going right back to 1986 I will give about 10 quotes from the Prime Minister over a period of 10 years. You would think the Australian press would have learnt that he cannot be trusted on these issues. But let me read from 14 May 1986. There the Prime Minister said: Australia is so undisciplined, so disinterested in its salvation and its economic well being ... the only thing to do is to slow the growth down to a canter . .. Then, you have gone. You are a banana republic. That is the famous banana republic statement on the current account deficit. On 2 July 1987 he said, 'What we are saying is the worse is over.' That was about the current account deficit in 1987. That was a laugh, wasn't it? The Prime Minister, on 13 May 1988, said: that is, the policywill continue lower the current account deficit and, in doing so, restore Australia's sovereignty ove· its own affairs. This was years before the current high level total debt of $260 billion, or a net debt of $180 billion. On 27 November 1989, he said: The current account problem is created by the new investment. It is not created by the government's incapacity to deal with the underlying current account deficit. On 16 February 1990, he said: Too much of a good thing can still be too much of a good thing. I mean, basically the glass is too full and the effervescence is spilling over the sides and that effervescence is the current account and inflation. Come back to November 1990. He said: This is a recession that Australia had to have. On 3 March 1991, he said: The current account deficit remains Australia's most pressing pressure. I think we have to be quite clear about that. Over a period of five years it has still remained the problem. From the banana republic statement of 1986 to the 3 March statement in 1991, it is quite clear that the Prime Minister has achieved nothing in five years. On 21 March 1991, the Prime Minister said: The worse is now behind us. The government established the strategy to deal with the current account deficit and inflation and has stuck to it and is succeeding. On 19 April 1991, he said: We are looking at establishing the current account deficit well below the proportion of GDP reached in the late 1980s. It has got worse. It is far worse than the current account deficit in Mexico. As we have learned today, Finland, the UK and Canada have solved their problems, but Australia's problems are still bad. The Prime Minister was making those promises in 1991-'lt is time we fixed it up' and 'It is well on the way to being fixed up'. On 26 February 1992, he said: Labor's plan for the next four years will recreate over 800,000 jobs without increasing the current account deficit. On 30 July 1992, he said 'So you know, success breeds success' - in terms of the current account. On 2 December 1992, he said: I sayan economy that can't travel at four per cent without spilling over into imports should give the game away, we ought to be able to run this economy at four per cent at least. On 4 July 1995, he said: As the economy gets back to a sustainable rate of growth, so too will we see a subsidence in the current account deficit. In other words, we have got the position covered. That is 10 years of absolute failure, year after year making a statement admitting that failure and not being able to deal with the most horrific problem that is worrying every Australian. It has increased our costs. It has meant that we have had to sell far more of our assets than was needed. It has meant that Australians are not in control of their own destiny-and that is the most worrying item that concerns Australians in New South Wales, Queensland, Western Australia and all those parts of Australia where the Labor Party will lose seats at the next election.

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Here we are again, debating yet another government tax bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1995. The 4,000 or so pages in the tax legislation are not enough. We are about to get another great stack of new regulations, new taxes, new burdens on the Australian people. The facts are that this government just goes on a taxing binge every time the budget is presented to the Australian people. In the last coalition budget-sadly, far too long ago-the total tax receipts were $40.7 billion. In the budget presented to us this year from the Labor government they are $124.4 billion. So the Australian taxpayers have lamented each budget as new and more severe tax measures have been imposed upon the Australian people. All this comes from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who told us in November 1992, 'What I am promising is not to put up tax'-I repeat: what I am promising is not to put up tax. Of course, every budget since then, following on all those prior to that, has massively increased taxes. In the current budget individual income tax is up 13.6 per cent; the Medicare levy up 18.4 per cent; company tax up 15.4 per cent; super funds tax up 13.2 per cent; fringe benefits tax, 4.4 per cent, after being up 131 per cent in the previous budget; other income taxes up 8.3 per cent; sales tax up 22.3 per cent; fuel excise, 7.7 per cent-in fact, fuel excise has increased seven-fold in the life of the Labor government; other excise duties up 8.8 per cent; and customs duties up 3.2 per cent. So the list goes on and on. These enormous increases are really costing Australians dearly. It is not just business that pays taxes, it is not just rich people that pay taxes; every ordinary Australian pays them every day. A bite of every pension payment, a bite of every disability pension and a bite of every welfare benefit goes to paying taxes-the government's indirect tax regime. At the last federal election there was so much criticism of the coalition's GST proposals. But it is interesting to note that Labor is now collecting more from the indirect taxes the coalition was going to abolish than the coalition had aimed to collect from its GST. All of that has happened without any of the compensatory measures that the coalition was proposing. There are none of the alternative benefits that were going to be provided and none of the benefits to the national economy. Just on a raw tax basis, Labor is now collecting more from its sales taxes, its fuel excise and the like than the coalition would have collected from the GST. So there is no doubt about who are the big taxers in Australian history: it is the Labor government. In spite of all of the talk about simplification and tax cuts, the fact is that the burden gets greater each year and the complexity gets greater each year. That is one of the real tragedies of our current tax system. When the Income Tax Assessment Act became law in 1936, it contained just 126 pages. It had grown to 1,328 pages by 1983. So in its first almost 50 years it gained something like 1,200 pages. But in the life of the Labor government the Income Tax Assessment Act has grown close to 4,000 pages. In just 13 years, it has more than trebled in length. In all, Australia now has more than one million words of tax law spread over 7,000 pages. According to figures provided to a Senate estimates committee last year, it now costs more than $1.1 billion just to operate the Australian Taxation Office. That is almost four times what it cost a decade ago. The ATO now pays $213 million a year for leasing and maintaining its offices and is the biggest rent payer in most Australian capitals. At the time of that committee inquiry, the ATO had almost 18,000 permanent staff working in 25 separate offices to collect our tax. All of that cost is basically borne by the victims of the Australian tax system. A recent study by the Australian Tax Research Foundation found that it cost business $123 for every $100 of company tax it pays to the federal government. It will cost companies around $4 billion in hidden calculation and other compliance costs to pay next year's company tax bill. The costs in Australia are almost 11 times higher than those in the United Kingdom. For the majority of companies, the cost of compliance is higher than the amount of corporate tax that they pay. That is an incredible indictment on the current system. It costs most companies more in compliance costs than in actual tax. When we have a system of that nature, is it any wonder that business complains about the complexity of our tax law? This legislation fails to address those sorts of problems. I think the National President of the National Tax Agents Association, Ray Regan, summed it up well recently when he said: Complex unworkable laws produce unfavourable tax audit statistics. It is a statement of fact that at least 74 per cent of all businesses which are audited have their returns amended as a result of the tax investigation. Fringe benefits tax almost constantly identifies an error rate of between 80 and lOOper cent of returns audited, resulting in substantial additional tax payable and returns being amended for up to four years. In fact, in 1992 the ATO conducted 104,000 audits on individuals which collected $84.5 millionplus in additional revenue, resulting in each taxpayer having to pay back an average of $900 each . . . our current tax system is repeatedly producing unacceptably high audit amendments that not even the tax office can disguise as simply targeting those taxpayers where mistakes were most likely to be made.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Is that Ray Regan?

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: It is. If you were listening, you would have known it was Ray Regan. It is a pity that you do not listen to what he says and do something about it. He continued by saying: The fact is many taxpayers come out of a tax audit with a very bad taste in their mouths, believing it was simply impossible to comply with existing legislation which has seen the legislative services division of the ATO writing such complex rules which now compel more and more specialist cells to be established in the ATO, because not one tax auditor could possibly understand the maze of legislation that exists. The Taxation Office cannot understand the maze of legislation which exists, but the poor, individual taxpayers are expected to. The last Tax Pack was crammed with errors, yet taxpayers who made a mistake were penalised and required to account for every one of their actions. The fact is that the existing law has become unreasonably complex and impossible for ordinary Australians to understand and comply with. It is high time that our tax law was addressed and we looked seriously at simplifying it and achieving an understandable law which people were able to deal with. The fringe benefits tax is the classic example of this. Most people just give up in despair at the complexity they face when trying to adequately fulfil the requirements of the fringe benefits tax law. It is almost impossible to keep the required documentation, so when the tax office comes along most businesses just ask in despair, 'How much do you want?' and, instead of arguing, they pay up and shut up. That is not the way tax law ought to be administered, and it is not the way a responsible government should act. This government continues with its constant binge of tax collection and its constant approach that businesses only exist so they can pay higher and higher taxes to the government and that citizens only earn wages so they can contribute more to the government's coffers so the government can then go on its wild spending programs. I understand that today the government released some kind of a book to chronicle its achievements in government. Frankly, I do not know why they needed a book to do that; a postage stamp would have been absolutely adequate. I have seen a number of books in news agencies which on the outside cover says, 'The complete and unabridged achievements of the Labor government,' but when you open them up you find that every page is blank. I think most people would wish that their tax law had a lot more blank pages. The Labor Party's entire record would be better presented as blank pages than this wonder book that you can now apparently get on the Internet. Labor is attempting to persuade the public that it has actually achieved something worthwhile. A much more worthwhile publication is out now that has on its cover a phrase that would be very well known to members sitting opposite. The front page says, 'This is as good as it gets.' It is a quote from Paul Keating.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Who said that?

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Is the Assistant Treasurer identifying himself with that statement? I understand that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) has. He also thinks this is as good as it gets and it will never get any better. I have to admit that this might be as good as Labor can do and it might be as good as the Prime Minister can do, but it sure ain't good enough for the Australian people. If this is as good as the government can do, it is time they gave it away and let somebody else get on with running the country and achieving worthwhile things for our nation. There are a number of specific matters I would like to address in relation to this legislation. This might seem to be a very small matter, but I think it is one of some significance and importance. Just over a year ago, there was a terrible bus crash in Brisbane which took the lives of a number of my constituents. An inquiry into that bus crash was undertaken-as has happened with many other similar accidents in Australia over recent years-and it was recently completed. In almost all of those inquiries-certainly the inquiry into the crash of the Maryborough bus-it was stated that lives almost certainly would have been saved if passengers in the bus had been wearing seat belts. In fact, the federal and state governments have agreed to make the fitting of lap-sash seat belts compulsory in all new coaches. As new coaches are sales tax free, no sales tax applies to the seats and seat belts fitted to those vehicles. However, there are a small number of existing coaches which can be upgraded to meet the new safety standards with the fitting of new seats and lap sash belts. In cases where the seats and seat belts are retrofitted, incredibly, they attract sales tax at the rate of 22 per cent. Coach operators are not obliged to upgrade their existing vehicles to meet the standards applying to new coaches. They can continue to operate them indefinitely. I am told that the cost of fitting modified seats and lap sash belts to an existing coach is approximately $35,000 per vehicle, a significant amount. The imposition of a 22 per cent sales tax on such an investment is an enormous disincentive for any coach owner to introduce such improved safety measures. The Wide Bay Tours coach that was involved in the accident near Brisbane last year could not have been fitted with these seats. More often than not, the older coaches do not have adequate anchor points. You really need to build these in at the time the coach is constructed. But there are some coaches around, particularly those constructed in recent years, that could have the safer seating fitted. I believe we should encourage the owners of those vehicles to fit the alternative seating. They should not be discouraged by harsh taxation. You really have to question the government's sincerity in endeavouring to upgrade coach safety when it imposes such a heavy tax penalty on those who voluntarily chose to install Australian Standards seats with lap sash seat belts. I first raised this matter with Treasury in November last year. I sent subsequent reminder letters but I still have not been given the courtesy of a reply. Sadly, that is typical of Treasury. It seems to adopt a very arrogant approach to correspondence. It is commonin fact, it is the norm-to wait six, nine or 12 months to get a response to submissions put to it. That is disgraceful, and a discourtesy to members of parliament or anyone else who writes to make a constructive suggestion. This is not a big revenue item. I have already mentioned that a lot of coaches are able to be retrofitted with these sorts of seats. Surely, if even one life was saved, there would be massive benefits to our community. If even one accident victim was less severely injured, the cost returns to the nation would be overwhelmingly realised. I call on the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), who is actually in the chamber on a rare visit, to take this matter on board. I ask him to go back to the letter I wrote to Treasury in November last year, consider it carefully, and make a considered judgment on whether there should be a sales tax concession in these sorts of circumstances. While dealing with sales tax matters, I would like to refer to another anomaly. I had the courtesy of a reply from the Assistant Treasurer on a matter I raised with him initially on 20 June 1994. I finally got a reply on 9 March 1995-about a nine-month turnaround, which is par for the course. Sadly, the answer, when I got it, was no. With this particular matter-another safety matter-it was drawn to my attention that builders' safety cut-out boxes, which are an important electrical safety item, are subject to sales tax when they are a stand-alone item.
