If they were included in a product as part of a larger piece of machinery, the identical item would be sales tax free. Again, it seems to me that the general principle should be that matters essential to safety in the workplacein many cases, things that are compulsoryshould be sales tax exempt. The minister's reply in this instance is really quite extraordinary. He admitted that there was an anomaly and said that there were a couple of ways it could be solved. One would be to exempt all goods of this nature from sales tax-I thought that was a commendable approach-but he was worried about the effects on his budget. He does not look at ways in which the government might be prepared to save money; he prefers to place workers' lives at risk by imposing this ever-increasing sales tax on a product which could help save many people from electrical injury. He suggested that another way out of this anomaly would be to exempt from tax all products that require the safety cut-out box. That is a perfectly noble suggestion except that the minister completed his letter by saying, 'The government does not propose at this stage to change the tax treatment for such items.' He admits it could be done, he admits it is an important safety feature, he admits there is anomaly but he will not do anything about it. Sadly, that is the approach so often taken by the government when anomalies in the current taxation system are drawn to their attention. Our current tax law, for all its complexity and its attempts to stamp out avoidance measures, has become all the more complex and difficult to understand. In the process, every time changes such as those before us tonight are made, a new set of anomalies is created, a new set of distortions is put in place. There needs to be radical reform of the tax system. This government thinks that this is as good as it can get. It is certainly time it stood aside and called the election tomorrow. Then let's get somebody in there who can fix these problems and ensure that our nation has a fairer and more appropriate tax system.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: If we want to talk about reform of the tax system-with a call for it from the opposition-maybe we could get a few clues from them about what sort of tax regime they would want. I see the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) in the chamber. I know he was a bit embarrassed yesterday when he proposed that the GST

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: He let the cat out of the bag.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I said yesterday that he was only saying publicly what others are saying privately. Mr Andrews-Don't misrepresent me, will you?

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I thought I was doing you a favour because I said you were only saying what your leader said a couple of months ago. It is not as if you were out of step with your leader. You were totally in step with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in saying that a GST had not been ruled out. Mr Truss-He didn't say that.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The opposition leader did; that was the headline. They talk about reform of the tax system-they are always calling for it-but there are never any details. Do you notice that about the opposition? It does not matter whether it is a debate on tax, higher education, law and order or social securityyou can go through the gamut of what we debate here in this parliament-they always say that things could be better. They have a slim book over there with our words of our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on it but there is nothing inside. It is empty. Mr Rocher-There's nothing worthwhile saying.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The Independent member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who had to leave the Liberal Party, at least takes some interest in the tax system. I am not asking him to speak for the Liberal Party, because he is no longer a member of it. If he were, I am sure we would get some more detail from him. Sadly, he is an Independent. The previous speaker in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1995, the member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), talked about the fact that this was a high taxing governmentMr Truss-Sure is.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: How come the government in this budget, as a percentage of GDP, will raise $3,500 million less than your leader did when he was last Treasurer. If we had taxes at the same percentage of GDP that the Leader of the Opposition had, we would raise $3.5 billion more this year than he would have raised. So who is the highest taxer? It is the Leader of the Opposition. You talk about the complexity of the tax act; you talk about the number of pages. We used to have a simple tax system once-for the rich, that is. They had a choice of whether they paid it or not. That was when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer. That was a simple tax system: 'Will I pay tax or will I not? I don't think I will pay tax.' That was a simple system. We had a real slim tax act back in those days. We did not have many people in the tax office. And look what happened: all of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. It was not as if the Treasurer of the day was not warned. The tax office was up there begging him to do something about it, but he would not. That is the sort of tax system the Liberals ran the last time they were in government, and here they are preaching to us about how we should run our tax system. There are a number of reasons for the number of pages in the tax act, for it being as voluminous as it is. The simple fact is that we put a lot of decent tax on the books-things like a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax, which the opposition never supported. What about the capital gains tax? Are you going to get rid of it? No. What about the fringe benefits tax? Are you going to get rid of it? No. You are not going to get rid of that one either. You did not support it when we brought it in here, but you have seen over time how decent these taxes are. I know that the only reason you are not getting rid of them is that you cannot afford to. With all of the promises you are going to make in the next election campaign, you actually need the revenue that these taxes bring in. We know that is the real reason you are going to keep them-not out of any sense of decency. We had that debate, and the member for Curtin was here. He was a member of the Liberal Party then and he voted and spoke against them. He said that the sun would not come up tomorrow if we had a capital gains tax. He did not mention the fact that every other country in the world had one. The bottom-of-the-harbour schemes were made possible because we did not have a capital gains tax. You voted against the capital gains tax. And the fringe benefits tax. What a rort! Under the now Leader of the Opposition, if you had the choice why would you take all of your income in cash? You would be a mug. You would pay tax on it. The fringe benefits tax now is a fair tax. We talk about compliance costs, and the previous speaker, the member for Wide Bay, spoke about compliance costs. I know a little about the compliance costs of the fringe benefits tax because, on behalf of the Treasurer (Mr Willis), I went around and spoke to firms about the compliance costs of the fringe benefits tax. We came up with a package, introduced a couple of weeks ago, which slashed the compliance costs of the fringe benefits tax. I remind the House-the member for Menzies was here-about the shadow Treasurer. This shadow Treasurer is a beauty. He goes down to a tax forum in Old Parliament House-the old hairy chest, the big speech: 'I am going to slash the costs of complying with the fringe benefits tax.' What happens? The next day, I introduce a bill to do just and what do we get out of him? We got three little amendments, which he did not even move himself. He left it to the member for Menzies to move them. We saw three little amendments, which did nothing more than tinker with ours. Do not kid us about compliance costs. We have seen how good you are. When the shadow Treasurer talks about tax reform, he has nothing up his sleeve but his arm. We know that now because we gave him the opportunity the day after he said he would slash compliance costs. He had nothing. I made the point before: when these people come around and talk to you about slashing compliance costs on the FBT, about cutting taxes or about doing anything with the tax system, do not believe them. They have nothing in the locker. The other thing I said at the time we were debating the fringe benefits tax was that in most cases it is a voluntary tax. The government does not force firms to give people cars. The government does not force employers to say to people, 'We will give you an aroundthe-world holiday,' or to pay any of the other expenses like a child's education expenses or private health insurance. We do not tell firms to do that. That is something they do themselves voluntarily. So if they are paying the fringe benefits tax, they are doing it because they choose to. Why do they not just cash it out? They would not be in the fringe benefits tax system any more. So do not talk to us about reducing compliance costs or about simplifying the tax system because we know it is all rhetoric. If there was anything you had to do about the taxation system, surely we would have had a glimpse of it by now, apart from the suggestion of the member for Menzies and the Leader of the Opposition that the GST still burns in the old heart of the Liberal Party. There is no doubt about that. The GST is still there. Mr Andrews-No.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: You know. You should 'not shake your head. You walk around here and talk to the guys in the corridors and they all say, 'That GST was a beautiful thing. We just didn't sell it properly.' Given the chance, you that would put it back in again tomorrow. The last thing I will say about the taxation system is that you talk about high taxes. We have actually reduced John Howard's 60c to 47c and the 30c to 20c. That is always forgotten. What about 30c reduced to 20c? You do not think that helps the battlers? And we collect $3,500 miIIion less tax than John Howard did as a percentage of GOP. So there you are. Lastly, you quoted Ray Regan. Anything Ray Regan has to say about Tax Pack or about the complexity of the tax laws is done rules. out of vested interest. Ray Regan has a vested interest in making sure that people out there think we have a tax system which is just too insurmountable to tackle. He would like you to think that the Tax Pack was riddled with errors. You did not quote the tax ombudsman, but did you see what the tax ombudsman had to say about Ray Regan's complaints? He said they were basically baseless. Do not worry about Ray Regan. Ray Regan 1992. will whip up a storm about Tax Pack. If we had not one error in it, he would be out there with a press release. He has the press releases written before we put the Tax Pack out. There is no doubt about that because he has a vested interest in driving people to use accountants. He is the president of the accountants associathe tion, so do not quote Ray Regan to us. We know where he comes from. Let us get back to the biIl. I have had of fun here because I have been responding to some of the most outrageous claims getting from the opposition. I thought I would have to put them in their place. The member for Menzies and the Independent member for Curtin complained that the CFC amendments would have a retrospective effect. I remind members that the CFC provisions are antiavoidance measures. The proposed amendments will simply overcome a weakness that has been exploited by parties seeking to escape accruals taxation on income that should be taxed under the CFC measures. The alternatives to their proposed treatment biIl is to defer the commencement of the amendments by a year. That would allow all of these activities to flourish for another and we are not going to do it. There was also some debate about the Superannuation Guarantee Act, about the changes that apply for reconstructions after the date of effect; that is, 1 July 1992. I am informed that the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia suggests early application of the amendments on the basis that the Treasurer's December 1991 information paper canvassed successor scheme restructuring. Many things are canvassed in papers but subject to submissions, discussion and review. So it was with possible successor scheme The bill introduced in parliament on 2 April 1992 did not provide for employers to continue to contribute under a pre-1991 earnings base if they changed funds. It provided no successor scheme rule and parliament showed no intention of providing for such a rule in its consideration and passage of the bill which became the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 with effect from 1 July Employers who restructured their superannuation schemes before 28 June 1994 did so in the knowledge that the law required them to use the standard ordinary time earnings base after the restructure. True, the possibility of a successor fund rule was discussed before law was made, but the law foreshadowed when it was introduced before the date for which it was to apply included no such rule. Until the Treasurer's statement of 28 June a bit 1994, no employer had any reason to expect to keep a lesser earnings base after restructurwe are ing superannuation funds. Employers who bought a business or business assets and transferred the associated employees had no reason at all to expect to keep a lesser earnings base on the former employer's use for those employees. Not the December 1991 information paper, the April 1992 bill, or the parliament's consideration of it suggested such a possibility. These amendments led employers to avoid the administrative cost of changing the earnings base for in the their superannuation contributions. The amendments apply from 1 July 1995 for restructures after the Treasurer announced year these changes on 28 June 1994. Restructures before that time have already incurred the cost of changing to the standard base ordinary time earnings and restructures before that time were made with no reasonable expectation of going back to a lesser measure for superannuation contribution. For this reason, these amendments apply only in relation to restructures occurring after the Treasurer's announcement. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Consideration in Detail Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: by leave-I move opposition amendments Nos 1 and 2: (1) Schedule 1, page 7, item 20, omit "ending after 30 June 1995" substitute "commencing after 30 June 1995". (2) Schedule 1, page 9, item 21, at the end of proposed section 461 add the following subsections: " '(6) For the purposes of subsection (3), "transfer" means the movement of funds, whether by accounting entry or otherwise, where the company, in making the transfer, had the intention of facilitating the distribution to shareholders amount or amounts which would otherwise represent a distribution from a disqualifying account.' '(7) An amount transferred from a disqualifying account to a non-disqualifying account which occurs pursuant to an order of the court under the Corporations Law shall not be taken to give rise to a credit under (3) above in the company's notional disqualifying account.'" The first of the amendments to which I refer seeks to replace words 'ending after 30 June 1995' with 'commencing after 30 June 1995'. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has already alluded to the reason. It involves a matter of retrospectivity. Let me say at the outset I have no objection to the intention of the clause to come to grips with avoidance practices. I made that abundantly clear in my speech on the second reading. This matter of retrospectivity has been raised by representatives of concerned taxpayers-notably, but not exclusively, the Corporate Tax Association. I have covered many of my reasons in my speech in the second reading debate so I will not traverse the whole raft of those. On the matter of the changes affecting the tainted income of controlled foreign companies, CFCs, there is indeed a retrospective element. I think the Assistant Treasurer has acknowledged that in summing up the second reading debate. It applies to companies whose financial year, or tax years, if you prefer, did not end on 30 June 1995. The explanatory memorandum states-and I will go over that again: . . . the amendments will clarify that the Commissioner of Taxation may make adjustments, reflecting arm's length values, to amounts used in determining whether a CFC has passed the income test. I regret that the Assistant Treasurer, for whatever reason, was not here during my speech on the second reading but I am sure he has got the gist of it from the advisers. The problem is that the government amendment, as it now stands, will be applied retrospectively for accounting periods ending after 30 June this year. It is therefore axiomatic that part of the relevant tax year to attract this burden occurs before 30 June 1995 and therefore becomes taxable for that part of the tax year prior to 30 June last. Therefore, the measure is applicable of an from 1 July 1995 and, as a consequence, it will in some cases have a retrospective impact on the attributable income of CFCs. The amendment I am proposing to clause 20 of schedule 1 will ensure that no company which has a statutory accounting period other than one which involves the end of a financial year on 30 June will be affected by the application of the new tainted income rules. I want to stress that not many companies do not wrap up their tax years or financial years on dates other than 30 June each year. Therefore, there is not much revenue involved in this. It is unquantifiable, I guess, but there is very little involved in this. That just makes it even more important to me that there should be an absence of retrospectivity and there is really no excuse for not treating taxpayers equitably. It is only fair. Remember that it has only limited application. Because it has only limited application, it is not worth breaching a principle of abhorrence of retrospectivity which we should hold if we value certainty under the law. My proposal is only fair because, as the bill now stands, a company has, for example, a statutory accounting period ending on 30 September 1995, the tainted income provisions of this tax amendment bill becoming applicable from 1 October 1994-that being the beginning of that particular accounting period. There is no need for revenue or other reasons. There is a good case to be made out on equity grounds for accepting this amendment. I just want to finish by saying that presence of retrospective legislation does undermine certainty, credibility and fairness in the tax system. Retrospectivity is a denial of natural justice, in my view, and a repudiation of fairness in that system. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The government will not be supporting either of these amendments. The first amendment, as I said in my closing comments, will defer the start of the CFC measures by a full year and that would allow the people who avoid the CFC to continue to do that for another year. For that reason we are not going to do it. Turning to amendment No.2, government amendments Nos 3 and 4 will address certain transfers pursuant to a court order but only where there is no arrangement to pay a dividend from the amounts transferred. It would not be appropriate to allow dividends from amounts transferred from disqualifying accounts to be rebatable or frankable, even if they were transferred pursuant to a court order. This is because these dividends could enable the reduction of taxable capital gains by corporate tax holders and franking credit trading. Moreover, under the proposed new Corporations Law, transfers from disqualifying accounts will not have to be made pursuant to a court order. Therefore, the proposal by the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) would not be effective under the new Corporations Law regime.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I will not delay the time of the House long because I spoke about this matter in my speech on the second reading. I just wish to repeat, without rehearsing the argument at length, that the opposition has sympathy for the amendment which has been moved by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) because, as he pointed out, it does have an element of retrospectivity and it does adversely affect at least a number of companies, as the Corporate Tax Association has pointed out in its submissions. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has really advanced no good reason why these particular amendments should not be accepted. Amendments negatived.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: by leave-I move government amendments Nos 1 to 7: (1) Schedule 1, page 8, item 21, after proposed paragraph 46H(I)(a), insert the following paragraph: "(aa) an account consisting of shareholders' capital (as defined in section 61 of the Life Insurance Act 1995) in relation to a statutory fund of a life company (both within the meaning of that Act);". (2) Schedule 1, page 8, item 21, omit proposed paragraph 46H(1)(c), substitute the following paragraph: "(c) a reserve to the extent that it consists of profits from the revaluation of assets of the company that: (i) have not been disposed of by the company; and (ii) if the company is a life company within the meaning of the Life Insurance Act 1995-are not assets of a statutory fund (within the meaning of that Act) of the company.". (3) Schedule 1, page 9, item 21, proposed subsection 461(3), after "non-disqualifying account,", insert "then, except where the transfer is an excluded transfer (see section 46IA),". '(4D) The amount of the capital loss is the smallest of the following: (a) the amount paid in respect of the debt; (b) so much of the debt as the Commissioner is satisfied was taken into account in working out the amount of the denied loss; (c) the amount of the denied loss, reduced by the sum of any capital losses taken by subsection (4C) to have been incurred as a result of previous payments in respect of debts that the Commissioner was satisfied were taken into account in working out the amount of the denied loss.'.". Part IT of schedule 1 will ensure that dividends paid out of share capital and asset revaluation reserves will not be rebatable or frankable. This is an anti-avoidance measure. to The amendments moved to schedule 1 will prevent the anti-avoidance measure from applying to ordinary commercial transactions. Amendment No. 1 provides for the addition of a new disqualifying account in proposed was section 46H of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. This new account will consist of capital held in a statutory fund incurred of a life assurance company and will enable is", the company to transfer share premiums to is statutory funds without triggering adverse tax consequences. Amendment No. 2 will amend proposed section 46H to exclude profits from the revaluation of assets held in the statutory fund a of a life assurance company from the defini(the tion of the asset revaluation reserve disqualifying account. This will prevent adverse tax consequences arising from transactions of life assurance companies undertaken in the ordinary course of business. Amendments Nos 3 and 4 provide that the provisions of the bill will not apply to certain transfers called excluded transfers. An excluded transfer is a transfer to offset accumulated losses that are permanent, a transfer from an asset revaluation reserve to reflect a reduction in the value of an asset or a transfer to make a distribution to participating policyholders. These amendments also ensure that if any part of the amount transferred is transferred under an arrangement to pay a dividend or to replace an amount from which a dividend was paid then the amount transferred will not be an excluded transfer. Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Amendments 5 and 6 amend part 3 of schedule 1 of the bill. That part proposes denying net capital losses incurred before a taxpayer's bankruptcy or release from debts under bankruptcy law. The main purpose of these amendments is to treat such taxpayers as incurring a capital loss if they pay a debt that was taken into account in calculating denied net capital loss. The amendment will bring the treatment of net capital losses more into line with the existing law's treatment of revenue losses. Amendment 5 is a technical amendment to ensure that proposed subsection 160ZC(4A) achieves its intended effect. The amendment ensures that the provision will deny only the net capital loss of the year immediately preceding the bankruptcy or release from debts. This will, in tum, ensure that other amendments being made to this part of the bill do not give rise to multiple capital losses for the one payment and that the subsection does not deny earlier years' net capital losses that may already have been offset against capital gains. Amendment 6 will ensure that a taxpayer who makes a payment in respect of the debt will be taken to have incurred a capital loss in the year in which the payment is made if the taxpayer incurred a net capital loss that is denied under proposed subsection 160ZC(4A) and the Commissioner of Taxation is satisfied that the debt was taken into account in working out the amount of the denied net capital loss. This amendment also specifies how to calculate the amount of the capital loss taken to have been incurred because of the payment. Amendment 7 corrects a minor technical error in schedule 3, page 41 of the bill. I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum to the bill.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I will not delay the House for very long in relation to these amendments, except to say that the matters which are the subject of the amendment were also raised and canvassed during my second reading speech. The opposition is not opposing the amendments. Many of them arise from what has been sensibly pointed out as a deficiency in the bill by the Insurance Council of Australia. Our only disappointment is that, once again, the government is bringing in amendments to its own bill here at such a late stage. We hope that in future it will get its drafting of the legislation right in the first place.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: My reason for moving the earlier amendments, which set out to do what I understand the government proposes to do with 21,4 pages of further amendments to the main bill, surrounds an absence of advice from the office of the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) which, despite liaison with it during most of yesterday, did not result in me receiving a copy of the amendments until something like 9.20 this morning, with the bill due to be debated at about 10.00 a.m. I did not get the explanatory memorandum that goes with the amendments until 10.15 a.m. Hence, I moved those amendments. I must say that I like mine better if they have the desired effect because mine happen to be only two paragraphs long, whereas these happen to be 21,4 pages long. I would like some advice and I would really like the Senate to have a look at them if the Assistant Treasurer cannot give me advice as to whether my amendments have been looked at to see whether they achieve the same result. It has been brought to my attention by the Taxation Institute that sometimes a new holding company may apply to a court in order to access reconstruction profits for permission to transfer amounts from the share premium account to retained earnings as part of a corporate reconstruction. The bill as it currently stands, and without my amendment and before the government's amendment is adopted, will deny a company that has received court approval for such a transfer the ability to frank dividends associated with the payment of dividends from such amounts. I have covered that at length in my speech in the second reading debate. The anti-avoidance nature of the legislation should impact on court sanction transfers from share capital and share premium accounts to retained earnings. That is the reason for my concern. I believe that my amendment rectified the problem on the best advice available to me. I repeat the question: do the government amendments do the same? Is that all they do? If so, what is so terribly wrong with my words? I would like an assurance from the government at some stage during these proceedings that somehow 21,4 pages is superior to a couple of paragraphs.

Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Barker) (7.38 p.m.)A few weeks ago a virus deadly to the Australian feral rabbit population escaped from a fenced off quarantine area four miles off the coast of South Australia on Wardang Island. Apparently, it stayed on the island for some time. This virus-the rabbit calicivirus-was being tested by a consortium of the CSIRO, the state DPI and the Animal and Plant to Control Commission of South Australia with, I understand, involvement from the New Zealand government, the NFF, the wool board, the Wool Corporation and so forth. The escape raises the possibility that a vector-perhaps a bush fly or other carrieris able to transfer the virus from one area or another with deadly result to the rabbit. Up till now scientists have only thought that the infection could move from one rabbit to another by very close physical contact. The rabbit, apart from the advent of the European perhaps, has probably turned out to be the most effective imported destroyer of the environment in the history of this country-or probably, for that matter, in the history of any country. No feral animal has destroyed more vegetation and produced erosion and false drought than has the European rabbit in this country for 100 years. Even after the advent of the very successful myxomatosis virus, which has been operating for some 25 years, the numbers of rabbits are still in the tens of millions, and we are failing to handle the increase in those numbers at the present time. There is no doubt that the number of rabbits got to a high of between 600 million and a billion in this country. I remember as a small boy seeing thousands of pairs of ears in the evening light-the ground bare, warren-ridden and pockmarked-and in some cases rabbits were 10 feet up the trees, ringbarking the bullock bushes as they went. Some people earn a living out of rabbits at the present time as a sort of offshoot of this feral population by either shooting or harvesting them in some way or another. That is fine, but in this case all those people in effect are living off the destruction by the rabbit of private property and the destruction of our landscape. There have been some statements in recent times, since this escape, which I would have to say are somewhat irresponsible. I refer to some statements by Dr Hugh Wirth. I know that Hugh Wirth for five or six years has felt, as President of the RSPCA, that we should be using more humane methods. But I would like to point out to him that since that time, five or six years ago, the debate has come a long way. Last year the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales conducted a two-day seminar, the whole purpose of which was to discuss ways of eradication of feral animals in Australia. That was a big move when you think back to the animal liberation debate of only a few years ago. We simply do not have the luxury of not using the good fortune that we may now have found ourselves in. We have found a vector to move this thing around. It is worth pointing out that this RCV virus is in 40 countries. So far it has never proved effective on anything but the European rabbit. Even other wild rabbits in other countries have not been affected, as I understand it. Some people obviously do not know what the current procedure is. As myxomatosis has become less effective, we are back to the old-fashioned methods of poisoning, bulldozing and what have you with the commensurate destruction of the environment in those areas where that is happening. When the disease-as it is now on the mainland-is brought back under CSIRO control, which I hope happens in the near future, I hope that these experiments go on, because after 80 years of all the money and effort that we have put into trying to get rid of our most destructive imported pests it would seem to me to be ridiculous to go in any other direction. There are absolutely no positive results from the rabbit in Australianot in any way whatsoever. (Time expired) Hunter Region

Speaker: Mr HORNE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: This evening I wish to speak about an issue that is dear to my heart, and that is the seven years of neglect of the Hunter region under the Fahey government. I particularly want to talk about facilities for young athletes in the region. Members opposite will probably not be aware that the Hunter has a greater population than Tasmania and contributes more to the GDP of this nation than most areasindeed, more than the whole of Tasmaniayet we do not have a single first-class athletic facility. This is an area that is less than two hours drive from Sydney that is going to host the Olympics in the year 2000. I was very pleased the other day to hear, less than six months after coming to power, Michael Egan, the Treasurer for New South Wales, indicate that he will pursue the establishment of a first-class facility in the Hunter region. It will be a regional facility, and hopefully it will be constructed on surplus railway land in the suburb of Glendale, which is in the electorate of my very good friend and colleague the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). This will mean that athletes in our area who do have a national and state ranking will be able to train seriously towards representing their country at the Olympic Games in Sydney in the year 2000. Athletes such as Katie Hall, Jacquie Munro, Mindy Slomka, Andrew Laverick, Lucas Moffat and Clinton Mackevicius-not all residents of my electorate but people from around the Hunter regionand dozens of others will now have the opportunity to train with first-class facilities, so guaranteeing that they will be competitive and that Australia will be proud of the effort that they put in. Apart from that, the injection of $4 million, plus the availability of land on which this facility can be constructed, provides another avenue for helping young people in the Hunter region-and that is employment. I have already approached officers from the Department of Employment, Education and Training and I have approached my federal colleagues from the Hunter and suggested that we should look, under the Working Nation program, at training programs being involved in the development of these facilities. I am confident it will happen. After all, I am sure the skills that young people will learn as they are constructing these facilities will be in great demand in Australia in the lead-up the Olympic Games. They will be constructtwo ing sporting facilities that will be in high demand, not only by Australian athletes but by athletes who will come here for up to 12 months before the Olympics actually take place to acclimatise themselves to Australian standards. I cannot think of any better place to do than in the Hunter region. Some will go to the Illawarra region. I am aware, Mr Speaker, of your interest in that area. Although it is as good as the Hunter, it is still quite a good area and certainly close to the major competiinclude tion centres. Mr Truss-Is that a reflection on the chair?

Speaker: Mr HORNE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I am sure that the member for Wide Bay would love some to go up there, but I am not sure what will attract them. Mr Neville-A good member of parliament.

Speaker: Mr HORNE

text: Yes, but unfortunately they cholera do not have one. Mr Speaker, I should not respond to interjections. I am looking forward to this. I sincerely hope that it will come to pass. Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Fisher) (7.48 p.m.)Tonight I would like to raise an issue highlighted by the Chairman of the CSIRO, Professor Adrienne Clarke, in her Brodie-Hall address in Perth the night before last. Professor Clarke is one of Australia's leading scientists. She mentioned that Australia risked losing control over one of the most powerful technologies reshaping today's society. She said in her speech that biotechnology is critical to Australia's future in agriculture, the environment and medicine. With the world population predicted to rise to at least 10 billion by the year 2050, biotechnology could transform agriculture and how food is supplied to the world's population. What is biotechnology? In Professor to Clarke's words, biotechnology is based on key pieces of knowledge: firstly, we can grow cells of living organisms, plants, animals, bacteria and fungi in culture in artificial conditions and, secondly, we can isolate the genetic material that defines the nature of these cells and move these genes from one cell to another, known as genetic engineering. that The main impact of this technology has been felt in agriculture and medicine, but applications in fields such as forensic science, securinot ty and mining are becoming commonplace. Some examples of recent developments the first engineered fresh tomato, now being sold in shops in the USA, and tomato paste is being manufactured from engineered tomatoes in the United Kingdom. The UK also has green cheese made genetically, and engineered rennet is marketed in the United Kingdom as green cheese, as it does away with using rennet from the stomachs of baby calves. In the area of medicine, children in developing countries can now receive vaccine for and hepatitis B by eating a genetically engineered banana. On the other side of the coin, biotechnology is all about ownership of that information. There are many controversial issues about patenting, access and equity of that information. Professor Clarke warned that Australia is in very real danger of missing the biotechnology train and being left on the outer, with little control over its developing future. At the moment, rights of advancements and new discoveries made in Australia are usually sold to overseas interests. That means Australia gives up the rights of core technologies and then in the future has to pay the price to use that technology. For example, for every chicken eaten in Australia a royalty is paid to overseas owners. Professor Clarke said it is critical that Australia retain control over its own emerging and core technologies, and that this means substantial investment by Australian business in Australian research and commercialisation of products. She said that Australia has the scientific capacity within CSIRO, the universities and a few fledgling companies to be among the world leaders in a few carefully targeted areas. But Australia is a very small player on the international scene and probably accounts for between two and four per cent of all new knowledge in this area, which is about right for our size. The question is whether Australia has the framework to retain control over the technology we do develop. Professor Clarke says that presently we probably do not. If Australia fails to change its approach to this issue, it runs the very real risk of losing control of this matter. Professor Clarke argued that a structure similar to the one which kick-started the film industry is essential to commercialise Australian discoveries in biotechnology. I ask the government to consider various policies which could encourage Australian companies to invest in Australian technology. Senator Schacht, in his opening address at the last Pacific rim biotechnology conference, said that Australia was aiming to be a leader in innovations, science and advanced industry within the Asia-Pacific region. While Australia has the ability to be a leader in technology, we do not appear to be able to maintain Australian ownership of these rights. Our future is at stake and the government must provide leadership in this area and encourage a climate that is attractive to Australian companies and agencies investing in our technological future. Melbourne Casino

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I think it is entirely accurate to say that all members of this House, irrespective of political differences, are agreed that the totality of Australia Remembers ceremonies, some large, some small, all enable this generation of Australians to pause, to take time, to publicly, openly and with a generosity of spirit say thank you to an earlier generation that had borne the brunt and the sacrifice that is endemic in a nation at war. Such moments are important to our sense of community, to our understanding of why we are and who we are. Over many years, like other citizens of Melbourne, I have participated at dawn ceremonies and ANZAC Day ceremonies. I have been moved to comment on those occasions that, while the ranks grew thinner, the audience grew larger. One aspect of that was the number of younger people, children, who not only attended but increasingly are now participating in those ceremonies. It is equally true that other events on our calendar-Christmas and Good Friday-are occasions when, for the great majority of our citizens, the assertion of spiritual values transcend the material and commercial considerations that are so dominant for the rest of the year. Communities, like man, do not live by bread alone. These events are an essential part of our community and assert our values which are critical to our perceptions of ourselves and our Melbourne community. I am appalled at the fact that the Victorian Premier, with the cosy complicity of his close friends who operate the Melbourne casino, has blithely accepted the proposition that this is the one major business undertaking that must be pennitted to operate on the morning of ANZAC Day, when ceremonies are taking place, and on Good Friday and Christmas Day-days of immense religious significance to members of my community. These are family days. These are days for personal reflections. These are days when 'the money changers have no place in the temple'. I am bound to admit that I do not believe in a casino-led recovery, or in a gambling-led recovery. Gambling does not produce wealth: it redistributes it. For the operators of the casino, it is a redistribution that is immensely profitable for them. For the Victorian government, it is about collecting an indirect tax, a tax that for the most part falls most heavily on those who cannot afford it. To the Premier who has sacked judges, limited rights to compensation, whose commitment to privatisation exceeds his commitment to social equity and justice, I say: enough is enough. Nobody believes that ANZAC Day morning, Christmas Day and Good Friday are essential to the operations of a casino. These days are sacred days for the people of Victoria and Melbourne and they are not to be transgressed by the Premier on behalf of his friends. It is, I think, important to remind honourable members opposite of the speeches that they made when this House took the important decision that ANZAC Day was a day of national commemoration. I for one accept the sincerity of their commitments as the legislation received the unanimous endorsement of the House. These commitments do not live with the Victorian Premier's cosy complicity with the decision that fundamentally attacks those very commitments, with the decision that involves a placid acceptance that the Melbourne casino is the one and only business that can operate on Christmas Day, Good Friday and the morning of ANZAC Day. I believe the time is now appropriate for not merely members of the Victorian parliament but for members of this parliament to say to the Premier that that is not a position which is consistent with the commitment given on behalf of members of the opposition and unanimously passed by this parliament. ANZAC Day and what it stands for are too important. These other sacred ceremonies are too important. They should not be cast aside in terms of the business interests of those who are in positions of power and, unfortunately, are close friends of the Premier of Victoria. Main Committee adjourned at 12.59 p.m. NA The following answers to questions were circulated: Aeroplane Ditchings: Survivors (Question No. 2035) Mr Jones asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 8 February 1995: Is he aware of any case in the history of civil aviation in which passengers have survived a plane having been ditched; if so, will he provide details.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: REPRESENTATNES MAIN COMMITIEE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The Australian Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) does not and is not required to keep records of overseas air safety occurrences. Therefore, my response to the honourable member's question is based on reported occurrences involving civil aircraft in Australia. A search of the BASI's air safety occurrence recording system has revealed 32 occurrences involving ditching where passengers have survived the accident or incident. Details of these occurrences are: (1) On 28 March 1969, a De Havilland DH-82A aircraft ditched near King Island, Tas and the only passenger on board survived. (2) On 30 September 1970, a Cessna 177 aircraft ditched in Randalls Bay, Tas and all three passengers on board survived. (3) On 25 March 1972, a Sikorsky S-58B aircraft ditched in Darwin Harbour, NT and all nine passengers on board survived. (4) On 22 April 1973, a Piper PA-23-250 aircraft ditched near Karumba, Qld and all five passengers on board survived. (5) On 12 November 1976, a Mooney M20E aircraft ditched near Newcastle,NSW and all three passengers on board survived. (6) On 31 May 1977, a Hughes 369HS aircraft ditched in King George Sound Gulf, WA and the two passengers on board survived. (7) On 26 October 1977, a Piper PA-28-140 aircraft ditched in a river near Bankstown, NSW and the only passenger on board survived. (8) On 27 April 1981, an Aero Commander 500S aircraft ditched near Hobart, Tas and all five passengers on board survived. NA (9) On 15 August 1981, a Bell 47G-5A aircraft ditched in a lagoon near Van Rook Station, Qld and the only passenger on board survived. (10) On 26 October 1981, an American AA-IC aircraft ditched in Bateau Bay, NSW and the only passenger on board survived. (11) On 18 September 1983, a Piper PA-32R-3oo aircraft ditched near Kieta, PNG and all three passengers on board survived. (12) On 26 October 1984, a Bell 206B aircraft ditched near Bond Island, Qld and all three passengers on board survived. (13) On 29 December 1986, an Aerospatiale SA.330J aircraft ditched near Karratha, WA and thirteen of the fifteen passengers on board survived. (14) On 25 April 1987, a Cessna 182G aircraft data ditched near Groote Eylandt, NT and all four passengers on board survived. (15) On 15 January 1988, a Kawasaki BK117-A4 aircraft ditched at Balmoral Beach, NSW and the two passengers on board survived. (16) On 13 March 1988, a Cessna P2ION aircraft ditched near Outer Harbour, SA and three of the four passengers on board survived. (17) On 28 March 1988, a Bell 214ST aircraft ditched near Troughton Island, WA and all thirteen passengers on board survived. (18) On 24 June 1989, a Bell 206B aircraft ditched near Ingham, Qld and all four passengers on board survived. (19) On 3 July 1989, a Bell 206B(II1) aircraft ditched near Sydney, NSW and the two passengers on board survived. (20) On 6 October 1989, an Aero Commander 500-S aircraft ditched near Port Hedland, WA and all three passengers on board survived. (21) On 16 January 1991, a Bell 206B(III) aircraft ditched near Heron Island, Qld and all four passengers on board survived. (22) On 12 May 1991, an Aerospatiale SA.330J aircraft ditched near Karratha, WA and the only passenger on board survived. (23) On 5 July 1991, a Chrislea CH-3 Series 4 aircraft ditched near Moruya, NSW and the only passenger on board survived. (24) On 21 November 1991, a Bell 2I4ST aircraft ditched in the Timor Sea, WA and all fifteen passengers on board survived. (25) On 8 January 1992, a Cessna 210 aircraft ditched near Hamilton Island, Qld and all five passengers on board survived. (26) On 28 July 1993, a Bell 206B(III) aircraft ditched near Gladstone, Qld and one of the three passengers on board survived. (27) On 23 October 1993, a Bell 47J-2A aircraft ditched near Whyalla, SA and the only passenger on board survived. (28) On 29 November 1993, a Cessna 152 aircraft ditched near Port Stephens, NSW and the only passenger on board survived. (29) On 15 February 1994, a Bell 206B aircraft ditched near Dalywoi Bay, NT and all five passen. gers on board survived. (30) On 24 April 1994, a Douglas DC3C-SIC3G aircraft ditched in Botany Bay, NSW and all twenty-one passengers on board survived. (31) On 6 July 1994, a Cessna U206G aircraft ditched near Whyalla, SA and the only passenger on board survived. (32) On 21 September 1994, a Cessna I77RG aircraft ditched in the Gulf of Carpentaria near Massacre Point, Qld and the only passenger on board survived. Mr Tickner-The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) has provided the following information in response to the honourable member's question: (1) Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legal Services generally do not apply a specific means test to applications for assistance primarily because they believe the application of such a means test would not be cost effective. Helicopter Operations (Question No. 2475) Mr Mack asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 27 June 1995: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a letter from Mr Rob Elder, Government Relations, Civil Aviation Authority, to Ms Judith Rintoul, Northside Residents Against Helicopter Noise, dated 10 May 1995, indicating that the Minister had asked the CAA to undertake an urgent review of helicopter operations over Sydney Harbour and surrounding areas. (2) Has he asked the CAA to undertake the review referred to in part (1); if not, (a) what is the status of Mr Elder's letter and (b) why was it written. (3) If he has asked for a review to be undertaken, (a) when did he ask for the review, (b) has the review commenced, (c) what stage has the review reached, (d) what conclusions has it reached or recommendations has it made, (e) who within the CAA is responsible for the review, (f) will (i) noise, (ii) safety, (iii) heights, (iv) regulations, monitoring and (vi) other aspects of helicopter operations be considered in the review, (g) what are the guidelines or terms of reference for the review, (h) what indications or announcements have been made to (i) the general public and (ii) local councils regarding the review and its conduct, (i) what provision is there for (i) the general public or (ii) local councils to make submissions to the review, U) what are the details concerning making submissions to the review, (k) on what dates will the (i) review conclude, (ii) conclusions or recommendations be released to the public and (iii) the report be handed to him and (1) how and when will changes recommended by the review by implemented.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: GROUPS UNDER THE MODEL DIRECTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1)(2) and (3) I am aware that in May 1995 an officer of the former Civil Aviation Authority replied to a letter from Ms Judith Rintoul, Northside Residents Against Helicopter Noise, confirming that I had asked the Authority to undertake a review of helicopter operations over residential areas of Sydney with a particular focus on helicopter flights over the harbour. The initial phase of this review resulted in a decision by the newly established Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CAS A) to increase the height at which helicopters are required to fly in the prescribed access lanes east of the Sydney Harbour Bridge from 152 metres to 305 metres. I announced that change in a media release on 10 August 1995 and it was implemented on 14 September 1995. I also confirmed that this is the first in a range of measures being undertaken by CAS A and Airservices Australia in response to concerns by residents about the environmental impact of low flying and hovering helicopters around Sydney Harbour and in the vicinity of sporting and entertainment venues. CASA is reviewing all approvals given for low level helicopter operations in the Sydney area, particularly banner towing. I am advised that the Authority recently issued a policy paper to its Regional offices in relation to the requirements for bannerlflag towing operations in Australia and, in particular over Sydney Harbour. I have also called for compulsory limits for hovering times over residential areas. This activity poses a particular noise nuisance for residents. For operations other than police and essential services, CASA will have to be satisfied that any approvals are justified on both environmental and (v) safety grounds. Approvals should be granted only in exceptional circumstances. The legislation establishing CASA specifically requires the Authority to take into account the environmental effect of aircraft operations while maintaining the highest possible safety standards. The issue of the noise nuisance associated with low level helicopter operations is not confined to Sydney, and I have asked the authorities to ensure that the new arrangements apply to built-up residential areas across Australia's major cities. I understand that the Authority recently met with Airservices Australia, the Federal Airports Corporation and the NSW Environmental Protection Agency to discuss these issues. I expect that the second phase of the review will be completed by the end of the year. Any changes to the regulation of aircraft operations would require consultation with interested parties including community groups. Pension Applications and Approvals (Question No. 2588) Mr Abbott asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 28 August 1995: (1) How long does his Department take to process pension applications. (2) Does his Department keep statistics on waiting times for pension approval. (3) What is the longest delay between application for and granting of a pension. (4) Is it a fact that (a) all claims for pensions are processed within four months and (b) telephone inquiries have quick access to Departmental officers. Mr Sciacca-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) There are three major types of pensions paid by the Department: service pensions, disability pensions and war widows' pensions. Based on the first six months' statistics of 1995, it is estimated that the mean time taken to process a claim for service pension was 34 days, and 128 days for disability and war widow's pension claims. (2) Yes. (3) The longest delay between application and granting of a service pension claim in the first six months of 1995 was up to one year. However, there were only five of a total of 2 230 claims received that took 250 days or more to process during the period. The longest delay between application and granting of a disability pension claim is over two years. However, these claims were approximately 0.1 per cent of the total intake. About 1.6 per cent of such cases took over a year. (4)(a) Yes, in respect of service pension claims. The first six months' statistics of 1995 indicate that nearly 98 per cent of service pension claims were processed within 120 days. No, in respect of compensation claims. However, the Department has set a target of 120 days for processing all compensation claims with 80 per cent to be finalised within 80 days. Statistics for the first six months of 1995 of compensation claims processing are not a reliable reflection of current processing because of the recent introduction of a new Compensation Claims Processing System in all States and the use of the new Repatriation Medical Authority Statements of Principles in the determination of compensation claims. These Statements of Principles are binding on all determining authorities. Statistics for the last two months show that about 55 per cent of disability pension claims and 59 per cent of war widow's pension claims were processed within 120 days. For this period the mean time taken to process compensation claims has reduced to 119 days and is expected to continue to fall as more efficiencies in the new system are realised. (4)(b) Yes, in respect of compensation claims. Since the introduction of the new Compensation Claims Processing System, claims are processed by officers who handle all aspects of the investigation and decision, including direct telephone contact with claimants concerning their claims. Where appropriate, the Department also makes telephone contact with claimants to minimise delays in the processing of their claims for service pension. Logging (Question No. 2597) Mr Jones asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 30 August 1995: Further to the answer to question No. 2079 (Hansard, 22 August 1995, page 112), is it a fact that no statistics are readily available that indicate the relative size and productivity of the timber industry in each State and Territory, with indications of variation in practice among States and Territories; if so, on what basis is it possible for the Commonwealth to make an informed evaluation of the total number of coupes which may be logged for woodchip exports in any given year. Mr Beddall-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Statistics are available which indicate the relative size and productivity of the timber industry in each State. In addition, forest management processes in each State are determined by specific Codes of Practice, developed, implemented and overseen by relevant State Authorities. As you would be aware, under the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations, I have responsibility for refusing or granting licences for the export of woodchips. Under the regulations, I am required to give consideration to the possible effects of logging on the environment. I also have obligations to fulfil under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals), the Australian Heritage Commission and the Endangered Species Protection Acts when considering licence applications. Major exporters have been subject to Commonwealth Environmental Impact Statements and long term approvals are based on these assessments. In fulfilling these obligations, consultation is required with other Commonwealth Departments and Agencies such as the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and the Australian Heritage Commission. In making decisions on export licences for woodchips, I take into account their expert advice. However, the process is also dependent on the co-operation of the relevant States and, to this end, the Commonwealth and the States have signed the National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS) which commits both levels of government to the sustainable management and use of Australia's forests resources. Consistent with the NFPS, the Commonwealth has committed significant resources to the accelerated development of regional forest agreements (RFAs) to be signed by the Commonwealth and each State, identifying areas to be managed for conservation reserves, and areas for timber harvesting. Regional Forest Agreements will require a comprehensive assessment of the environmental, heritage, social and economic values of the forests in each region. The Commonwealth allocated $53 million over 4 years in the May Budget, for these assessments. As part of these studies, sustainable yield will be assessed. By 2000, no woodchip exports will be permitted except from areas covered by RFAs and substantial effort is being applied to their development which will obviate the need for coupe by coupe assessments in future. (Question No. 2632) Mr Hicks asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 21 September 1995: (1) What level of excise per litre of fuel was payable in March 1983. (2) When was the excise on fuel tied to the CPI. (3) When did application of the 2 cents per litre excise impost for the Bicentenary Road Fund (a) commence and (b) cease. (4) At the time it ceased, what was the effective rate of the excise referred to in part (3) as a result of the automatic CPI adjustment. (5) What revenue sum was collected from the (a) 2 cents per litre impost and (b) CPI compounded excise on that impost. (6) To what extent was the 2 cents per litre impost and compounded excise used for roads. (7) Was the additional excise resulting from CPI adjustment removed with the 2 cents per litre impost when the latter ceased; if not, what sum has been collected from the excise component comprising the CPI adjustment of the impost. (8) What sum did the Commonwealth (a) collect from fuel excise and (b) spend on road works in each year since 1982. (9) What method is used to apply parity pricing of fuel in Australia. (10) How is the excise on fuel adjusted when the world parity price falls. Mr Lee--The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) The excise rate for automotive gasoline and diesel oil in March 1983 was $0.06155 per litre. (2) Indexation of Excise Tariff rates on refined petroleum products was introduced on 23 August 1983. (3) The Department of Transport has advised: (a) 1 July 1983; and (b) 31 December 1988. (4) The Department of Transport has advised that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development (ABRD) Trust Fund Act established the rates of surcharge at 1 cent per litre for the period 17 August 1982 to 30 June 1983 and 2 cents per litre for the period 1 July 1983 to 31 December 1988. There was no provision in the Act to adjust the rate of surcharge to movements in the CPI. (5) The Department of Transport has advised: Fuel Excise (a) $2.407b l (b) Not applicable (6) The Department of Transport has advised that total receipts from the 2 cents per litre surcharge and interest on the ABRD Trust Fund was $2.407b. All of this was spent on roads. (7) Refer to answer for question 4. (8) The Department of Transport has provided the attached table. (9) The Department of the Treasury has advised: The four major oil companies-Shell, Mobil, BP and Australian Petroleum-are currently subject to prices surveillance by the Government's independent pricing body, the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA), in relation to the supply of petrol and automotive distillate. Surveillance is applied by means of wholesale price caps for sales of petrol and distillate direct to resellers and distributors set by reference to import parity prices. Under what is known as the intervention pricing system, a 'landed' cost for fuel is calculated based on import parity prices of bulk ex-refinery petrol and distillate from Singapore. Prices there closely reflect those in other major world petroleum product markets and it is the main source of imports into Australia. The Singapore product prices are adjusted to become import parity or landed prices by the addition of freight from Singapore, wharfage costs in Australia and insurance. As product and freight costs are quoted in US dollars, the value of the Australian dollar vis-a-vis the US dollar has an effect in the calculations. Intervention prices for petrol and automotive distillate are calculated daily, based on a seven day rolling average of the latest available Singapore prices. In the absence of the existing prices surveillance arrangements, the extent to which local petrol and distillate prices reflected international prices would be more fully determined by market forces. It appears that imports of petrol and distillate are a close substitute for local production, hence the domestic price of these products would be unlikely to move significantly out of line with international (import) prices provided effective competition exists at the wholesale level. Under the PSA's system, local consumers are protected as they need pay no more than international refinery prices plus 1983-84 1984-85 1985·86 1986-87 1987·88 1988-89 1989-90 1990-91 1991·92 1992-93 1993-94 1994·95 1995·96 Total Federal 1,256.50 1,293.60 1,297.40 1,216.40 1,196.10 1,194.60 Road Funding Fuel Excise 2,137.00 2,387.00 3,087.00 5,217.00 5,426.00 5,828.00 6,416.00 Collections Sources: Federal Road Funding-Federal Budget Excise Collections-Federal Budget Paper Note: "Fuel Excise Collections" includes shipping costs, local taxes, marketing and distribution costs. In addition, overseas refinery efficiency gains are reflected in domestic wholesale price caps and local refiners are given incentive to invest and employ. In the domestic LPG market, which is not subject to price regulation, major producers mostly set their prices for domestic sales on an import parity basis using the marker price established by the largest international supplier of LPG, Saudi Arabia.
